niwrap.c3d.c3d 

   1# This file was auto generated by Styx.
   2# Do not edit this file directly.

   4from styxdefs import *
   5import dataclasses
   6import pathlib
   7import typing
   8

  10    id="f1732790635348d98955440a3cbeaf174f186242",
  11    name="c3d",
  12)

  15@dataclasses.dataclass
  16class C3dAccum:
  17    """
  18    -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
  19
  20Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
  21
  22Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. 
  23
  24    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii
  25    """
  26    accum: str
  27    """-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
  28    
  29    Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
  30    
  31    Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the
  32    images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied
  33    to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of
  34    this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is
  35    the example of using the command to add multiple images.
  36    
  37    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii"""
  38    
  39    def run(
  40        self,
  41        execution: Execution,
  42    ) -> list[str]:
  43        """
  44        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
  45        
  46        Args:
  47            self: The sub-command object.
  48            execution: The execution object.
  49        Returns:
  50            
  51        """
  52        cargs = []
  53        cargs.extend(["-accum", self.accum])
  54        return cargs
  55

  83@dataclasses.dataclass
  84class C3dAdd:
  85    """
  86    -add: Voxelwise image addition
  87
  88Syntax: `-add`
  89
  90Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.
  91
  92    # Add two images: x = a + b
  93    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
  94
  95    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second
  96    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
  97    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
  98
  99    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
 100    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img
 101    """
 102    add: str
 103    """-add: Voxelwise image addition
 104    
 105    Syntax: `-add`
 106    
 107    Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the
 108    stack.
 109    
 110    # Add two images: x = a + b
 111    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
 112    
 113    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in
 114    the second
 115    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
 116    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
 117    
 118    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
 119    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img"""
 120    
 121    def run(
 122        self,
 123        execution: Execution,
 124    ) -> list[str]:
 125        """
 126        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 127        
 128        Args:
 129            self: The sub-command object.
 130            execution: The execution object.
 131        Returns:
 132            
 133        """
 134        cargs = []
 135        cargs.extend(["-add", self.add])
 136        return cargs
 137
 138
 139@dataclasses.dataclass
 140class C3dAlignLandmarks:
 141    """
 142    -alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching
 143
 144Syntax: `-alm dof outfile`
 145
 146Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes, etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom, which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the output matrix file. In this example, we have images **fixed.nii* and **moving.nii** with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align the moving image to the fixed:
 147
 148    c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat
 149    c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii
 150    """
 151    align_landmarks: str
 152    """-alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching
 153    
 154    Syntax: `-alm dof outfile`
 155    
 156    Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A
 157    landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of
 158    all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be
 159    created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes,
 160    etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and
 161    the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom,
 162    which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the
 163    output matrix file. In this example, we have images **fixed.nii* and
 164    **moving.nii** with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align
 165    the moving image to the fixed:
 166    
 167    c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat
 168    c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o
 169    moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii"""
 170    
 171    def run(
 172        self,
 173        execution: Execution,
 174    ) -> list[str]:
 175        """
 176        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 177        
 178        Args:
 179            self: The sub-command object.
 180            execution: The execution object.
 181        Returns:
 182            
 183        """
 184        cargs = []
 185        cargs.extend(["-align-landmarks", self.align_landmarks])
 186        return cargs
 187
 188
 189@dataclasses.dataclass
 190class C3dAnisotropicDiffusion:
 191    """
 192    -add: Voxelwise image addition
 193
 194Syntax: `-add`
 195
 196Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.
 197
 198    # Add two images: x = a + b
 199    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
 200
 201    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second
 202    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
 203    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
 204
 205    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
 206    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img
 207    """
 208    anisotropic_diffusion: str
 209    """-add: Voxelwise image addition
 210    
 211    Syntax: `-add`
 212    
 213    Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the
 214    stack.
 215    
 216    # Add two images: x = a + b
 217    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
 218    
 219    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in
 220    the second
 221    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
 222    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
 223    
 224    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
 225    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img"""
 226    
 227    def run(
 228        self,
 229        execution: Execution,
 230    ) -> list[str]:
 231        """
 232        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 233        
 234        Args:
 235            self: The sub-command object.
 236            execution: The execution object.
 237        Returns:
 238            
 239        """
 240        cargs = []
 241        cargs.extend(["-anisotropic-diffusion", self.anisotropic_diffusion])
 242        return cargs
 243
 244

 246class C3dAntialias:
 247    """
 248    No description found.
 249    """
 250    antialias: str
 251    """No description found."""

 254        self,
 255        execution: Execution,
 256    ) -> list[str]:

 267        cargs.extend(["-antialias", self.antialias])

 271@dataclasses.dataclass
 272class C3dSet:
 273    """
 274    -as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable
 275
 276Syntax: `-as var`
 277
 278Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name 'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using the **-push** command. The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: 
 279
 280    c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img
 281    """
 282    set_: str
 283    """-as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable
 284    
 285    Syntax: `-as var`
 286    
 287    Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name
 288    'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using
 289    the **-push** command. The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when
 290    you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation.
 291    For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image
 292    and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value
 293    0, you would use the following command:
 294    
 295    c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img"""
 296    
 297    def run(
 298        self,
 299        execution: Execution,
 300    ) -> list[str]:
 301        """
 302        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 303        
 304        Args:
 305            self: The sub-command object.
 306            execution: The execution object.
 307        Returns:
 308            
 309        """
 310        cargs = []
 311        cargs.extend(["-as", self.set_])
 312        return cargs
 313

 341@dataclasses.dataclass

 343    """
 344    -atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine
 345
 346Syntax: `-atan2`
 347
 348Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine followed by cosine): 
 349
 350    c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz
 351    """
 352    atan2: str
 353    """-atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine
 354    
 355    Syntax: `-atan2`
 356    
 357    Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This
 358    is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine
 359    followed by cosine):
 360    
 361    c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz"""
 362    
 363    def run(
 364        self,
 365        execution: Execution,
 366    ) -> list[str]:
 367        """

 371            self: The sub-command object.

 416@dataclasses.dataclass
 417class C3dN4BiasCorrection:
 418    """
 419    -biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction
 420
 421Syntax: `-biascorr`
 422
 423Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This feature uses the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4], based on the N3 algorithm by Sled et al. 
 424
 425    c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz
 426    """
 427    n4_bias_correction: str
 428    """-biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction
 429    
 430    Syntax: `-biascorr`
 431    
 432    Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This feature uses
 433    the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4], based on the N3 algorithm
 434    by Sled et al.
 435    
 436    c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz"""
 437    
 438    def run(
 439        self,
 440        execution: Execution,
 441    ) -> list[str]:

 455
 456@dataclasses.dataclass
 457class C3dBinarize:
 458    """
 459    -binarize: Convert image to binary
 460
 461Syntax: `-binarize`
 462
 463Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background is 0 by default and can be changed by the option **-background**) to 0 and all non-background values to 1. The **-binarize** command is shorthand for the **-threshold** command. 
 464
 465    c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img 
 466    c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img
 467    c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1              // equivalent to above command
 468    """
 469    binarize: str
 470    """-binarize: Convert image to binary
 471    
 472    Syntax: `-binarize`
 473    
 474    Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background
 475    is 0 by default and can be changed by the option **-background**) to 0 and
 476    all non-background values to 1. The **-binarize** command is shorthand for
 477    the **-threshold** command.
 478    
 479    c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img
 480    c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img
 481    c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1 // equivalent to above command"""
 482    
 483    def run(
 484        self,
 485        execution: Execution,
 486    ) -> list[str]:
 487        """
 488        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 489        
 490        Args:
 491            self: The sub-command object.
 492            execution: The execution object.
 493        Returns:
 494            
 495        """
 496        cargs = []
 497        cargs.extend(["-binarize", self.binarize])
 498        return cargs
 499

 501@dataclasses.dataclass
 502class C3dCanny:
 503    """
 504    -canny: Canny edge detector
 505
 506Syntax: `-canny <sigma_vector> <t_lower> <t_upper>`
 507
 508Performs edge detection on the last image on the stack using the Canny filter. The parameters are a vector of standard deviations defining the scale of the edges detected and lower and upper thresholds for edge selection. See documentation on the [ITK Canny Filter][14].
 509    """
 510    canny: str
 511    """-canny: Canny edge detector
 512    
 513    Syntax: `-canny <sigma_vector> <t_lower> <t_upper>`
 514    
 515    Performs edge detection on the last image on the stack using the Canny
 516    filter. The parameters are a vector of standard deviations defining the
 517    scale of the edges detected and lower and upper thresholds for edge
 518    selection. See documentation on the [ITK Canny Filter][14]."""
 519

 577@dataclasses.dataclass
 578class C3dCentroid:
 579    """
 580    -centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels
 581
 582Syntax: `-centroid`
 583
 584Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in the image. 
 585
 586    c3d binaryimage.img -centroid                         // centroid of all non-0 voxels
 587    c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1   // centroid of all voxels in range 1000-7000
 588    c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid          // centroid of all voxels with label 5
 589    c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor  // centroids of all labels (including 0)
 590    """
 591    centroid: str
 592    """-centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels
 593    
 594    Syntax: `-centroid`
 595    
 596    Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in
 597    the image.
 598    
 599    c3d binaryimage.img -centroid // centroid of all non-0 voxels
 600    c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1 // centroid of all
 601    voxels in range 1000-7000
 602    c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid // centroid of all voxels with
 603    label 5
 604    c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor // centroids of all
 605    labels (including 0)"""
 606    
 607    def run(
 608        self,
 609        execution: Execution,
 610    ) -> list[str]:
 611        """
 612        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 613        
 614        Args:
 615            self: The sub-command object.
 616            execution: The execution object.
 617        Returns:
 618            
 619        """
 620        cargs = []
 621        cargs.extend(["-centroid", self.centroid])
 622        return cargs
 623
 624
 625@dataclasses.dataclass
 626class C3dCentroidMark:
 627    """
 628    -centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels
 629
 630Syntax: `-centroid-mark <label>`
 631
 632Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike **-centroid**, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks the closest voxel in the image with the intensity **label**. The remaining voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to mark centers of regions with spheres.
 633
 634    c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3
 635    c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o centers.nii
 636    """
 637    centroid_mark: str
 638    """-centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels
 639    
 640    Syntax: `-centroid-mark <label>`
 641    
 642    Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike
 643    **-centroid**, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks
 644    the closest voxel in the image with the intensity **label**. The remaining
 645    voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to
 646    mark centers of regions with spheres.
 647    
 648    c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3
 649    c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o
 650    centers.nii"""
 651    
 652    def run(
 653        self,
 654        execution: Execution,
 655    ) -> list[str]:
 656        """
 657        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 658        
 659        Args:
 660            self: The sub-command object.
 661            execution: The execution object.
 662        Returns:
 663            
 664        """
 665        cargs = []
 666        cargs.extend(["-centroid-mark", self.centroid_mark])
 667        return cargs
 668
 669
 670@dataclasses.dataclass
 671class C3dConnectedComponents:
 672    """
 673    -comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components
 674
 675Syntax: `-comp`
 676
 677Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component, combine the call to **-comp** with a call to **-threshold**. 
 678
 679    c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img
 680    c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img
 681    """
 682    connected_components: str
 683    """-comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components
 684    
 685    Syntax: `-comp`
 686    
 687    Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected
 688    component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of
 689    the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The
 690    background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component,
 691    combine the call to **-comp** with a call to **-threshold**.
 692    
 693    c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img
 694    c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img"""
 695    
 696    def run(
 697        self,
 698        execution: Execution,
 699    ) -> list[str]:
 700        """
 701        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 702        
 703        Args:
 704            self: The sub-command object.
 705            execution: The execution object.
 706        Returns:
 707            
 708        """
 709        cargs = []
 710        cargs.extend(["-connected-components", self.connected_components])
 711        return cargs
 712
 713

 717    -clear: Clear the image stack
 718
 719Syntax: `-clear` 
 720
 721Clears the image stack. Images assigned a name with the **-as** command will remain in memory.

 723    clear_: str

 725    
 726    Syntax: `-clear`
 727    
 728    Clears the image stack. Images assigned a name with the **-as** command will
 729    remain in memory."""

 733        execution: Execution,

 748
 749@dataclasses.dataclass
 750class C3dClip:
 751    """
 752    -clip: Clip image intensity to range
 753
 754Syntax: `-clip iMin iMax`
 755
 756Clips image intensities, so that the values below *iMin* are converted to *iMin* and values greater than *iMax* are converted to *iMax*. This is useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values *iMin* and *iMax* are intensity specifications (see below). 
 757
 758    c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img          // Clips below and above
 759    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img          // Clips above only
 760    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img           // Clips at 95th percentile
 761    """
 762    clip: str
 763    """-clip: Clip image intensity to range
 764    
 765    Syntax: `-clip iMin iMax`
 766    
 767    Clips image intensities, so that the values below *iMin* are converted to
 768    *iMin* and values greater than *iMax* are converted to *iMax*. This is
 769    useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values *iMin* and *iMax*
 770    are intensity specifications (see below).
 771    
 772    c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img // Clips below and above
 773    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img // Clips above only
 774    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img // Clips at 95th percentile"""
 775    
 776    def run(
 777        self,
 778        execution: Execution,
 779    ) -> list[str]:
 780        """
 781        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 782        
 783        Args:
 784            self: The sub-command object.
 785            execution: The execution object.
 786        Returns:
 787            
 788        """
 789        cargs = []
 790        cargs.extend(["-clip", self.clip])
 791        return cargs
 792
 793
 794@dataclasses.dataclass
 795class C3dColorMap:
 796    """
 797    -color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map    
 798
 799Syntax: `-color-map <ColormapName> [min max]`
 800
 801Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map. The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input image, e.g., using the **jet** color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped to red. The admissible color maps are **hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder**. The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image. 
 802
 803    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
 804
 805By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional **min** and **max** parameters can be used to set the range of the color map. 
 806
 807    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
 808    """
 809    color_map: str
 810    """-color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map
 811    
 812    Syntax: `-color-map <ColormapName> [min max]`
 813    
 814    Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map.
 815    The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and
 816    blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input
 817    image, e.g., using the **jet** color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the
 818    image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped
 819    to red. The admissible color maps are
 820    **hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder**.
 821    The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The
 822    example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image.
 823    
 824    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc
 825    colorslice.png
 826    
 827    By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional **min**
 828    and **max** parameters can be used to set the range of the color map.
 829    
 830    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc
 831    colorslice.png"""
 832    
 833    def run(
 834        self,
 835        execution: Execution,
 836    ) -> list[str]:
 837        """
 838        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 839        
 840        Args:
 841            self: The sub-command object.
 842            execution: The execution object.
 843        Returns:
 844            
 845        """
 846        cargs = []
 847        cargs.extend(["-colormap", self.color_map])
 848        return cargs
 849
 850
 851@dataclasses.dataclass
 852class C3dCompress:
 853    """
 854    -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
 855
 856Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
 857
 858Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
 859
 860    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
 861    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha
 862    """
 863    compress: str
 864    """-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
 865    
 866    Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
 867    
 868    Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file
 869    formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the
 870    filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage,
 871    you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two
 872    commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
 873    
 874    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
 875    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha"""
 876    
 877    def run(
 878        self,
 879        execution: Execution,
 880    ) -> list[str]:
 881        """
 882        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 883        
 884        Args:
 885            self: The sub-command object.
 886            execution: The execution object.
 887        Returns:
 888            
 889        """
 890        cargs = []
 891        cargs.extend(["-compress", self.compress])
 892        return cargs
 893
 894
 895@dataclasses.dataclass
 896class C3dNoCompress:
 897    """
 898    -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
 899
 900Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
 901
 902Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
 903
 904    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
 905    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha
 906    """
 907    no_compress: str
 908    """-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
 909    
 910    Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
 911    
 912    Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file
 913    formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the
 914    filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage,
 915    you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two
 916    commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
 917    
 918    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
 919    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha"""
 920    
 921    def run(
 922        self,
 923        execution: Execution,
 924    ) -> list[str]:
 925        """
 926        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 927        
 928        Args:
 929            self: The sub-command object.
 930            execution: The execution object.
 931        Returns:
 932            
 933        """
 934        cargs = []
 935        cargs.extend(["-no-compress", self.no_compress])
 936        return cargs
 937
 938
 939@dataclasses.dataclass
 940class C3dConv:
 941    """
 942    -conv: Convolution
 943
 944Syntax `-conv`
 945
 946Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see ["FFT Based Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann][Lehmann].
 947
 948    c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii
 949
 950
 951[Lehmann]: https://hdl.handle.net/10380/3154
 952    """
 953    conv: str
 954    """-conv: Convolution
 955    
 956    Syntax `-conv`
 957    
 958    Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The
 959    convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image
 960    of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see ["FFT Based
 961    Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann][Lehmann].
 962    
 963    c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii
 964    
 965    
 966    [Lehmann]: https://hdl.handle.net/10380/3154"""
 967    
 968    def run(
 969        self,
 970        execution: Execution,
 971    ) -> list[str]:
 972        """
 973        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
 974        
 975        Args:
 976            self: The sub-command object.
 977            execution: The execution object.
 978        Returns:
 979            
 980        """
 981        cargs = []
 982        cargs.extend(["-conv", self.conv])
 983        return cargs
 984
 985
 986@dataclasses.dataclass
 987class C3dCoordinateMapVoxel:
 988    """
 989    -cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)
 990
 991Syntax: `-cmv`
 992
 993For a *N*-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with *N* images. The *k*-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate of that voxel, in voxel units.
 994
 995    c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz
 996
 997One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)
 998
 999    c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop  -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK \
1000        -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz \
1001        -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 \
1002        -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz
1003    """
1004    coordinate_map_voxel: str
1005    """-cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)
1006    
1007    Syntax: `-cmv`
1008    
1009    For a *N*-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with *N*
1010    images. The *k*-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate
1011    of that voxel, in voxel units.
1012    
1013    c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz
1014    
1015    One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left
1016    hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X
1017    coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)
1018    
1019    c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK \
1020    -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz \
1021    -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 \
1022    -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz"""
1023    
1024    def run(
1025        self,
1026        execution: Execution,
1027    ) -> list[str]:
1028        """
1029        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1030        
1031        Args:
1032            self: The sub-command object.
1033            execution: The execution object.
1034        Returns:
1035            
1036        """
1037        cargs = []
1038        cargs.extend(["-coordinate-map-voxel", self.coordinate_map_voxel])
1039        return cargs
1040
1041
1042@dataclasses.dataclass
1043class C3dCoordinateMapPhysical:
1044    """
1045    -cmp, -coordinate-map-physical: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)
1046
1047Syntax: `-cmp`
1048
1049This command is similar to **-cmv** (**-coordinate-map-voxel**), but the output will contain the physical coordinates of the voxels, in the NIFTI (RAS) coordinate frame.
1050    """
1051    coordinate_map_physical: str
1052    """-cmp, -coordinate-map-physical: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel
1053    units)
1054    
1055    Syntax: `-cmp`
1056    
1057    This command is similar to **-cmv** (**-coordinate-map-voxel**), but the
1058    output will contain the physical coordinates of the voxels, in the NIFTI
1059    (RAS) coordinate frame."""
1060    
1061    def run(
1062        self,
1063        execution: Execution,
1064    ) -> list[str]:
1065        """
1066        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1067        
1068        Args:
1069            self: The sub-command object.
1070            execution: The execution object.
1071        Returns:
1072            
1073        """
1074        cargs = []
1075        cargs.extend(["-coordinate-map-physical", self.coordinate_map_physical])
1076        return cargs

1078
1079@dataclasses.dataclass
1080class C3dCopyTransform:
1081    """
1082    -copy-transform: Copy header information 
1083
1084Syntax: `-copy-transform`
1085
1086Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store this information well. In the example below, *out.nii* will have the same header as *first.nii* and the same intensities as *second.nii*.
1087
1088    c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii
1089    """
1090    copy_transform: str
1091    """-copy-transform: Copy header information
1092    
1093    Syntax: `-copy-transform`
1094    
1095    Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform
1096    (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to
1097    the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store
1098    this information well. In the example below, *out.nii* will have the same
1099    header as *first.nii* and the same intensities as *second.nii*.
1100    
1101    c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii"""
1102    
1103    def run(
1104        self,
1105        execution: Execution,
1106    ) -> list[str]:
1107        """
1108        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1109        
1110        Args:
1111            self: The sub-command object.
1112            execution: The execution object.
1113        Returns:
1114            
1115        """
1116        cargs = []
1117        cargs.extend(["-copy-transform", self.copy_transform])
1118        return cargs
1119

1147@dataclasses.dataclass
1148class C3dCreate:
1149    """
1150    -create: Generate blank image
1151
1152Syntax: `-create dimensions voxel_size`
1153
1154Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the **-background** command. The origin of the image can be changed with the **-origin** command. 
1155
1156    c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img
1157    c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o newimage.img
1158    """
1159    create: str
1160    """-create: Generate blank image
1161    
1162    Syntax: `-create dimensions voxel_size`
1163    
1164    Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and
1165    places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current
1166    background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the
1167    **-background** command. The origin of the image can be changed with the
1168    **-origin** command.
1169    
1170    c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img
1171    c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o
1172    newimage.img"""
1173    
1174    def run(
1175        self,
1176        execution: Execution,
1177    ) -> list[str]:
1178        """
1179        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1180        
1181        Args:
1182            self: The sub-command object.
1183            execution: The execution object.
1184        Returns:
1185            
1186        """
1187        cargs = []
1188        cargs.extend(["-create", self.create])
1189        return cargs
1190

1227@dataclasses.dataclass
1228class C3dDicomSeriesRead:
1229    """
1230    -dicom-series-read: Read a DICOM image series
1231
1232Syntax: `-dicom-series-read <directory> <series_id>`
1233
1234Imports a specific DICOM image series from a directory containing DICOM files. The **directory** parameter may also point to one of the DICOM files in the directory.
1235The **seried_id** is a string identifier for the series that can be obtained by calling **-dicom-series-list**
1236    """
1237    dicom_series_read: str
1238    """-dicom-series-read: Read a DICOM image series
1239    
1240    Syntax: `-dicom-series-read <directory> <series_id>`
1241    
1242    Imports a specific DICOM image series from a directory containing DICOM
1243    files. The **directory** parameter may also point to one of the DICOM files
1244    in the directory.
1245    The **seried_id** is a string identifier for the series that can be obtained
1246    by calling **-dicom-series-list**"""
1247    
1248    def run(
1249        self,
1250        execution: Execution,
1251    ) -> list[str]:
1252        """
1253        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1254

1256            self: The sub-command object.

1258        Returns:
1259

1261        cargs = []
1262        cargs.extend(["-dicom-series-read", self.dicom_series_read])

1266@dataclasses.dataclass
1267class C3dDilate:
1268    """
1269    -dilate: Binary dilation
1270
1271Syntax: `-dilate <label> <radius_vector>`
1272
1273Applies the dilation [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a binary image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the object that is to be dilated. The second is the radius of the dilation structuring element in 3D. 
1274
1275    c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img
1276    """
1277    dilate: str
1278    """-dilate: Binary dilation
1279    
1280    Syntax: `-dilate <label> <radius_vector>`
1281    
1282    Applies the dilation [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a binary
1283    image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the object that is to
1284    be dilated. The second is the radius of the dilation structuring element in
1285    3D.
1286    
1287    c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img"""
1288    
1289    def run(
1290        self,
1291        execution: Execution,
1292    ) -> list[str]:
1293        """
1294        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1295        
1296        Args:
1297            self: The sub-command object.
1298            execution: The execution object.
1299        Returns:
1300            
1301        """
1302        cargs = []
1303        cargs.extend(["-dilate", self.dilate])
1304        return cargs

1307@dataclasses.dataclass
1308class C3dDivide:
1309    """
1310    -divide: Voxelwise image division    
1311
1312Syntax: `-divide`
1313
1314Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the command 
1315
1316    c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img
1317
1318Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains zeros. You can use **-replace** to get rid of these values
1319
1320    c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img
1321    """
1322    divide: str
1323    """-divide: Voxelwise image division
1324    
1325    Syntax: `-divide`
1326    
1327    Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the
1328    command
1329    
1330    c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img
1331    
1332    Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains
1333    zeros. You can use **-replace** to get rid of these values
1334    
1335    c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img"""
1336    
1337    def run(
1338        self,
1339        execution: Execution,
1340    ) -> list[str]:
1341        """
1342        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1343        
1344        Args:
1345            self: The sub-command object.
1346            execution: The execution object.
1347        Returns:
1348            
1349        """
1350        cargs = []
1351        cargs.extend(["-divide", self.divide])
1352        return cargs
1353
1354
1355@dataclasses.dataclass
1356class C3dDuplicate:
1357    """
1358    -dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack
1359
1360Syntax: `-dup` 
1361
1362Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to **-as var -push var**, but shorter. An example is when you want to pass an image as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g., computing the square of the image intensity: 
1363
1364    c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img
1365
1366### Commands: Voxelwise Calculations
1367    """
1368    duplicate: str
1369    """-dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack
1370    
1371    Syntax: `-dup`
1372    
1373    Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to **-as
1374    var -push var**, but shorter. An example is when you want to pass an image
1375    as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g., computing the square of the
1376    image intensity:
1377    
1378    c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img
1379    
1380    ### Commands: Voxelwise Calculations"""
1381    
1382    def run(
1383        self,
1384        execution: Execution,
1385    ) -> list[str]:
1386        """
1387        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1388        
1389        Args:
1390            self: The sub-command object.
1391            execution: The execution object.
1392        Returns:
1393            
1394        """
1395        cargs = []
1396        cargs.extend(["-dup", self.duplicate])
1397        return cargs
1398
1399
1400@dataclasses.dataclass
1401class C3dEndaccum:
1402    """
1403    -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
1404
1405Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
1406
1407Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. 
1408
1409    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii
1410    """
1411    endaccum: str
1412    """-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
1413    
1414    Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
1415    
1416    Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the
1417    images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied
1418    to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of
1419    this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is
1420    the example of using the command to add multiple images.
1421    
1422    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii"""
1423    
1424    def run(
1425        self,
1426        execution: Execution,
1427    ) -> list[str]:
1428        """
1429        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1430        
1431        Args:
1432            self: The sub-command object.
1433            execution: The execution object.
1434        Returns:
1435            
1436        """
1437        cargs = []
1438        cargs.extend(["-endaccum", self.endaccum])
1439        return cargs
1440

1442@dataclasses.dataclass
1443class C3dEndfor:
1444    """
1445    -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1446
1447Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1448
1449This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, 
1450
1451    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii
1452    """
1453    endfor: str
1454    """-foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1455    
1456    Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1457    
1458    This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be
1459    applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to
1460    automate processing of multiple datasets. For example,
1461    
1462    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii"""
1463    
1464    def run(
1465        self,
1466        execution: Execution,
1467    ) -> list[str]:
1468        """
1469        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1470        
1471        Args:
1472            self: The sub-command object.
1473            execution: The execution object.
1474        Returns:
1475            
1476        """
1477        cargs = []
1478        cargs.extend(["-endfor", self.endfor])
1479        return cargs

1485    -erode: Binary erosion
1486
1487Syntax: `-erode <label> <radius_vector>`
1488

1490
1491    c3d binary.img -erode 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img
1492    """
1493    erode: str

1500    eroded. The second is the radius of the erosion structuring element in 3D.
1501    
1502    c3d binary.img -erode 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img"""

1522@dataclasses.dataclass
1523class C3dErf:
1524    """
1525    -erf: Standard error function
1526
1527Syntax: `-erf mu sigma`
1528
1529Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma). 
1530
1531    c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img
1532    """
1533    erf: str
1534    """-erf: Standard error function
1535    
1536    Syntax: `-erf mu sigma`
1537    
1538    Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft
1539    thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma).
1540    
1541    c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img"""
1542    
1543    def run(
1544        self,
1545        execution: Execution,
1546    ) -> list[str]:
1547        """
1548        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1549        
1550        Args:
1551            self: The sub-command object.
1552            execution: The execution object.
1553        Returns:
1554            
1555        """
1556        cargs = []
1557        cargs.extend(["-erf", self.erf])
1558        return cargs

1561@dataclasses.dataclass
1562class C3dExp:
1563    """
1564    -exp: Voxelwise natural exponent
1565
1566Syntax: `-exp`
1567
1568Computes exponent of each voxel in the last image on the stack.
1569
1570    c3d input.img -exp -o output.img
1571    """
1572    exp: str
1573    """-exp: Voxelwise natural exponent
1574    
1575    Syntax: `-exp`
1576    
1577    Computes exponent of each voxel in the last image on the stack.
1578    
1579    c3d input.img -exp -o output.img"""
1580    
1581    def run(
1582        self,
1583        execution: Execution,
1584    ) -> list[str]:
1585        """
1586        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1587        
1588        Args:
1589            self: The sub-command object.
1590            execution: The execution object.
1591        Returns:
1592            
1593        """
1594        cargs = []
1595        cargs.extend(["-exp", self.exp])
1596        return cargs
1597
1598
1599@dataclasses.dataclass
1600class C3dExportPatches:
1601    """
1602    -export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions
1603
1604Syntax: `-export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>`
1605
1606See also: **-export-patches-aug (-xpa)** command, which provides data augmentation for deep learning.
1607
1608This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example, NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.
1609
1610    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
1611
1612This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.
1613
1614To read these samples in NumPy use the following code
1615
1616    dims = (9,9,9)                          # Patch dimensions
1617    k = 3                                   # Number of channels
1618    bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1))    # Bytes per sample
1619    np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps      # Number of samples
1620    arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)
1621
1622It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples.
1623
1624The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion, as follows:
1625
1626    c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1
1627
1628In the above example, **-centroid-mark** transforms the lesion segmentation into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken.
1629    """
1630    export_patches: str
1631    """-export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions
1632    
1633    Syntax: `-export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>`
1634    
1635    See also: **-export-patches-aug (-xpa)** command, which provides data
1636    augmentation for deep learning.
1637    
1638    This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them
1639    into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example,
1640    NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning
1641    projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.
1642    
1643    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
1644    
1645    This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground
1646    voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled
1647    randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that
1648    every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that
1649    patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled
1650    intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.
1651    
1652    To read these samples in NumPy use the following code
1653    
1654    dims = (9,9,9) # Patch dimensions
1655    k = 3 # Number of channels
1656    bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1)) # Bytes per sample
1657    np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps # Number of samples
1658    arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)
1659    
1660    It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by
1661    reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the
1662    patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples.
1663    
1664    The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if
1665    we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in
1666    an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion,
1667    as follows:
1668    
1669    c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1
1670    
1671    In the above example, **-centroid-mark** transforms the lesion segmentation
1672    into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken."""
1673    
1674    def run(
1675        self,
1676        execution: Execution,
1677    ) -> list[str]:
1678        """
1679        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1680        
1681        Args:
1682            self: The sub-command object.
1683            execution: The execution object.
1684        Returns:
1685            
1686        """
1687        cargs = []
1688        cargs.extend(["-export-patches", self.export_patches])
1689        return cargs
1690
1691
1692@dataclasses.dataclass
1693class C3dExportPatchesAug:
1694    """
1695    -export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning
1696
1697Syntax `-export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>`
1698
1699This command must precede the `-export-patches (-xp)` command and instructs this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also sample **N** randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh standard deviation **sigma_angle**, specified in degrees. This kind of sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms.
1700
1701    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
1702    """
1703    export_patches_aug: str
1704    """-export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning
1705    
1706    Syntax `-export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>`
1707    
1708    This command must precede the `-export-patches (-xp)` command and instructs
1709    this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also
1710    sample **N** randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly
1711    distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh
1712    standard deviation **sigma_angle**, specified in degrees. This kind of
1713    sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms.
1714    
1715    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4
1716    100"""
1717    
1718    def run(
1719        self,
1720        execution: Execution,
1721    ) -> list[str]:
1722        """
1723        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1724        
1725        Args:
1726            self: The sub-command object.
1727            execution: The execution object.
1728        Returns:
1729            
1730        """
1731        cargs = []
1732        cargs.extend(["-export-patches-aug", self.export_patches_aug])
1733        return cargs
1734

1788@dataclasses.dataclass
1789class C3dFft:
1790    """
1791    -fft: Fast Fourier transform
1792
1793Syntax `-fft`
1794
1795Computes the Fourier transform of a real-valued image at the end of the stack. The image is replaced by the real and imaginary components of the FFT. This command is only available if **convert3d** is compiled with the FFTW library support. 
1796
1797    c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii
1798    """
1799    fft: str
1800    """-fft: Fast Fourier transform
1801    
1802    Syntax `-fft`
1803    
1804    Computes the Fourier transform of a real-valued image at the end of the
1805    stack. The image is replaced by the real and imaginary components of the
1806    FFT. This command is only available if **convert3d** is compiled with the
1807    FFTW library support.
1808    
1809    c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii"""
1810    
1811    def run(
1812        self,
1813        execution: Execution,
1814    ) -> list[str]:

1820            execution: The execution object.
1821        Returns:
1822            
1823        """
1824        cargs = []
1825        cargs.extend(["-fft", self.fft])

1868@dataclasses.dataclass
1869class C3dFloor:
1870    """
1871    -floor: Round down image intensities
1872
1873Syntax: `-floor `
1874
1875Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or equal to it.
1876
1877    c3d input.img -floor -o output.img
1878
1879To round each intensity to the closest integer, use
1880
1881    c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor
1882    """
1883    floor: str
1884    """-floor: Round down image intensities
1885    
1886    Syntax: `-floor `
1887    
1888    Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or equal to
1889    it.
1890    
1891    c3d input.img -floor -o output.img
1892    
1893    To round each intensity to the closest integer, use
1894    
1895    c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor"""
1896    
1897    def run(
1898        self,
1899        execution: Execution,
1900    ) -> list[str]:
1901        """
1902        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1903        
1904        Args:
1905            self: The sub-command object.
1906            execution: The execution object.
1907        Returns:
1908            
1909        """
1910        cargs = []
1911        cargs.extend(["-floor", self.floor])
1912        return cargs

1915@dataclasses.dataclass
1916class C3dForeach:
1917    """
1918    -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1919
1920Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1921
1922This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, 
1923
1924    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii
1925    """
1926    foreach: str
1927    """-foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1928    
1929    Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1930    
1931    This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be
1932    applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to
1933    automate processing of multiple datasets. For example,
1934    
1935    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii"""
1936    
1937    def run(
1938        self,
1939        execution: Execution,
1940    ) -> list[str]:
1941        """
1942        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1943        
1944        Args:
1945            self: The sub-command object.
1946            execution: The execution object.
1947        Returns:
1948            
1949        """
1950        cargs = []
1951        cargs.extend(["-foreach", self.foreach])
1952        return cargs
1953
1954
1955@dataclasses.dataclass
1956class C3dForeachComp:
1957    """
1958    -foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a multi-component image 
1959
1960Syntax `-foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor`
1961
1962This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack contains images *x1* *y1* *z1* *x2* *y2* *z2*, then the operations will be run on *[x1,x2]*, *[y1,y2]*, *[z1,z2]*. For example, if multi_1.nii to multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image is given by
1963
1964    c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii
1965    """
1966    foreach_comp: str
1967    """-foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a
1968    multi-component image
1969    
1970    Syntax `-foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor`
1971    
1972    This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a
1973    set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to
1974    perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it
1975    can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack
1976    contains images *x1* *y1* *z1* *x2* *y2* *z2*, then the operations will be
1977    run on *[x1,x2]*, *[y1,y2]*, *[z1,z2]*. For example, if multi_1.nii to
1978    multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image
1979    is given by
1980    
1981    c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii"""
1982    
1983    def run(
1984        self,
1985        execution: Execution,
1986    ) -> list[str]:
1987        """
1988        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1989        
1990        Args:
1991            self: The sub-command object.
1992            execution: The execution object.
1993        Returns:
1994            
1995        """
1996        cargs = []
1997        cargs.extend(["-foreach-comp", self.foreach_comp])
1998        return cargs
1999
2000
2001@dataclasses.dataclass
2002class C3dGlm:
2003    """
2004    -glm: General linear model    
2005
2006Syntax: `-glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file`
2007
2008Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely, the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X \beta + \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $\beta$ is a set of $k$ unknown images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute the $\beta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds., *Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition*][6]. The example below computes the regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's age: 
2009
2010      echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt
2011      echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt
2012      echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt
2013      echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt
2014      echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt
2015      c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img
2016    """
2017    glm: str
2018    """-glm: General linear model
2019    
2020    Syntax: `-glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file`
2021    
2022    Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely,
2023    the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X \beta +
2024    \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each
2025    voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design
2026    matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $\beta$ is a set of $k$ unknown
2027    images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute
2028    the $\beta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are
2029    specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector
2030    are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of
2031    numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel
2032    and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds.,
2033    *Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition*][6]. The example below computes the
2034    regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's
2035    age:
2036    
2037    echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt
2038    echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt
2039    echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt
2040    echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt
2041    echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt
2042    c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt
2043    contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img"""
2044    
2045    def run(
2046        self,
2047        execution: Execution,
2048    ) -> list[str]:
2049        """
2050        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2051        
2052        Args:
2053            self: The sub-command object.
2054            execution: The execution object.
2055        Returns:
2056            
2057        """
2058        cargs = []
2059        cargs.extend(["-glm", self.glm])
2060        return cargs
2061
2062
2063@dataclasses.dataclass
2064class C3dGradient:
2065    """
2066    -grad, -gradient: Image gradient
2067
2068Syntax `-grad`
2069
2070Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to smooth the image first before computing the gradient.
2071
2072    c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii
2073    """
2074    gradient: str
2075    """-grad, -gradient: Image gradient
2076    
2077    Syntax `-grad`
2078    
2079    Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed
2080    on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS
2081    coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other
2082    words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the
2083    isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to
2084    smooth the image first before computing the gradient.
2085    
2086    c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii"""
2087    
2088    def run(
2089        self,
2090        execution: Execution,
2091    ) -> list[str]:
2092        """
2093        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2094        
2095        Args:
2096            self: The sub-command object.
2097            execution: The execution object.
2098        Returns:
2099            
2100        """
2101        cargs = []
2102        cargs.extend(["-grad", self.gradient])
2103        return cargs
2104
2105
2106@dataclasses.dataclass
2107class C3dHelp:
2108    """
2109    -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2110
2111Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2112
2113Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.
2114
2115    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
2116    """
2117    v__help: str
2118    """-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2119    
2120    Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2121    
2122    Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues
2123    of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on
2124    the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the
2125    '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing
2126    applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in
2127    physical (mm) units.
2128    
2129    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz"""
2130    
2131    def run(
2132        self,
2133        execution: Execution,
2134    ) -> list[str]:
2135        """
2136        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2137        
2138        Args:
2139            self: The sub-command object.
2140            execution: The execution object.
2141        Returns:
2142            
2143        """
2144        cargs = []
2145        cargs.extend(["-h", self.v__help])
2146        return cargs
2147
2148
2149@dataclasses.dataclass
2150class C3dHolefill:
2151    """
2152    -holefill: Fill holes in binary image
2153
2154Syntax: `-holefill intensity_value [0|1] `
2155
2156Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this algorithm][7]. 
2157
2158    c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz
2159    """
2160    holefill: str
2161    """-holefill: Fill holes in binary image
2162    
2163    Syntax: `-holefill intensity_value [0|1] `
2164    
2165    Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in
2166    the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label
2167    segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value
2168    that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The
2169    second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to
2170    determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face
2171    connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and
2172    vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this
2173    algorithm][7].
2174    
2175    c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz"""
2176    
2177    def run(
2178        self,
2179        execution: Execution,
2180    ) -> list[str]:
2181        """
2182        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2183        
2184        Args:
2185            self: The sub-command object.
2186            execution: The execution object.
2187        Returns:
2188            
2189        """
2190        cargs = []
2191        cargs.extend(["-hf", self.holefill])
2192        return cargs
2193
2194
2195@dataclasses.dataclass
2196class C3dHessianEigenvalues:
2197    """
2198    -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2199
2200Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2201
2202Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.
2203
2204    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
2205    """
2206    hessian_eigenvalues: str
2207    """-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2208    
2209    Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2210    
2211    Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues
2212    of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on
2213    the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the
2214    '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing
2215    applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in
2216    physical (mm) units.
2217    
2218    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz"""
2219    
2220    def run(
2221        self,
2222        execution: Execution,
2223    ) -> list[str]:
2224        """
2225        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2226        
2227        Args:
2228            self: The sub-command object.
2229            execution: The execution object.
2230        Returns:
2231            
2232        """
2233        cargs = []
2234        cargs.extend(["-hesseig", self.hessian_eigenvalues])
2235        return cargs
2236
2237
2238@dataclasses.dataclass
2239class C3dHessianObjectness:
2240    """
2241    -hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter
2242
2243Syntax: `-hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>`
2244
2245Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF]. 
2246
2247Parameter `dimension` is an integer that determines the kind of features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is used.
2248
2249    # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm
2250    c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5
2251
2252 [HTOMIF] http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html
2253    """
2254    hessian_objectness: str
2255    """-hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter
2256    
2257    Syntax: `-hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>`
2258    
2259    Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to
2260    highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For
2261    details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF].
2262    
2263    Parameter `dimension` is an integer that determines the kind of features
2264    that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The
2265    min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of
2266    the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is
2267    used.
2268    
2269    # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm
2270    c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5
2271    
2272    [HTOMIF]
2273    http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html"""
2274    
2275    def run(
2276        self,
2277        execution: Execution,
2278    ) -> list[str]:
2279        """
2280        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2281        
2282        Args:
2283            self: The sub-command object.
2284            execution: The execution object.
2285        Returns:
2286            
2287        """
2288        cargs = []
2289        cargs.extend(["-hessobj", self.hessian_objectness])
2290        return cargs
2291

2404
2405@dataclasses.dataclass
2406class C3dInsert:
2407    """
2408    -insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack
2409
2410Syntax: `-insert var pos` 
2411
2412This command is similar to **-push**, but allows you to insert the image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as **-push**). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end position, and so on.
2413    """
2414    insert: str
2415    """-insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack
2416    
2417    Syntax: `-insert var pos`
2418    
2419    This command is similar to **-push**, but allows you to insert the image
2420    associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end.
2421    When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as
2422    **-push**). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end
2423    position, and so on."""
2424    
2425    def run(
2426        self,
2427        execution: Execution,
2428    ) -> list[str]:
2429        """
2430        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2431        
2432        Args:
2433            self: The sub-command object.
2434            execution: The execution object.
2435        Returns:
2436            
2437        """
2438        cargs = []
2439        cargs.extend(["-insert", self.insert])
2440        return cargs
2441
2442
2443@dataclasses.dataclass
2444class C3dInterpolation:
2445    """
2446    -interpolation: Set interpolation mode
2447
2448Syntax: `-interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param]`
2449
2450Specifies the interpolation used with **-resample** and other commands. Default is **Linear**. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with small sigmas (a few voxels across). 
2451
2452Shorthand 0 can be used for *NearestNeighbor*, 1 for *Linear* and 3 for *Cubic*. For example:
2453
2454    c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii
2455    """
2456    interpolation: str
2457    """-interpolation: Set interpolation mode
2458    
2459    Syntax: `-interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian>
2460    [param]`
2461    
2462    Specifies the interpolation used with **-resample** and other commands.
2463    Default is **Linear**. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the
2464    standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation
2465    is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter
2466    and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and
2467    has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with
2468    small sigmas (a few voxels across).
2469    
2470    Shorthand 0 can be used for *NearestNeighbor*, 1 for *Linear* and 3 for
2471    *Cubic*. For example:
2472    
2473    c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii"""
2474    
2475    def run(
2476        self,
2477        execution: Execution,
2478    ) -> list[str]:
2479        """
2480        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2481        
2482        Args:
2483            self: The sub-command object.
2484            execution: The execution object.
2485        Returns:
2486            
2487        """
2488        cargs = []
2489        cargs.extend(["-interpolation", self.interpolation])
2490        return cargs
2491
2492
