5163
5164@dataclasses.dataclass
5165class C3dRfApply:
5166    """
5167    -rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier 
5168
5169Syntax: `-rf-apply <classifier_file>`
5170
5171This command applies a classifier trained previously by **-rf-train**. The stack must contain the same number of feature images as when training. The images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See examples under **-rf-train** for usage.
5172    """
5173    rf_apply: str
5174    """-rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier
5175    
5176    Syntax: `-rf-apply <classifier_file>`
5177    
5178    This command applies a classifier trained previously by **-rf-train**. The
5179    stack must contain the same number of feature images as when training. The
5180    images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K
5181    probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See
5182    examples under **-rf-train** for usage."""
5183    
5184    def run(
5185        self,
5186        execution: Execution,
5187    ) -> list[str]:
5188        """
5189        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5190        
5191        Args:
5192            self: The sub-command object.
5193            execution: The execution object.
5194        Returns:
5195            
5196        """
5197        cargs = []
5198        cargs.extend(["-rf-apply", self.rf_apply])
5199        return cargs
5200
5201
5202@dataclasses.dataclass
5203class C3dRfTrain:
5204    """
5205    -rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier
5206
5207Syntax: `-rf-train <classifier_file>`
5208
5209This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with label *L* are treated as the examples of class *L*. The classifier is output to a binary file that can later be used by the **-rf-apply** command. Multiple parameters can be specified with the **-rf-param-xxx** options before calling **-rf-train**. The stack is not modified by this command.
5210
5211    # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters
5212    c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf
5213
5214    # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)
5215    c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf
5216
5217    # Applying the classifier
5218    c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz
5219
5220The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:
5221
5222    # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects
5223    c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \
5224        seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \
5225        -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \
5226        -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf
5227
5228    # Apply using single MRI
5229    c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii
5230
5231 [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32.
5232 [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media
5233    """
5234    rf_train: str
5235    """-rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier
5236    
5237    Syntax: `-rf-train <classifier_file>`
5238    
5239    This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et
5240    al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by
5241    [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images
5242    of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The
5243    latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different
5244    classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels
5245    with label *L* are treated as the examples of class *L*. The classifier is
5246    output to a binary file that can later be used by the **-rf-apply** command.
5247    Multiple parameters can be specified with the **-rf-param-xxx** options
5248    before calling **-rf-train**. The stack is not modified by this command.
5249    
5250    # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters
5251    c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf
5252    
5253    # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)
5254    c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf
5255    
5256    # Applying the classifier
5257    c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz
5258    
5259    The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation
5260    mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire
5261    image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers
5262    jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as
5263    long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space
5264    and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:
5265    
5266    # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects
5267    c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \
5268    seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \
5269    -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \
5270    -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf
5271    
5272    # Apply using single MRI
5273    c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii
5274    
5275    [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32.
5276    [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer
5277    vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media"""
5278    
5279    def run(
5280        self,
5281        execution: Execution,
5282    ) -> list[str]:
5283        """
5284        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5285        
5286        Args:
5287            self: The sub-command object.
5288            execution: The execution object.
5289        Returns:
5290            
5291        """
5292        cargs = []
5293        cargs.extend(["-rf-train", self.rf_train])
5294        return cargs
5295
5296
5297@dataclasses.dataclass
5298class C3dRfParamPatch:
5299    """
5300    -rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size
5301
5302Syntax: `-rf-param-patch <size_spec>`
5303
5304Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See **-rf-train** command for details.
5305
5306    # Set patch size to 5x5x5 
5307    c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf
5308    """
5309    rf_param_patch: str
5310    """-rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size
5311    
5312    Syntax: `-rf-param-patch <size_spec>`
5313    
5314    Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier.
5315    By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel
5316    is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in
5317    neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve
5318    classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each
5319    dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See **-rf-train** command for details.
5320    
5321    # Set patch size to 5x5x5
5322    c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf"""
5323    
5324    def run(
5325        self,
5326        execution: Execution,
5327    ) -> list[str]:
5328        """
5329        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5330        
5331        Args:
5332            self: The sub-command object.
5333            execution: The execution object.
5334        Returns:
5335            
5336        """
5337        cargs = []
5338        cargs.extend(["-rf-param-patch", self.rf_param_patch])
5339        return cargs
5340
5341
5342@dataclasses.dataclass
5343class C3dRfParamUsexyz:
5344    """
5345    -rf-param-usexyz: Random Forest coordinate features
5346
5347Syntax: `-rf-param-usexyz`
5348
5349Use the coordinates of voxels as additional features. This allows some geometric relations between different labels to be learned. Equivalent to the corresponding ITK-SNAP option.
5350    """
5351    rf_param_usexyz: str
5352    """-rf-param-usexyz: Random Forest coordinate features
5353    
5354    Syntax: `-rf-param-usexyz`
5355    
5356    Use the coordinates of voxels as additional features. This allows some
5357    geometric relations between different labels to be learned. Equivalent to
5358    the corresponding ITK-SNAP option."""
5359    
5360    def run(
5361        self,
5362        execution: Execution,
5363    ) -> list[str]:
5364        """
5365        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5366        
5367        Args:
5368            self: The sub-command object.
5369            execution: The execution object.
5370        Returns:
5371            
5372        """
5373        cargs = []
5374        cargs.extend(["-rf-param-usexyz", self.rf_param_usexyz])
5375        return cargs
5376

5404@dataclasses.dataclass
5405class C3dRfParamNtrees:
5406    """
5407    -rf-param-ntrees: Random Forest forest size
5408
5409Syntax: `-rf-param-ntrees <integer>`
5410
5411Sets the number of trees in the forest. Default value is 50. Larger forests are more robust but more time to train and apply.
5412    """
5413    rf_param_ntrees: str
5414    """-rf-param-ntrees: Random Forest forest size
5415    
5416    Syntax: `-rf-param-ntrees <integer>`
5417    
5418    Sets the number of trees in the forest. Default value is 50. Larger forests
5419    are more robust but more time to train and apply."""
5420    
5421    def run(
5422        self,
5423        execution: Execution,
5424    ) -> list[str]:

5427

5430            execution: The execution object.
5431        Returns:
5432            
5433        """
5434        cargs = []
5435        cargs.extend(["-rf-param-ntrees", self.rf_param_ntrees])
5436        return cargs

5509@dataclasses.dataclass
5510class C3dReplace:
5511    """
5512    -replace: Replace intensities in image
5513
5514Syntax: `-replace I1 J1 I2 J2 ... `
5515
5516Replace intensity I1 by J1, I2 by J2 and so on. Allowed values of intensity include **nan**, **inf** and **-inf**. 
5517
5518    c3d img1.img -replace 1 128 nan 0.0 -o img2.img
5519    """
5520    replace: str
5521    """-replace: Replace intensities in image
5522    
5523    Syntax: `-replace I1 J1 I2 J2 ... `
5524    
5525    Replace intensity I1 by J1, I2 by J2 and so on. Allowed values of intensity
5526    include **nan**, **inf** and **-inf**.
5527    
5528    c3d img1.img -replace 1 128 nan 0.0 -o img2.img"""
5529    
5530    def run(
5531        self,
5532        execution: Execution,
5533    ) -> list[str]:
5534        """
5535        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

5547
5548@dataclasses.dataclass
5549class C3dResample:
5550    """
5551    -resample: Resample image to new dimensions
5552
5553Syntax: `-resample <dimensions> `
5554
5555Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but changing the number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be specified as a percentage, for example to double the number of voxels in each direction. The **-interpolation** flag affects how sampling is performed. 
5556
5557    c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img 
5558    c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img 
5559    c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img 
5560    c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img
5561    """
5562    resample: str
5563    """-resample: Resample image to new dimensions
5564    
5565    Syntax: `-resample <dimensions> `
5566    
5567    Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but changing the
5568    number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be specified as a
5569    percentage, for example to double the number of voxels in each direction.
5570    The **-interpolation** flag affects how sampling is performed.
5571    
5572    c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img
5573    c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img
5574    c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img
5575    c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o
5576    img2.img"""
5577    
5578    def run(
5579        self,
5580        execution: Execution,
5581    ) -> list[str]:
5582        """
5583        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5584        
5585        Args:
5586            self: The sub-command object.
5587            execution: The execution object.
5588        Returns:
5589            
5590        """
5591        cargs = []
5592        cargs.extend(["-resample", self.resample])
5593        return cargs
5594
5595
5596@dataclasses.dataclass
5597class C3dResampleIso:
5598    """
5599    -resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution
5600
5601Syntax: `-resample-iso <min|max>`
5602
5603Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls **-resample** with appropriately calculated new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic. 
5604
5605    c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img
5606    """
5607    resample_iso: str
5608    """-resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution
5609    
5610    Syntax: `-resample-iso <min|max>`
5611    
5612    Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based
5613    on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension
5614    ('max' mode). This command calls **-resample** with appropriately calculated
5615    new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is
5616    preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual
5617    voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic.
5618    
5619    c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img"""
5620    
5621    def run(
5622        self,
5623        execution: Execution,
5624    ) -> list[str]:
5625        """
5626        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5627        
5628        Args:
5629            self: The sub-command object.
5630            execution: The execution object.
5631        Returns:
5632            
5633        """
5634        cargs = []
5635        cargs.extend(["-resample-iso", self.resample_iso])
5636        return cargs
5637
5638
5639@dataclasses.dataclass
5640class C3dResampleMm:
5641    """
5642    -resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution
5643
5644Syntax: `-resample-mm <voxel_size> `
5645
5646Resamples the image as in **-resample**, but the user specifies the new voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so the bounding box of the image may change. A warning will be generated in that case. 
5647
5648    c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img
5649    """
5650    resample_mm: str
5651    """-resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution
5652    
5653    Syntax: `-resample-mm <voxel_size> `
5654    
5655    Resamples the image as in **-resample**, but the user specifies the new
5656    voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so the bounding
5657    box of the image may change. A warning will be generated in that case.
5658    
5659    c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img"""
5660    
5661    def run(
5662        self,
5663        execution: Execution,
5664    ) -> list[str]:
5665        """
5666        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5667        
5668        Args:
5669            self: The sub-command object.
5670            execution: The execution object.
5671        Returns:
5672            
5673        """
5674        cargs = []
5675        cargs.extend(["-resample-mm", self.resample_mm])
5676        return cargs

5740@dataclasses.dataclass
5741class C3dResliceIdentity:
5742    """
5743    -reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform 
5744
5745Syntax: `-reslice-identity `
5746
5747Applies the **-reslice-matrix** command with the identity transform. This is useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1 
5748
5749    c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii
5750    """
5751    reslice_identity: str
5752    """-reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform
5753    
5754    Syntax: `-reslice-identity `
5755    
5756    Applies the **-reslice-matrix** command with the identity transform. This is
5757    useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate
5758    transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the
5759    space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in
5760    different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space
5761    of the T1
5762    
5763    c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii"""
5764    
5765    def run(
5766        self,
5767        execution: Execution,
5768    ) -> list[str]:
5769        """
5770        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5771        
5772        Args:
5773            self: The sub-command object.
5774            execution: The execution object.
5775        Returns:
5776            
5777        """
5778        cargs = []
5779        cargs.extend(["-reslice-identity", self.reslice_identity])
5780        return cargs

5783@dataclasses.dataclass
5784class C3dRgb2hsv:
5785    """
5786    -rgb2hsv: Convert RGB image to HSV image
5787
5788Syntax `-rgb2hsv`
5789
5790Takes the last three images on the stack and treats them as red, green, and blue channels. Outputs three images corresponding to hue, saturation, value. To read color images you need the ***-msc*** command.
5791
5792    c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png
5793    """
5794    rgb2hsv: str
5795    """-rgb2hsv: Convert RGB image to HSV image
5796    
5797    Syntax `-rgb2hsv`
5798    
5799    Takes the last three images on the stack and treats them as red, green, and
5800    blue channels. Outputs three images corresponding to hue, saturation, value.
5801    To read color images you need the ***-msc*** command.
5802    
5803    c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png"""
5804    
5805    def run(
5806        self,
5807        execution: Execution,
5808    ) -> list[str]:
5809        """
5810        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5811        
5812        Args:
5813            self: The sub-command object.
5814            execution: The execution object.
5815        Returns:
5816            
5817        """
5818        cargs = []
5819        cargs.extend(["-rgb2hsv", self.rgb2hsv])
5820        return cargs

5822
5823@dataclasses.dataclass
5824class C3dRms:
5825    """
5826    -rms: Voxelwise vector norm
5827
5828Syntax: `-rms`
5829
5830Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same size. 
5831
5832    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img
5833
5834The equivalent of this command is
5835
5836    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor \
5837        -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img
5838    """
5839    rms: str
5840    """-rms: Voxelwise vector norm
5841    
5842    Syntax: `-rms`
5843    
5844    Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command
5845    takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and
5846    takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical
5847    operations. Images must have the same size.
5848    
5849    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img
5850    
5851    The equivalent of this command is
5852    
5853    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor \
5854    -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img"""
5855    
5856    def run(
5857        self,
5858        execution: Execution,
5859    ) -> list[str]:
5860        """
5861        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5862        
5863        Args:
5864            self: The sub-command object.
5865            execution: The execution object.
5866        Returns:
5867            
5868        """
5869        cargs = []
5870        cargs.extend(["-rms", self.rms])
5871        return cargs
5872
5873
5874@dataclasses.dataclass
5875class C3dRound:
5876    """
5877    -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior
5878
5879Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `
5880
5881By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. 
5882
5883    c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img
5884    """
5885    round_: str
5886    """-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior
5887    
5888    Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `
5889    
5890    By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when converting
5891    to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding
5892    should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from
5893    the internal floating point representation.
5894    
5895    c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img"""
5896    
5897    def run(
5898        self,
5899        execution: Execution,
5900    ) -> list[str]:
5901        """
5902        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5903        
5904        Args:
5905            self: The sub-command object.
5906            execution: The execution object.
5907        Returns:
5908            
5909        """
5910        cargs = []
5911        cargs.extend(["-round", self.round_])
5912        return cargs
5913

5932    given factor.

6021        return cargs
6022
6023
6024@dataclasses.dataclass
6025class C3dSlice:
6026    """
6027    -slice: Extract slices from an image
6028
6029Syntax: `-slice axis position_spec`
6030
6031Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier **position_spec** can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image. 
6032
6033    c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz
6034    c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz
6035    c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png
6036    c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz 
6037    c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz 
6038
6039With the new command **c4d**, the **-slice** command can be used to extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command 
6040
6041    c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz
6042    """
6043    slice_: str
6044    """-slice: Extract slices from an image
6045    
6046    Syntax: `-slice axis position_spec`
6047    
6048    Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier
6049    **position_spec** can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single
6050    slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is
6051    zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N
6052    is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last.
6053    The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last
6054    dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image.
6055    
6056    c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz
6057    c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz
6058    c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png
6059    c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz
6060    c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz
6061    
6062    With the new command **c4d**, the **-slice** command can be used to extract
6063    volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as
6064    a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command
6065    
6066    c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz"""
6067    
6068    def run(
6069        self,
6070        execution: Execution,
6071    ) -> list[str]:
6072        """
6073        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6074        
6075        Args:
6076            self: The sub-command object.
6077            execution: The execution object.
6078        Returns:
6079            
6080        """
6081        cargs = []
6082        cargs.extend(["-slice", self.slice_])
6083        return cargs
6084
6085
6086@dataclasses.dataclass
6087class C3dSliceAll:
6088    """
6089    -slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack
6090
6091Syntax `-slice-all axis position_spec`
6092
6093This command behaves identical to the **-slice** command, but all images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows:
6094
6095    c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz
6096    """
6097    slice_all: str
6098    """-slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack
6099    
6100    Syntax `-slice-all axis position_spec`
6101    
6102    This command behaves identical to the **-slice** command, but all images on
6103    the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for
6104    slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component
6105    image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows:
6106    
6107    c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz"""
6108    
6109    def run(
6110        self,
6111        execution: Execution,
6112    ) -> list[str]:
6113        """
6114        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6115        
6116        Args:
6117            self: The sub-command object.
6118            execution: The execution object.
6119        Returns:
6120            
6121        """
6122        cargs = []
6123        cargs.extend(["-slice-all", self.slice_all])
6124        return cargs
6125

6204@dataclasses.dataclass
6205class C3dSignedDistanceTransform:
6206    """
6207    -sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary image
6208
6209Syntax: `-sdt`
6210
6211Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary image. 
6212
6213    c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img
6214    """
6215    signed_distance_transform: str
6216    """-sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary
6217    image
6218    
6219    Syntax: `-sdt`
6220    
6221    Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the
6222    binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the
6223    binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value
6224    will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object
6225    represented by the binary image.
6226    
6227    c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img"""
6228    
6229    def run(
6230        self,
6231        execution: Execution,
6232    ) -> list[str]:
6233        """
6234        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6235        
6236        Args:

6238            execution: The execution object.
6239        Returns:
6240            
6241        """
6242        cargs = []
6243        cargs.extend(["-signed-distance-transform", self.signed_distance_transform])
6244        return cargs

6332

6336
6337    c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img
6338    """
6339    spacing: str

6345    positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the image to 1mm
6346    isotropic, use the command below. This command only changes the header of
6347    the image, not its contents.
6348    
6349    c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img"""

6368
6369@dataclasses.dataclass
6370class C3dSplit:
6371    """
6372    -split: Split multi-label image into binary images
6373
6374Syntax: `-split`
6375
6376This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the **-merge** command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by **convert3d** so that when **-merge** is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The **-merge** command treats each input as a probability image, and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using **-merge** 
6377
6378    c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o ml_smooth.nii
6379
6380Also of note is that the **-split** command will disregard infinite intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with *inf*, for example, using the **-thresh** command.
6381    """
6382    split: str
6383    """-split: Split multi-label image into binary images
6384    
6385    Syntax: `-split`
6386    
6387    This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete
6388    intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each
6389    of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the **-merge**
6390    command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by
6391    **convert3d** so that when **-merge** is called, the labels are faithfully
6392    reassigned. The **-merge** command treats each input as a probability image,
6393    and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The
6394    example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using
6395    **-merge**
6396    
6397    c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o
6398    ml_smooth.nii
6399    
6400    Also of note is that the **-split** command will disregard infinite
6401    intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels,
6402    you can replace labels you do not care about with *inf*, for example, using
6403    the **-thresh** command."""
6404    
6405    def run(
6406        self,
6407        execution: Execution,
6408    ) -> list[str]:
6409        """
6410        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6411        
6412        Args:
6413            self: The sub-command object.
6414            execution: The execution object.
6415        Returns:
6416            
6417        """
6418        cargs = []
6419        cargs.extend(["-split", self.split])
6420        return cargs
6421
6422

6432    c3d input.img -sqrt -o output.img

6437    Syntax: `-sqrt `

6441    c3d input.img -sqrt -o output.img"""
6442    
6443    def run(
6444        self,

6446    ) -> list[str]:

6449        
6450        Args:

6457        cargs.extend(["-sqrt", self.sqrt])
6458        return cargs
6459
6460
6461@dataclasses.dataclass
6462class C3dStaple:
6463    """
6464    -staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations
6465
6466Syntax: `-staple <intensity_value> `
6467
6468Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a different rater. The parameter *intensity_value* specifies the label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the *intensity_value*). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the **-verbose** command is used before the **-staple** command. 
6469
6470    c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img
6471    c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img
6472    """
6473    staple: str
6474    """-staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations
6475    
6476    Syntax: `-staple <intensity_value> `
6477    
6478    Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]).
6479    STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given
6480    a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images
6481    on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a
6482    different rater. The parameter *intensity_value* specifies the label in the
6483    segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the
6484    segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2
6485    corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in
6486    2 as the *intensity_value*). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image
6487    with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel
6488    being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a
6489    binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the
6490    sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the
6491    **-verbose** command is used before the **-staple** command.
6492    
6493    c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img
6494    c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img"""
6495    
6496    def run(
6497        self,
6498        execution: Execution,
6499    ) -> list[str]:
6500        """
6501        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6502        
6503        Args:
6504            self: The sub-command object.
6505            execution: The execution object.
6506        Returns:
6507            
6508        """
6509        cargs = []
6510        cargs.extend(["-staple", self.staple])
6511        return cargs
6512
6513
6514@dataclasses.dataclass
6515class C3dStructureTensorEigenvalues:
6516    """
6517    -steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor
6518
6519Syntax `-steig <scale> <radius>`
6520
6521Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.
6522
6523    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
6524    """
6525    structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str
6526    """-steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the
6527    structure tensor
6528    
6529    Syntax `-steig <scale> <radius>`
6530    
6531    Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues
6532    of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on
6533    the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the
6534    '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing
6535    applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in
6536    physical (mm) units.
6537    
6538    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz"""
6539    
6540    def run(
6541        self,
6542        execution: Execution,
6543    ) -> list[str]:
6544        """
6545        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6546        
6547        Args:
6548            self: The sub-command object.
6549            execution: The execution object.
6550        Returns:
6551            
6552        """
6553        cargs = []
6554        cargs.extend(["-steig", self.structure_tensor_eigenvalues])
6555        return cargs
6556
6557
6558@dataclasses.dataclass
6559class C3dSpm:
6560    """
6561    -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output
6562
6563Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `
6564
6565These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.
6566
6567    c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz
6568    """
6569    spm: str
6570    """-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output
6571    
6572    Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `
6573    
6574    These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze
6575    (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM
6576    in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze
6577    files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the
6578    **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and
6579    SPM5 or later.
6580    
6581    c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz"""
6582    
6583    def run(
6584        self,
6585        execution: Execution,
6586    ) -> list[str]:
6587        """
6588        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6589        
6590        Args:
6591            self: The sub-command object.
6592            execution: The execution object.
6593        Returns:
6594            
6595        """
6596        cargs = []
6597        cargs.extend(["-spm", self.spm])
6598        return cargs
6599

6653@dataclasses.dataclass
6654class C3dStretch:
6655    """
6656    -stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly
6657
6658Syntax: `-stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> `
6659
6660Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use 
6661
6662    c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img
6663    """
6664    stretch: str
6665    """-stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly
6666    
6667    Syntax: `-stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> `
6668    
6669    Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and
6670    u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in
6671    the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating
6672    point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an
6673    unsigned short image, use
6674    
6675    c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img"""
6676    
6677    def run(
6678        self,
6679        execution: Execution,
6680    ) -> list[str]:
6681        """
6682        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6683        
6684        Args:
6685            self: The sub-command object.
6686            execution: The execution object.
6687        Returns:
6688            
6689        """
6690        cargs = []
6691        cargs.extend(["-stretch", self.stretch])
6692        return cargs
6693
6694
6695@dataclasses.dataclass
6696class C3dSwapdim:
6697    """
6698    -swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image
6699
6700Syntax `-swapdim <code>`
6701
6702This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command.
6703
6704    c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii
6705
6706
6707### Commands: Image Processing
6708
6709The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options, which are listed separately.
6710    """
6711    swapdim: str
6712    """-swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image
6713    
6714    Syntax `-swapdim <code>`
6715    
6716    This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a
6717    desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image
6718    remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels
6719    in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The
6720    transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the
6721    '''-orient''' command.
6722    
6723    c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii
6724    
6725    
6726    ### Commands: Image Processing
6727    
6728    The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary
6729    commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands
6730    apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options,
6731    which are listed separately."""
6732    
6733    def run(
6734        self,
6735        execution: Execution,
6736    ) -> list[str]:
6737        """
6738        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6739        
6740        Args:
6741            self: The sub-command object.
6742            execution: The execution object.
6743        Returns:
6744            
6745        """
6746        cargs = []
6747        cargs.extend(["-swapdim", self.swapdim])
6748        return cargs
6749
6750
6751@dataclasses.dataclass
6752class C3dTestImage:
6753    """
6754    -test-image, -test-probe: Test condition
6755
6756Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value> [tolerance]`
6757
6758These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell). The commands check a certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the test failed. 
6759
6760**-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8. 
6761
6762    c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image
6763
6764**-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by **vector** is equal to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the default is 1e-8. 
6765
6766    c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6
6767    """
6768    test_image: str
6769    """-test-image, -test-probe: Test condition
6770    
6771    Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value>
6772    [tolerance]`
6773    
6774    These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily
6775    meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also be used for flow
6776    control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell). The commands check a
6777    certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause the program to exit with
6778    either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the
6779    test failed.
6780    
6781    **-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are identical
6782    (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical.
6783    The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8.
6784    
6785    c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image
6786    
6787    **-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if the value
6788    of the last image on the stack at the position given by **vector** is equal
6789    to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the
6790    default is 1e-8.
6791    
6792    c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6"""
6793    
6794    def run(
6795        self,
6796        execution: Execution,
6797    ) -> list[str]:
6798        """
6799        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6800        
6801        Args:
6802            self: The sub-command object.
6803            execution: The execution object.
6804        Returns:
6805            
6806        """
6807        cargs = []
6808        cargs.extend(["-test-image", self.test_image])
6809        return cargs
6810

6820

6872
6873@dataclasses.dataclass
6874class C3dThreshold:
6875    """
6876    -thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding
6877
6878Syntax: `-thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> `
6879
6880Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values *u1* and *u2* are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values **inf** and **-inf** for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also specify *u1* and *u2* as percentiles. 
6881    c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img
6882    c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img
6883    c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img
6884    """
6885    threshold: str
6886    """-thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding
6887    
6888    Syntax: `-thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> `
6889    
6890    Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2]
6891    to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values *u1* and *u2* are intensity
6892    specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values **inf**
6893    and **-inf** for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also
6894    specify *u1* and *u2* as percentiles.
6895    c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img
6896    c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img
6897    c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img"""
6898    
6899    def run(
6900        self,
6901        execution: Execution,
6902    ) -> list[str]:
6903        """
6904        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6905        
6906        Args:
6907            self: The sub-command object.
6908            execution: The execution object.
6909        Returns:
6910            
6911        """
6912        cargs = []
6913        cargs.extend(["-threshold", self.threshold])
6914        return cargs
6915
6916
6917@dataclasses.dataclass
6918class C3dTile:
6919    """
6920    -tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one
6921
6922Syntax: `-tile <tile_spec>`
6923
6924Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single tiled image. The **tile_spec** parameter can either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g., **4x4**) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of slices, we use 
6925
6926    c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz
6927
6928And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we would use the **c2d** command as follows: 
6929
6930    c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png
6931    """
6932    tile: str
6933    """-tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one
6934    
6935    Syntax: `-tile <tile_spec>`
6936    
6937    Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into
6938    a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single
6939    tiled image. The **tile_spec** parameter can either specify a coordinate
6940    axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g.,
6941    **4x4**) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the
6942    last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of
6943    images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of
6944    slices, we use
6945    
6946    c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz
6947    
6948    And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we
6949    would use the **c2d** command as follows:
6950    
6951    c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png"""
6952    
6953    def run(
6954        self,
6955        execution: Execution,
6956    ) -> list[str]:
6957        """
6958        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6959        
6960        Args:
6961            self: The sub-command object.
6962            execution: The execution object.
6963        Returns:
6964            
6965        """
6966        cargs = []
6967        cargs.extend(["-tile", self.tile])
6968        return cargs
6969
6970
6971@dataclasses.dataclass
6972class C3dTrim:
6973    """
6974    -trim: Trim background region of image
6975
6976Syntax: `-trim <margin_vector>`
6977
6978Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides
6979
6980    c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img
6981    """
6982    trim: str
6983    """-trim: Trim background region of image
6984    
6985    Syntax: `-trim <margin_vector>`
6986    
6987    Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is
6988    filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region
6989    that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then
6990    expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the
6991    resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an
6992    image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides
6993    
6994    c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img"""
6995    
6996    def run(
6997        self,
6998        execution: Execution,
6999    ) -> list[str]:
7000        """
7001        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7002        
7003        Args:
7004            self: The sub-command object.
7005            execution: The execution object.
7006        Returns:
7007            
7008        """
7009        cargs = []
7010        cargs.extend(["-trim", self.trim])
7011        return cargs
7012
7013
7014@dataclasses.dataclass
7015class C3dTrimToSize:
7016    """
7017    -trim-to-size: Trim image to given size
7018
7019Syntax: `-trim-to-size <size_vector>`
7020
7021Like **-trim**, this command trims the background in an image. However, instead of **-trim**, you specify the target size of the output region. The actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call 
7022
7023    c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img
7024    """
7025    trim_to_size: str
7026    """-trim-to-size: Trim image to given size
7027    
7028    Syntax: `-trim-to-size <size_vector>`
7029    
7030    Like **-trim**, this command trims the background in an image. However,
7031    instead of **-trim**, you specify the target size of the output region. The
7032    actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the
7033    boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image
7034    containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call
7035    
7036    c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img"""
7037    
7038    def run(
7039        self,
7040        execution: Execution,
7041    ) -> list[str]:
7042        """
7043        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7044        
7045        Args:
7046            self: The sub-command object.
7047            execution: The execution object.
7048        Returns:
7049            
7050        """
7051        cargs = []
7052        cargs.extend(["-trim-to-size", self.trim_to_size])
7053        return cargs

7056@dataclasses.dataclass
7057class C3dType:
7058    """
7059    -type: Specify pixel type for image output
7060
7061Syntax: `-type < char | uchar | short | ushort | int | uint | float | double > `
7062
7063Specifies the pixel type for the output image. By default, images are written in floating point (**float**) format. The type does not affect how images are processed, only how they are saved. 
7064
7065    c3d image1.img -type short image2.img
7066
7067Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG images, uchar or ushort type must be specified.
7068    """
7069    type_: str
7070    """-type: Specify pixel type for image output
7071    
7072    Syntax: `-type < char | uchar | short | ushort | int | uint | float | double
7073    > `
7074    
7075    Specifies the pixel type for the output image. By default, images are
7076    written in floating point (**float**) format. The type does not affect how
7077    images are processed, only how they are saved.
7078    
7079    c3d image1.img -type short image2.img
7080    
7081    Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG images,
7082    uchar or ushort type must be specified."""
7083    
7084    def run(
7085        self,
7086        execution: Execution,
7087    ) -> list[str]:
7088        """
7089        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7090        
7091        Args:
7092            self: The sub-command object.
7093            execution: The execution object.
7094        Returns:
7095            
7096        """
7097        cargs = []
7098        cargs.extend(["-type", self.type_])
7099        return cargs

7192
7193@dataclasses.dataclass
7194class C3dVote:
7195    """
7196    -vote: Vote among images on the stack
7197
7198Syntax: `-vote `
7199
7200This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel *(i,j,k)* returns the index of the image for which the image value at *(i,j,k)* is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the **-vote** command will return the most probable label at each voxel. 
7201
7202    c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img
7203
7204The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands **-split** and **-merge**.
7205    """
7206    vote: str
7207    """-vote: Vote among images on the stack
7208    
7209    Syntax: `-vote `
7210    
7211    This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel
7212    *(i,j,k)* returns the index of the image for which the image value at
7213    *(i,j,k)* is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability
7214    maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give
7215    the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the **-vote**
7216    command will return the most probable label at each voxel.
7217    
7218    c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img
7219    
7220    The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of
7221    the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the
7222    output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for
7223    prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands **-split** and
7224    **-merge**."""
7225    
7226    def run(
7227        self,
7228        execution: Execution,
7229    ) -> list[str]:
7230        """
7231        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7232        
7233        Args:
7234            self: The sub-command object.
7235            execution: The execution object.
7236        Returns:
7237            
7238        """
7239        cargs = []
7240        cargs.extend(["-vote", self.vote])
7241        return cargs
7242
7243
7244@dataclasses.dataclass
7245class C3dVoteMrf:
7246    """
7247    -vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization
7248
7249Syntax: `-vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>`
7250
7251This command is similar to **-vote** but it performs regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more contiguous segments. 
7252
7253The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel **x** in image **k** holds the probability that voxel **x** has label **k**. Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label 0 in the output.
7254
7255The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel **x** the label **k**. The parameter **mode** describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost. 
7256
7257* `VOTES_AGAINST` or `VA`. This mode is useful when the command is being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that assign label *k* to voxel *x*. The data term equals to the error associated to assining the voxel *k* label *x*. This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all labels at *x* minus the likelihood for *k* at *x*. Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted as missing data for some voxels. 
7258
7259* `LOG_LIKELIHOOD` or `LL`. The cost for label *k* at voxel *x* is the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at *x*. This will assign infinite cost when the likelihood is zero. 
7260
7261The regularlization term is encoded as **lambda** times the total number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that have different labels. 
7262
7263The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers. 
7264
72651. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, *Efficient Approximate Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001. 
7266
72672. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, *What Energy Functions can be Minimized via Graph Cuts?*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004.
7268
72693. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, *An Experimental Comparison of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004. 
7270
7271As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication.  If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, *System and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts*, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.
7272
7273The example below illustrates applying **-vote-mrf** with a user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label.
7274
7275    c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \
7276        -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \
7277        -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii
7278    """
7279    vote_mrf: str
7280    """-vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization
7281    
7282    Syntax: `-vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>`
7283    
7284    This command is similar to **-vote** but it performs regularlization using
7285    the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the
7286    total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more
7287    contiguous segments.
7288    
7289    The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are
7290    likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel
7291    **x** in image **k** holds the probability that voxel **x** has label **k**.
7292    Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range
7293    are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels
7294    will be assigned label 0 in the output.
7295    
7296    The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a
7297    data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost
7298    (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel **x** the label **k**. The
7299    parameter **mode** describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost.
7300    
7301    * `VOTES_AGAINST` or `VA`. This mode is useful when the command is being
7302    used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each
7303    likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that
7304    assign label *k* to voxel *x*. The data term equals to the error associated
7305    to assining the voxel *k* label *x*. This error is calculated as the sum of
7306    the likelihoods for all labels at *x* minus the likelihood for *k* at *x*.
7307    Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be
7308    interpreted as missing data for some voxels.
7309    
7310    * `LOG_LIKELIHOOD` or `LL`. The cost for label *k* at voxel *x* is the
7311    logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at *x*. This will assign infinite
7312    cost when the likelihood is zero.
7313    
7314    The regularlization term is encoded as **lambda** times the total number of
7315    neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that
7316    have different labels.
7317    
7318    The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut
7319    algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers.
7320    
7321    1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, *Efficient Approximate Energy
7322    Minimization via Graph Cuts*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p.
7323    1222-1239, 2001.
7324    
7325    2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, *What Energy Functions can be
7326    Minimized via Graph Cuts?*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p.
7327    147-159, 2004.
7328    
7329    3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, *An Experimental Comparison of
7330    Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision*, IEEE
7331    transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004.
7332    
7333    As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms
7334    distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used
7335    only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any
7336    resulting publication. If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms
7337    described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should
7338    be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, *System
7339    and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts*, United
7340    Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.
7341    
7342    The example below illustrates applying **-vote-mrf** with a user-specified
7343    mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number)
7344    and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label.
7345    
7346    c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \
7347    -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \
7348    -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii"""
7349    
7350    def run(
7351        self,
7352        execution: Execution,
7353    ) -> list[str]:
7354        """
7355        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7356        
7357        Args:
7358            self: The sub-command object.
7359            execution: The execution object.
7360        Returns:
7361            
7362        """
7363        cargs = []
7364        cargs.extend(["-vote-mrf", self.vote_mrf])
7365        return cargs
7366
7367

7434@dataclasses.dataclass
7435class C3dVoxelIntegral:
7436    """
7437    -voxel-integral: Print volume integral of all voxel intensities
7438
7439Syntax: `-voxel-integral`
7440
7441Like **-voxel-sum**, but multiplies the sum of voxel intensities by voxel volume. This is useful for computing volumes of objects represented by binary images. The result is in 'ml'. 
7442
7443    $ c3d image.img -voxel-integral 
7444    Voxel Integral: 2341
7445    """
7446    voxel_integral: str
7447    """-voxel-integral: Print volume integral of all voxel intensities
7448    
7449    Syntax: `-voxel-integral`
7450    
7451    Like **-voxel-sum**, but multiplies the sum of voxel intensities by voxel
7452    volume. This is useful for computing volumes of objects represented by
7453    binary images. The result is in 'ml'.
7454    
7455    $ c3d image.img -voxel-integral
7456    Voxel Integral: 2341"""

7460        execution: Execution,

7475
7476@dataclasses.dataclass
7477class C3dVoxelwiseRegression:
7478    """
7479    -voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images
7480
7481Syntax: `-voxreg regression_order `
7482
7483Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b\_0, b\_1, ..., b\_k, such that Y is best approximated by b\_0 + b\_1 * X + b\_2 * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression. 
7484
7485    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2 
7486    REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935
7487    REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024
7488
7489    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2
7490    REGCOEFF[0] = 0
7491    REGCOEFF[1] = 1
7492    """
7493    voxelwise_regression: str
7494    """-voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images
7495    
7496    Syntax: `-voxreg regression_order `
7497    
7498    Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command
7499    takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b\_0,
7500    b\_1, ..., b\_k, such that Y is best approximated by b\_0 + b\_1 * X + b\_2
7501    * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression.
7502    
7503    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2
7504    REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935
7505    REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024
7506    
7507    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2
7508    REGCOEFF[0] = 0
7509    REGCOEFF[1] = 1"""
7510    
7511    def run(
7512        self,
7513        execution: Execution,
7514    ) -> list[str]:
7515        """
7516        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7517        
7518        Args:
7519            self: The sub-command object.
7520            execution: The execution object.
7521        Returns:
7522            
7523        """
7524        cargs = []
7525        cargs.extend(["-voxelwise-regression", self.voxelwise_regression])
7526        return cargs
7527
