7580
7581@dataclasses.dataclass
7582class C3dWrap:
7583    """
7584    -wrap: Wrap (rotate) image 
7585
7586Syntax: `-wrap <vector> `
7587
7588Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer components, possibly negative. For example, 
7589
7590    c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz
7591
7592will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20). 
7593
7594
7595### Commands: Options and Parameters
7596
7597Options change the behavior of commands that *appear later on the command line*. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will have no effect.
7598    """
7599    wrap: str
7600    """-wrap: Wrap (rotate) image
7601    
7602    Syntax: `-wrap <vector> `
7603    
7604    Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used
7605    to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer
7606    components, possibly negative. For example,
7607    
7608    c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz
7609    
7610    will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel
7611    at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20).
7612    
7613    
7614    ### Commands: Options and Parameters
7615    
7616    Options change the behavior of commands that *appear later on the command
7617    line*. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will
7618    have no effect."""
7619    
7620    def run(
7621        self,
7622        execution: Execution,
7623    ) -> list[str]:
7624        """
7625        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7626        
7627        Args:
7628            self: The sub-command object.
7629            execution: The execution object.
7630        Returns:
7631            
7632        """
7633        cargs = []
7634        cargs.extend(["-wrap", self.wrap])
7635        return cargs
7636
7637
7638@dataclasses.dataclass
7639class C3dWeightedSum:
7640    """
7641    -wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights
7642
7643Syntax: `-wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN `
7644
7645Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack. 
7646
7647    c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii
7648
7649This command is particularly useful for combining components in a multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows: 
7650
7651    c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii
7652    """
7653    weighted_sum: str
7654    """-wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights
7655    
7656    Syntax: `-wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN `
7657    
7658    Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack.
7659    
7660    c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii
7661    
7662    This command is particularly useful for combining components in a
7663    multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to
7664    grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows:
7665    
7666    c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii"""
7667    
7668    def run(
7669        self,
7670        execution: Execution,
7671    ) -> list[str]:
7672        """
7673        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7674        
7675        Args:
7676            self: The sub-command object.
7677            execution: The execution object.
7678        Returns:
7679            
7680        """
7681        cargs = []
7682        cargs.extend(["-weighted-sum", self.weighted_sum])
7683        return cargs
7684
7685
7686@dataclasses.dataclass
7687class C3dWeightedSumVoxelwise:
7688    """
7689    -wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially varying weights
7690
7691Syntax: `-wsv `
7692
7693Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used.
7694
7695    c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7696
7697The **-reorder** command can simplify loading the images:
7698
7699    c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7700
7701### Commands: Image Header Manipulation
7702    """
7703    weighted_sum_voxelwise: str
7704    """-wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially
7705    varying weights
7706    
7707    Syntax: `-wsv `
7708    
7709    Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images
7710    must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used.
7711    
7712    c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii
7713    -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7714    
7715    The **-reorder** command can simplify loading the images:
7716    
7717    c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7718    
7719    ### Commands: Image Header Manipulation"""
7720    
7721    def run(
7722        self,
7723        execution: Execution,
7724    ) -> list[str]:
7725        """
7726        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7727        
7728        Args:
7729            self: The sub-command object.
7730            execution: The execution object.
7731        Returns:
7732            
7733        """
7734        cargs = []
7735        cargs.extend(["-weighted-sum-voxelwise", self.weighted_sum_voxelwise])
7736        return cargs
7737
7738
7739class C3dOutputs(typing.NamedTuple):
7740    """
7741    Output object returned when calling `c3d(...)`.
7742    """
7743    root: OutputPathType
7744    """Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs."""
7745
7746
7747def c3d(
7748    input_: InputPathType,
7749    output: InputPathType,
7750    operations: typing.Union[C3dAccum, C3dAcos, C3dAdd, C3dAlignLandmarks, C3dAnisotropicDiffusion, C3dAntialias, C3dSet, C3dAsin, C3dAtan2, C3dBackground, C3dN4BiasCorrection, C3dBinarize, C3dCanny, C3dCeil, C3dCentroid, C3dCentroidMark, C3dConnectedComponents, C3dClear, C3dClip, C3dColorMap, C3dCompress, C3dNoCompress, C3dConv, C3dCoordinateMapVoxel, C3dCoordinateMapPhysical, C3dCopyTransform, C3dCos, C3dCreate, C3dDicomSeriesList, C3dDicomSeriesRead, C3dDilate, C3dDivide, C3dDuplicate, C3dEndaccum, C3dEndfor, C3dErode, C3dErf, C3dExp, C3dExportPatches, C3dExportPatchesAug, C3dExtrudeSeg, C3dFillBackgroundWithNoise, C3dFft, C3dFlip, C3dFloor, C3dForeach, C3dForeachComp, C3dGlm, C3dGradient, C3dHelp, C3dHolefill, C3dHessianEigenvalues, C3dHessianObjectness, C3dHistogramMatch, C3dInfo, C3dInfoFull, C3dInsert, C3dInterpolation, C3dIterations, C3dLabelOverlap, C3dLabelStatistics, C3dLandmarksToSpheres, C3dLaplacian, C3dLevelset, C3dLevelsetCurvature, C3dLevelsetAdvection, C3dLog, C3dLog10, C3dManual, C3dMatchBoundingBox, C3dMaximum, C3dMulticomponentSplit, C3dMean, C3dMedianFilter, C3dMerge, C3dMeanFilter, C3dMutualInfo, C3dMinimum, C3dMixtureModel, C3dMoments, C3dMattesMutualInfo, C3dMeanSquare, C3dMultiply, C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelation, C3dNormalizedCorrelation, C3dNormalizedMutualInfo, C3dNoiseGaussian, C3dNoisePoisson, C3dNoiseSpeckle, C3dNoiseSaltPepper, C3dNoMulticomponentSplit, C3dNormalizeLocalWindow, C3dNormpdf, C3dNoround, C3dNospm, C3dOutput, C3dOutputMulticomponent, C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponent, C3dOrient_, C3dOutputMultiple, C3dOrient_, C3dOrigin, C3dOriginVoxel, C3dOriginVoxelCoord, C3dOverlap, C3dOverlayLabelImage, C3dPad, C3dPadTo, C3dPca, C3dPercentIntensityMode, C3dPixel, C3dPop, C3dPopas, C3dProbe, C3dPush, C3dRank, C3dReciprocal, C3dRegion, C3dReorder, C3dRetainLabels, C3dRfApply, C3dRfTrain, C3dRfParamPatch, C3dRfParamUsexyz, C3dRfParamNousexyz, C3dRfParamNtrees, C3dRfParamTreedepth, C3dSetSform_, C3dReplace, C3dResample, C3dResampleIso, C3dResampleMm, C3dResliceItk, C3dResliceMatrix, C3dResliceIdentity, C3dRgb2hsv, C3dRms, C3dRound, C3dScale, C3dSetSform_, C3dSin, C3dSlice, C3dSliceAll, C3dSharpen, C3dShift, C3dSignedDistanceTransform, C3dSmooth, C3dSmoothFast, C3dSpacing, C3dSplit, C3dSqrt, C3dStaple, C3dStructureTensorEigenvalues, C3dSpm, C3dSubtract, C3dSupervoxel, C3dStretch, C3dSwapdim, C3dTestImage, C3dTestProbe, C3dThreshold, C3dTile, C3dTrim, C3dTrimToSize, C3dType, C3dVerbose, C3dNoverbose, C3dVersion, C3dVote, C3dVoteMrf, C3dVoteLabel, C3dVoxelSum, C3dVoxelIntegral, C3dVoxelwiseRegression, C3dWarp, C3dWarpLabel, C3dWrap, C3dWeightedSum, C3dWeightedSumVoxelwise],
7751    runner: Runner | None = None,
7752) -> C3dOutputs:
7753    """
7754    c3d.
7755    
7756    C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.
7757    
7758    Args:
7759        input_: The input image to process.
7760        output: The output image.
7761        operations: The operations to perform.
7762        runner: Command runner.
7763    Returns:
7764        NamedTuple of outputs (described in `C3dOutputs`).
7765    """
7766    runner = runner or get_global_runner()
7767    execution = runner.start_execution(C3D_METADATA)
7768    cargs = []
7769    cargs.append("c3d")
7770    cargs.extend(["-i", execution.input_file(input_)])
7771    cargs.extend(operations.run(execution))
7772    cargs.extend(["-o", execution.input_file(output)])
7773    ret = C3dOutputs(
7774        root=execution.output_file("."),
7775    )
7776    execution.run(cargs)
7777    return ret
7778
7779

C3D_METADATA = Metadata(id='f1732790635348d98955440a3cbeaf174f186242', name='c3d', package=None, citations=None, container_image_type=None, container_image_tag=None, container_image_index=None, container_image_opts=None)
@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dAccum: 
16@dataclasses.dataclass
17class C3dAccum:
18    """
19    -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
20
21Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
22
23Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. 
24
25    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii
26    """
27    accum: str
28    """-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
29    
30    Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
31    
32    Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the
33    images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied
34    to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of
35    this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is
36    the example of using the command to add multiple images.
37    
38    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii"""
39    
40    def run(
41        self,
42        execution: Execution,
43    ) -> list[str]:
44        """
45        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
46        
47        Args:
48            self: The sub-command object.
49            execution: The execution object.
50        Returns:
51            
52        """
53        cargs = []
54        cargs.extend(["-accum", self.accum])
55        return cargs

-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images

Syntax: -accum command-list -endaccum

Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. 

c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii
C3dAccum(accum: str)
accum: str

-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images

Syntax: -accum command-list -endaccum

Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images.

c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dAdd: 
 84@dataclasses.dataclass
 85class C3dAdd:
 86    """
 87    -add: Voxelwise image addition
 88
 89Syntax: `-add`
 90
 91Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.
 92
 93    # Add two images: x = a + b
 94    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
 95
 96    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second
 97    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
 98    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
 99
100    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
101    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img
102    """
103    add: str
104    """-add: Voxelwise image addition
105    
106    Syntax: `-add`
107    
108    Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the
109    stack.
110    
111    # Add two images: x = a + b
112    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
113    
114    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in
115    the second
116    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
117    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
118    
119    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
120    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img"""
121    
122    def run(
123        self,
124        execution: Execution,
125    ) -> list[str]:
126        """
127        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
128        
129        Args:
130            self: The sub-command object.
131            execution: The execution object.
132        Returns:
133            
134        """
135        cargs = []
136        cargs.extend(["-add", self.add])
137        return cargs

-add: Voxelwise image addition

Syntax: -add

Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.

# Add two images: x = a + b
c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img

# Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second
c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img

# Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img
C3dAdd(add: str)
add: str

-add: Voxelwise image addition

Syntax: -add

Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.

Add two images: x = a + b

c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img

Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in

the second c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img

Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b

c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dAlignLandmarks: 
140@dataclasses.dataclass
141class C3dAlignLandmarks:
142    """
143    -alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching
144
145Syntax: `-alm dof outfile`
146
147Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes, etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom, which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the output matrix file. In this example, we have images **fixed.nii* and **moving.nii** with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align the moving image to the fixed:
148
149    c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat
150    c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii
151    """
152    align_landmarks: str
153    """-alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching
154    
155    Syntax: `-alm dof outfile`
156    
157    Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A
158    landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of
159    all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be
160    created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes,
161    etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and
162    the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom,
163    which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the
164    output matrix file. In this example, we have images **fixed.nii* and
165    **moving.nii** with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align
166    the moving image to the fixed:
167    
168    c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat
169    c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o
170    moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii"""
171    
172    def run(
173        self,
174        execution: Execution,
175    ) -> list[str]:
176        """
177        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
178        
179        Args:
180            self: The sub-command object.
181            execution: The execution object.
182        Returns:
183            
184        """
185        cargs = []
186        cargs.extend(["-align-landmarks", self.align_landmarks])
187        return cargs

-alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching

Syntax: -alm dof outfile

Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes, etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom, which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the output matrix file. In this example, we have images fixed.nii* and **moving.nii with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align the moving image to the fixed:

c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat
c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii
C3dAlignLandmarks(align_landmarks: str)
align_landmarks: str

-alm, -align-landmarks: Align images based on landmark matching

Syntax: -alm dof outfile

Performs rigid or affine alignment between to sets of landmark images. A landmark image is an image where for every intensity value, the centroid of all voxels with that intensity represents a landmark. Landmarks can be created using the paintbrush tool in ITK-SNAP (they can be spheres, cubes, etc). The first image on the stack is the target/fixed/reference image, and the second is the moving image. The parameters are the degrees of freedom, which is a number (6 for rigid, 7 for rigid+scale, 12 for affine) and the output matrix file. In this example, we have images fixed.nii* and **moving.nii with corresponding landmark images. We use landmarks to align the moving image to the fixed:

c3d fixed_landmarks.nii moving_landmarks.nii -alm 6 rigid.mat c3d fixed.nii moving.nii -reslice-matrix rigid.mat -o moving_resliced_to_fixed.nii

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
172    def run(
173        self,
174        execution: Execution,
175    ) -> list[str]:
176        """
177        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
178        
179        Args:
180            self: The sub-command object.
181            execution: The execution object.
182        Returns:
183            
184        """
185        cargs = []
186        cargs.extend(["-align-landmarks", self.align_landmarks])
187        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dAnisotropicDiffusion: 
190@dataclasses.dataclass
191class C3dAnisotropicDiffusion:
192    """
193    -add: Voxelwise image addition
194
195Syntax: `-add`
196
197Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.
198
199    # Add two images: x = a + b
200    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
201
202    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second
203    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
204    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
205
206    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
207    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img
208    """
209    anisotropic_diffusion: str
210    """-add: Voxelwise image addition
211    
212    Syntax: `-add`
213    
214    Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the
215    stack.
216    
217    # Add two images: x = a + b
218    c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img
219    
220    # Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in
221    the second
222    c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
223    c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img
224    
225    # Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
226    c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img"""
227    
228    def run(
229        self,
230        execution: Execution,
231    ) -> list[str]:
232        """
233        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
234        
235        Args:
236            self: The sub-command object.
237            execution: The execution object.
238        Returns:
239            
240        """
241        cargs = []
242        cargs.extend(["-anisotropic-diffusion", self.anisotropic_diffusion])
243        return cargs

-add: Voxelwise image addition

Syntax: -add

Adds the last two images on the stack, and places the sum at the end of the stack.

# Add two images: x = a + b
c3d a.img b.img -add -o x.img

# Add three images, x = (a + b) + c in the first example, x = a + (b + c) in the second
c3d a.img b.img -add c.img -add -o x.img
c3d a.img b.img c.img -add -add -o x.img

# Subtract two images, using -scale command: x = a - b
c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img

c3d a.img b.img -scale -1 -add -o x.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dAtan2: 
342@dataclasses.dataclass
343class C3dAtan2:
344    """
345    -atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine
346
347Syntax: `-atan2`
348
349Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine followed by cosine): 
350
351    c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz
352    """
353    atan2: str
354    """-atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine
355    
356    Syntax: `-atan2`
357    
358    Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This
359    is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine
360    followed by cosine):
361    
362    c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz"""
363    
364    def run(
365        self,
366        execution: Execution,
367    ) -> list[str]:
368        """
369        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
370        
371        Args:
372            self: The sub-command object.
373            execution: The execution object.
374        Returns:
375            
376        """
377        cargs = []
378        cargs.extend(["-atan2", self.atan2])
379        return cargs

-atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine

Syntax: -atan2

Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine followed by cosine): 

c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz
C3dAtan2(atan2: str)
atan2: str

-atan2: Voxelwise angle from sine and cosine

Syntax: -atan2

Computes the angle in radians from images containing sine and cosine. This is a voxel-wise operation. It requires two images on the stack (sine followed by cosine):

c3d sin_theta.nii.gz cos_theta.nii.gz -atan2 -o theta.nii.gz

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dBinarize: 
457@dataclasses.dataclass
458class C3dBinarize:
459    """
460    -binarize: Convert image to binary
461
462Syntax: `-binarize`
463
464Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background is 0 by default and can be changed by the option **-background**) to 0 and all non-background values to 1. The **-binarize** command is shorthand for the **-threshold** command. 
465
466    c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img 
467    c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img
468    c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1              // equivalent to above command
469    """
470    binarize: str
471    """-binarize: Convert image to binary
472    
473    Syntax: `-binarize`
474    
475    Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background
476    is 0 by default and can be changed by the option **-background**) to 0 and
477    all non-background values to 1. The **-binarize** command is shorthand for
478    the **-threshold** command.
479    
480    c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img
481    c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img
482    c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1 // equivalent to above command"""
483    
484    def run(
485        self,
486        execution: Execution,
487    ) -> list[str]:
488        """
489        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
490        
491        Args:
492            self: The sub-command object.
493            execution: The execution object.
494        Returns:
495            
496        """
497        cargs = []
498        cargs.extend(["-binarize", self.binarize])
499        return cargs

-binarize: Convert image to binary

Syntax: -binarize

Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background is 0 by default and can be changed by the option -background) to 0 and all non-background values to 1. The -binarize command is shorthand for the -threshold command. 

c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img 
c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img
c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1              // equivalent to above command
C3dBinarize(binarize: str)
binarize: str

-binarize: Convert image to binary

Syntax: -binarize

Converts an image to binary by mapping all background values (the background is 0 by default and can be changed by the option -background) to 0 and all non-background values to 1. The -binarize command is shorthand for the -threshold command.

c3d test.img -binarize -o binary.img c3d -background 10 -binarize -o binary.img c3d test.img -threshold 10 10 0 1 // equivalent to above command

504    """
505    -canny: Canny edge detector
506

508
509Performs edge detection on the last image on the stack using the Canny filter. The parameters are a vector of standard deviations defining the scale of the edges detected and lower and upper thresholds for edge selection. See documentation on the [ITK Canny Filter][14].

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dCentroid: 
578@dataclasses.dataclass
579class C3dCentroid:
580    """
581    -centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels
582
583Syntax: `-centroid`
584
585Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in the image. 
586
587    c3d binaryimage.img -centroid                         // centroid of all non-0 voxels
588    c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1   // centroid of all voxels in range 1000-7000
589    c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid          // centroid of all voxels with label 5
590    c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor  // centroids of all labels (including 0)
591    """
592    centroid: str
593    """-centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels
594    
595    Syntax: `-centroid`
596    
597    Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in
598    the image.
599    
600    c3d binaryimage.img -centroid // centroid of all non-0 voxels
601    c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1 // centroid of all
602    voxels in range 1000-7000
603    c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid // centroid of all voxels with
604    label 5
605    c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor // centroids of all
606    labels (including 0)"""
607    
608    def run(
609        self,
610        execution: Execution,
611    ) -> list[str]:
612        """
613        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
614        
615        Args:
616            self: The sub-command object.
617            execution: The execution object.
618        Returns:
619            
620        """
621        cargs = []
622        cargs.extend(["-centroid", self.centroid])
623        return cargs

-centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels

Syntax: -centroid

Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in the image. 

c3d binaryimage.img -centroid                         // centroid of all non-0 voxels
c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1   // centroid of all voxels in range 1000-7000
c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid          // centroid of all voxels with label 5
c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor  // centroids of all labels (including 0)
C3dCentroid(centroid: str)
centroid: str

-centroid: Report centroid of foreground voxels

Syntax: -centroid

Reports the centroid, in physical coordinates, of all foreground voxels in the image.

c3d binaryimage.img -centroid // centroid of all non-0 voxels c3d grayimage.img -thresh 1000 7000 1 0 -centroid 1 // centroid of all voxels in range 1000-7000 c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -centroid // centroid of all voxels with label 5 c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -centroid -endfor // centroids of all labels (including 0)

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dCentroidMark: 
626@dataclasses.dataclass
627class C3dCentroidMark:
628    """
629    -centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels
630
631Syntax: `-centroid-mark <label>`
632
633Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike **-centroid**, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks the closest voxel in the image with the intensity **label**. The remaining voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to mark centers of regions with spheres.
634
635    c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3
636    c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o centers.nii
637    """
638    centroid_mark: str
639    """-centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels
640    
641    Syntax: `-centroid-mark <label>`
642    
643    Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike
644    **-centroid**, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks
645    the closest voxel in the image with the intensity **label**. The remaining
646    voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to
647    mark centers of regions with spheres.
648    
649    c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3
650    c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o
651    centers.nii"""
652    
653    def run(
654        self,
655        execution: Execution,
656    ) -> list[str]:
657        """
658        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
659        
660        Args:
661            self: The sub-command object.
662            execution: The execution object.
663        Returns:
664            
665        """
666        cargs = []
667        cargs.extend(["-centroid-mark", self.centroid_mark])
668        return cargs

-centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels

Syntax: -centroid-mark <label>

Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike -centroid, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks the closest voxel in the image with the intensity label. The remaining voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to mark centers of regions with spheres.

c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3
c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o centers.nii
C3dCentroidMark(centroid_mark: str)
centroid_mark: str

-centroid-mark: Mark the centroid of foreground voxels

Syntax: -centroid-mark <label>

Marks the centroid of the foreground voxels in an image. Unlike -centroid, this command does not print the centroid location, but marks the closest voxel in the image with the intensity label. The remaining voxels are assigned 0 intensity. Combined with -dilate, this can be used to mark centers of regions with spheres.

c3d binaryimage.nii -centroid-mark -dilate 1 3x3x3 c3d labelimage.nii -split -foreach -centroid-mark -endfor -merge -o centers.nii

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dClip: 
750@dataclasses.dataclass
751class C3dClip:
752    """
753    -clip: Clip image intensity to range
754
755Syntax: `-clip iMin iMax`
756
757Clips image intensities, so that the values below *iMin* are converted to *iMin* and values greater than *iMax* are converted to *iMax*. This is useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values *iMin* and *iMax* are intensity specifications (see below). 
758
759    c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img          // Clips below and above
760    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img          // Clips above only
761    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img           // Clips at 95th percentile
762    """
763    clip: str
764    """-clip: Clip image intensity to range
765    
766    Syntax: `-clip iMin iMax`
767    
768    Clips image intensities, so that the values below *iMin* are converted to
769    *iMin* and values greater than *iMax* are converted to *iMax*. This is
770    useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values *iMin* and *iMax*
771    are intensity specifications (see below).
772    
773    c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img // Clips below and above
774    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img // Clips above only
775    c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img // Clips at 95th percentile"""
776    
777    def run(
778        self,
779        execution: Execution,
780    ) -> list[str]:
781        """
782        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
783        
784        Args:
785            self: The sub-command object.
786            execution: The execution object.
787        Returns:
788            
789        """
790        cargs = []
791        cargs.extend(["-clip", self.clip])
792        return cargs

-clip: Clip image intensity to range

Syntax: -clip iMin iMax

Clips image intensities, so that the values below iMin are converted to iMin and values greater than iMax are converted to iMax. This is useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values iMin and iMax are intensity specifications (see below). 

c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img          // Clips below and above
c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img          // Clips above only
c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img           // Clips at 95th percentile
C3dClip(clip: str)
clip: str

-clip: Clip image intensity to range

Syntax: -clip iMin iMax

Clips image intensities, so that the values below iMin are converted to iMin and values greater than iMax are converted to iMax. This is useful for eliminating hyperintensities in images. Values iMin and iMax are intensity specifications (see below).

c3d mri.img -clip 1000 8000 -o mriclip01.img // Clips below and above c3d mri.img -clip -inf 8000 -o mriclip02.img // Clips above only c3d mri.img -clip -inf 95% -o mriclip03.img // Clips at 95th percentile

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
777    def run(
778        self,
779        execution: Execution,
780    ) -> list[str]:
781        """
782        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
783        
784        Args:
785            self: The sub-command object.
786            execution: The execution object.
787        Returns:
788            
789        """
790        cargs = []
791        cargs.extend(["-clip", self.clip])
792        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dColorMap: 
795@dataclasses.dataclass
796class C3dColorMap:
797    """
798    -color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map    
799
800Syntax: `-color-map <ColormapName> [min max]`
801
802Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map. The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input image, e.g., using the **jet** color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped to red. The admissible color maps are **hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder**. The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image. 
803
804    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
805
806By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional **min** and **max** parameters can be used to set the range of the color map. 
807
808    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
809    """
810    color_map: str
811    """-color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map
812    
813    Syntax: `-color-map <ColormapName> [min max]`
814    
815    Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map.
816    The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and
817    blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input
818    image, e.g., using the **jet** color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the
819    image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped
820    to red. The admissible color maps are
821    **hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder**.
822    The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The
823    example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image.
824    
825    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc
826    colorslice.png
827    
828    By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional **min**
829    and **max** parameters can be used to set the range of the color map.
830    
831    c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc
832    colorslice.png"""
833    
834    def run(
835        self,
836        execution: Execution,
837    ) -> list[str]:
838        """
839        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
840        
841        Args:
842            self: The sub-command object.
843            execution: The execution object.
844        Returns:
845            
846        """
847        cargs = []
848        cargs.extend(["-colormap", self.color_map])
849        return cargs

-color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map

Syntax: -color-map <ColormapName> [min max]

Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map. The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input image, e.g., using the jet color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped to red. The admissible color maps are hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder. The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image. 

c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png

By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional min and max parameters can be used to set the range of the color map. 

c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
C3dColorMap(color_map: str)
color_map: str

-color-map, -colormap: Convert scalar image to RGB using color map

Syntax: -color-map <ColormapName> [min max]

Converts a scalar image to a color (RGB) image using a specified color map. The output of the command are three images, containing the red, green and blue channels of the RGB image. The mapping uses the range of the input image, e.g., using the jet color map, the lowest intensity pixel in the image will be mapped to blue, and the highest intesnity pixel will be mapped to red. The admissible color maps are hot,cool,spring,summer,autumn,winter,copper,jet,hsv,red,green,blue,grey,overunder. The command can be used with the -omc command to write RGB images. The example below generates a PNG image from a slice in a scalar image.

c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png

By default the full image intensity range is mapped. The optional min and max parameters can be used to set the range of the color map.

c3d scalar.nii.gz -slice z 50% -flip y -color-map jet 0 1 -type uchar -omc colorslice.png

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

848        cargs.extend(["-colormap", self.color_map])

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dCompress: 
852@dataclasses.dataclass
853class C3dCompress:
854    """
855    -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
856
857Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
858
859Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
860
861    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
862    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha
863    """
864    compress: str
865    """-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
866    
867    Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
868    
869    Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file
870    formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the
871    filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage,
872    you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two
873    commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
874    
875    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
876    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha"""
877    
878    def run(
879        self,
880        execution: Execution,
881    ) -> list[str]:
882        """
883        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
884        
885        Args:
886            self: The sub-command object.
887            execution: The execution object.
888        Returns:
889            
890        """
891        cargs = []
892        cargs.extend(["-compress", self.compress])
893        return cargs

-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files

Syntax: -compress or -no-compress

Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the .gz extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify -compress to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:

c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha
C3dCompress(compress: str)
compress: str

-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files

Syntax: -compress or -no-compress

Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the .gz extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify -compress to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:

c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dConnectedComponents: 
671@dataclasses.dataclass
672class C3dConnectedComponents:
673    """
674    -comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components
675
676Syntax: `-comp`
677
678Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component, combine the call to **-comp** with a call to **-threshold**. 
679
680    c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img
681    c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img
682    """
683    connected_components: str
684    """-comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components
685    
686    Syntax: `-comp`
687    
688    Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected
689    component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of
690    the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The
691    background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component,
692    combine the call to **-comp** with a call to **-threshold**.
693    
694    c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img
695    c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img"""
696    
697    def run(
698        self,
699        execution: Execution,
700    ) -> list[str]:
701        """
702        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
703        
704        Args:
705            self: The sub-command object.
706            execution: The execution object.
707        Returns:
708            
709        """
710        cargs = []
711        cargs.extend(["-connected-components", self.connected_components])
712        return cargs

-comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components

Syntax: -comp

Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component, combine the call to -comp with a call to -threshold. 

c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img
c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img
C3dConnectedComponents(connected_components: str)
connected_components: str

-comp, -connected-components: Compute connected components

Syntax: -comp

Computes the connected components of a binary image. Each connected component is assigned an integer index. Indices are ordered by the size of the component, so the component assigned index 1 is the largest. The background is assigned index 0. To select the largest connected component, combine the call to -comp with a call to -threshold.

c3d binary.img -comp -o comp.img c3d binary.img -comp -threshold 1 1 1 0 -o largest_comp.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dConv: 
940@dataclasses.dataclass
941class C3dConv:
942    """
943    -conv: Convolution
944
945Syntax `-conv`
946
947Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see ["FFT Based Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann][Lehmann].
948
949    c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii
950
951
952[Lehmann]: https://hdl.handle.net/10380/3154
953    """
954    conv: str
955    """-conv: Convolution
956    
957    Syntax `-conv`
958    
959    Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The
960    convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image
961    of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see ["FFT Based
962    Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann][Lehmann].
963    
964    c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii
965    
966    
967    [Lehmann]: https://hdl.handle.net/10380/3154"""
968    
969    def run(
970        self,
971        execution: Execution,
972    ) -> list[str]:
973        """
974        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
975        
976        Args:
977            self: The sub-command object.
978            execution: The execution object.
979        Returns:
980            
981        """
982        cargs = []
983        cargs.extend(["-conv", self.conv])
984        return cargs

-conv: Convolution

Syntax -conv

Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see "FFT Based Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann.

c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii
C3dConv(conv: str)
conv: str

-conv: Convolution

Syntax -conv

Performs convolution between the last two images on the stack. The convolution is performed using the Fourier transform. The result is an image of the same dimensions as the first image. For more details, see "FFT Based Convolution" by Gaetan Lehmann.

c3d image.nii kernel.nii -conv -o result.nii

1044class C3dCoordinateMapPhysical:

1053    """-cmp, -coordinate-map-physical: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel
1054    units)

1057    
1058    This command is similar to **-cmv** (**-coordinate-map-voxel**), but the

1060    (RAS) coordinate frame."""

-cmp, -coordinate-map-physical: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)

Syntax: -cmp

This command is similar to -cmv (-coordinate-map-voxel), but the output will contain the physical coordinates of the voxels, in the NIFTI (RAS) coordinate frame.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dCoordinateMapVoxel: 
 987@dataclasses.dataclass
 988class C3dCoordinateMapVoxel:
 989    """
 990    -cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)
 991
 992Syntax: `-cmv`
 993
 994For a *N*-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with *N* images. The *k*-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate of that voxel, in voxel units.
 995
 996    c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz
 997
 998One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)
 999
1000    c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop  -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK \
1001        -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz \
1002        -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 \
1003        -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz
1004    """
1005    coordinate_map_voxel: str
1006    """-cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)
1007    
1008    Syntax: `-cmv`
1009    
1010    For a *N*-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with *N*
1011    images. The *k*-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate
1012    of that voxel, in voxel units.
1013    
1014    c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz
1015    
1016    One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left
1017    hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X
1018    coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)
1019    
1020    c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK \
1021    -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz \
1022    -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 \
1023    -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz"""
1024    
1025    def run(
1026        self,
1027        execution: Execution,
1028    ) -> list[str]:
1029        """
1030        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1031        
1032        Args:
1033            self: The sub-command object.
1034            execution: The execution object.
1035        Returns:
1036            
1037        """
1038        cargs = []
1039        cargs.extend(["-coordinate-map-voxel", self.coordinate_map_voxel])
1040        return cargs

-cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)

Syntax: -cmv

For a N-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with N images. The k-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate of that voxel, in voxel units.

c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz

One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)

c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop  -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK         -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz         -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1         -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz
C3dCoordinateMapVoxel(coordinate_map_voxel: str)
coordinate_map_voxel: str

-cmv, -coordinate-map-voxel: Generate voxel coordinate maps (voxel units)

Syntax: -cmv

For a N-dimensional image, replaces the last image on the stack with N images. The k-th output image at each voxel contains the $k$-th coordinate of that voxel, in voxel units.

c3d image.nii -cmv -oo coordmap%d.nii.gz

One can use this command to split a brain segmentation image into a left hemisphere segmentation and a right hemisphere segmentation (assuming the X coordinate corresponds to the right-left axis)

c3d seg.nii -as SEG -cmv -pop -pop -thresh 50% inf 1 0 -as MASK -push SEG -times -o seg_left.nii.gz -push MASK -replace 1 0 0 1 -push SEG -times -o seg_right.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
1025    def run(
1026        self,
1027        execution: Execution,
1028    ) -> list[str]:
1029        """
1030        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1031        
1032        Args:
1033            self: The sub-command object.
1034            execution: The execution object.
1035        Returns:
1036            
1037        """
1038        cargs = []
1039        cargs.extend(["-coordinate-map-voxel", self.coordinate_map_voxel])
1040        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dCopyTransform: 
1080@dataclasses.dataclass
1081class C3dCopyTransform:
1082    """
1083    -copy-transform: Copy header information 
1084
1085Syntax: `-copy-transform`
1086
1087Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store this information well. In the example below, *out.nii* will have the same header as *first.nii* and the same intensities as *second.nii*.
1088
1089    c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii
1090    """
1091    copy_transform: str
1092    """-copy-transform: Copy header information
1093    
1094    Syntax: `-copy-transform`
1095    
1096    Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform
1097    (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to
1098    the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store
1099    this information well. In the example below, *out.nii* will have the same
1100    header as *first.nii* and the same intensities as *second.nii*.
1101    
1102    c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii"""
1103    
1104    def run(
1105        self,
1106        execution: Execution,
1107    ) -> list[str]:
1108        """
1109        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1110        
1111        Args:
1112            self: The sub-command object.
1113            execution: The execution object.
1114        Returns:
1115            
1116        """
1117        cargs = []
1118        cargs.extend(["-copy-transform", self.copy_transform])
1119        return cargs

-copy-transform: Copy header information

Syntax: -copy-transform

Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store this information well. In the example below, out.nii will have the same header as first.nii and the same intensities as second.nii.

c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii
C3dCopyTransform(copy_transform: str)
copy_transform: str

-copy-transform: Copy header information

Syntax: -copy-transform

Copies the image header, specifically the image to physical space transform (origin, spacing, direction cosines), from the first image (reference) to the second image (target). This is best done with NIFTI images, which store this information well. In the example below, out.nii will have the same header as first.nii and the same intensities as second.nii.

c3d first.nii second.nii -copy-transform -o out.nii

  • execution: The execution object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dCreate: 
1148@dataclasses.dataclass
1149class C3dCreate:
1150    """
1151    -create: Generate blank image
1152
1153Syntax: `-create dimensions voxel_size`
1154
1155Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the **-background** command. The origin of the image can be changed with the **-origin** command. 
1156
1157    c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img
1158    c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o newimage.img
1159    """
1160    create: str
1161    """-create: Generate blank image
1162    
1163    Syntax: `-create dimensions voxel_size`
1164    
1165    Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and
1166    places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current
1167    background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the
1168    **-background** command. The origin of the image can be changed with the
1169    **-origin** command.
1170    
1171    c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img
1172    c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o
1173    newimage.img"""
1174    
1175    def run(
1176        self,
1177        execution: Execution,
1178    ) -> list[str]:
1179        """
1180        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1181        
1182        Args:
1183            self: The sub-command object.
1184            execution: The execution object.
1185        Returns:
1186            
1187        """
1188        cargs = []
1189        cargs.extend(["-create", self.create])
1190        return cargs

-create: Generate blank image

Syntax: -create dimensions voxel_size

Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the -background command. The origin of the image can be changed with the -origin command. 

c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img
c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o newimage.img
C3dCreate(create: str)
create: str

-create: Generate blank image

Syntax: -create dimensions voxel_size

Creates a new blank image with specified dimensions and voxel size, and places it at the end of the stack. The image is set to the current background value, which is 0 by default but can be overwritten with the -background command. The origin of the image can be changed with the -origin command.

c3d -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -o newimage.img c3d -background 128 -create 256x256x160 1x1x1mm -origin 128x128x80mm -o newimage.img

@dataclasses.dataclass

1228@dataclasses.dataclass
1229class C3dDicomSeriesRead:
1230    """
1231    -dicom-series-read: Read a DICOM image series
1232
1233Syntax: `-dicom-series-read <directory> <series_id>`
1234
1235Imports a specific DICOM image series from a directory containing DICOM files. The **directory** parameter may also point to one of the DICOM files in the directory.
1236The **seried_id** is a string identifier for the series that can be obtained by calling **-dicom-series-list**
1237    """
1238    dicom_series_read: str
1239    """-dicom-series-read: Read a DICOM image series
1240    
1241    Syntax: `-dicom-series-read <directory> <series_id>`
1242

1244    files. The **directory** parameter may also point to one of the DICOM files
1245    in the directory.
1246    The **seried_id** is a string identifier for the series that can be obtained
1247    by calling **-dicom-series-list**"""
1248

-dicom-series-read: Read a DICOM image series

Syntax: -dicom-series-read <directory> <series_id>

Imports a specific DICOM image series from a directory containing DICOM files. The directory parameter may also point to one of the DICOM files in the directory. The seried_id is a string identifier for the series that can be obtained by calling -dicom-series-list

C3dDicomSeriesRead(dicom_series_read: str)

1268class C3dDilate:
1269    """
1270    -dilate: Binary dilation
1271
1272Syntax: `-dilate <label> <radius_vector>`
1273
1274Applies the dilation [mathematical morphology][5] operation to a binary image. The first parameter is the intensity value of the object that is to be dilated. The second is the radius of the dilation structuring element in 3D. 
1275
1276    c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img
1277    """
1278    dilate: str
1279    """-dilate: Binary dilation
1280

1285    be dilated. The second is the radius of the dilation structuring element in
1286    3D.
1287    
1288    c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img"""

1305        return cargs

c3d binary.img -dilate 255 3x3x3vox -o newimage.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dDivide: 
1308@dataclasses.dataclass
1309class C3dDivide:
1310    """
1311    -divide: Voxelwise image division    
1312
1313Syntax: `-divide`
1314
1315Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the command 
1316
1317    c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img
1318
1319Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains zeros. You can use **-replace** to get rid of these values
1320
1321    c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img
1322    """
1323    divide: str
1324    """-divide: Voxelwise image division
1325    
1326    Syntax: `-divide`
1327    
1328    Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the
1329    command
1330    
1331    c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img
1332    
1333    Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains
1334    zeros. You can use **-replace** to get rid of these values
1335    
1336    c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img"""
1337    
1338    def run(
1339        self,
1340        execution: Execution,
1341    ) -> list[str]:
1342        """
1343        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1344        
1345        Args:
1346            self: The sub-command object.
1347            execution: The execution object.
1348        Returns:
1349            
1350        """
1351        cargs = []
1352        cargs.extend(["-divide", self.divide])
1353        return cargs

-divide: Voxelwise image division

Syntax: -divide

Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the command 

c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img

Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains zeros. You can use -replace to get rid of these values

c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img
C3dDivide(divide: str)
divide: str

-divide: Voxelwise image division

Syntax: -divide

Divides one image by another. For instance to compute C = A / B, use the command

c3d A.img B.img -divide -o C.img

Divison may generate infinite and not-a-number (NaN) values if B contains zeros. You can use -replace to get rid of these values

c3d A.img B.img -divide -replace inf 1000 -inf -1000 NaN 0 -o C2.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dDuplicate: 
1356@dataclasses.dataclass
1357class C3dDuplicate:
1358    """
1359    -dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack
1360
1361Syntax: `-dup` 
1362
1363Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to **-as var -push var**, but shorter. An example is when you want to pass an image as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g., computing the square of the image intensity: 
1364
1365    c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img
1366
1367### Commands: Voxelwise Calculations
1368    """
1369    duplicate: str
1370    """-dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack
1371    
1372    Syntax: `-dup`
1373    
1374    Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to **-as
1375    var -push var**, but shorter. An example is when you want to pass an image
1376    as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g., computing the square of the
1377    image intensity:
1378    
1379    c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img
1380    
1381    ### Commands: Voxelwise Calculations"""
1382    
1383    def run(
1384        self,
1385        execution: Execution,
1386    ) -> list[str]:
1387        """
1388        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1389        
1390        Args:
1391            self: The sub-command object.
1392            execution: The execution object.
1393        Returns:
1394            
1395        """
1396        cargs = []
1397        cargs.extend(["-dup", self.duplicate])
1398        return cargs

-dup: Duplicate the last image on the stack

Syntax: -dup

Duplicates the image at the end of the stack. This is equivalent to -as var -push var, but shorter. An example is when you want to pass an image as both arguments to a binary operator, e.g., computing the square of the image intensity: 

c3d input.img -dup -times -o square.img

Commands: Voxelwise Calculations

duplicate: str

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dEndaccum: 
1401@dataclasses.dataclass
1402class C3dEndaccum:
1403    """
1404    -accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
1405
1406Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
1407
1408Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. 
1409
1410    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii
1411    """
1412    endaccum: str
1413    """-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images
1414    
1415    Syntax: `-accum command-list -endaccum`
1416    
1417    Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the
1418    images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied
1419    to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of
1420    this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is
1421    the example of using the command to add multiple images.
1422    
1423    c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii"""
1424    
1425    def run(
1426        self,
1427        execution: Execution,
1428    ) -> list[str]:
1429        """
1430        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1431        
1432        Args:
1433            self: The sub-command object.
1434            execution: The execution object.
1435        Returns:
1436            
1437        """
1438        cargs = []
1439        cargs.extend(["-endaccum", self.endaccum])
1440        return cargs

-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images

Syntax: -accum command-list -endaccum

Apply a binary operation (such as addition or multiplication) to all the images on the stack in a cumulative fashion. The command(s) will be applied to the last and second-to-last images on the stack, then to the result of this operation and the third-to-last image on the stack and so on. Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images. 

c3d image*.nii -accum -add -endaccum -o sum.nii
C3dEndaccum(endaccum: str)
endaccum: str

-accum, -endaccum: Accumulate operations over all images

Syntax: -accum command-list -endaccum

Below is the example of using the command to add multiple images.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dEndfor: 
1443@dataclasses.dataclass
1444class C3dEndfor:
1445    """
1446    -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1447
1448Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1449
1450This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, 
1451
1452    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii
1453    """
1454    endfor: str
1455    """-foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1456    
1457    Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1458    
1459    This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be
1460    applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to
1461    automate processing of multiple datasets. For example,
1462    
1463    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii"""
1464    
1465    def run(
1466        self,
1467        execution: Execution,
1468    ) -> list[str]:
1469        """
1470        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1471        
1472        Args:
1473            self: The sub-command object.
1474            execution: The execution object.
1475        Returns:
1476            
1477        """
1478        cargs = []
1479        cargs.extend(["-endfor", self.endfor])
1480        return cargs

-foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack

Syntax: -foreach commands-list -endfor

This command forces the commands between -foreach and -endfor to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, 

c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii
C3dEndfor(endfor: str)
endfor: str

c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dErf: 
1523@dataclasses.dataclass
1524class C3dErf:
1525    """
1526    -erf: Standard error function
1527
1528Syntax: `-erf mu sigma`
1529
1530Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma). 
1531
1532    c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img
1533    """
1534    erf: str
1535    """-erf: Standard error function
1536    
1537    Syntax: `-erf mu sigma`
1538    
1539    Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft
1540    thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma).
1541    
1542    c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img"""
1543    
1544    def run(
1545        self,
1546        execution: Execution,
1547    ) -> list[str]:
1548        """
1549        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1550        
1551        Args:
1552            self: The sub-command object.
1553            execution: The execution object.
1554        Returns:
1555            
1556        """
1557        cargs = []
1558        cargs.extend(["-erf", self.erf])
1559        return cargs

-erf: Standard error function

Syntax: -erf mu sigma

Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma). 

c3d input.img -erf 5 2 -o erf.img
C3dErf(erf: str)
erf: str

-erf: Standard error function

Syntax: -erf mu sigma

Computes the standard error function. This is useful for applying soft thresholds. The function computes y = erf((x - mu)/sigma).
