@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dExportPatches: 
1600@dataclasses.dataclass
1601class C3dExportPatches:
1602    """
1603    -export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions
1604
1605Syntax: `-export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>`
1606
1607See also: **-export-patches-aug (-xpa)** command, which provides data augmentation for deep learning.
1608
1609This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example, NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.
1610
1611    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
1612
1613This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.
1614
1615To read these samples in NumPy use the following code
1616
1617    dims = (9,9,9)                          # Patch dimensions
1618    k = 3                                   # Number of channels
1619    bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1))    # Bytes per sample
1620    np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps      # Number of samples
1621    arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)
1622
1623It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples.
1624
1625The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion, as follows:
1626
1627    c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1
1628
1629In the above example, **-centroid-mark** transforms the lesion segmentation into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken.
1630    """
1631    export_patches: str
1632    """-export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions
1633    
1634    Syntax: `-export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>`
1635    
1636    See also: **-export-patches-aug (-xpa)** command, which provides data
1637    augmentation for deep learning.
1638    
1639    This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them
1640    into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example,
1641    NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning
1642    projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.
1643    
1644    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
1645    
1646    This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground
1647    voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled
1648    randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that
1649    every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that
1650    patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled
1651    intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.
1652    
1653    To read these samples in NumPy use the following code
1654    
1655    dims = (9,9,9) # Patch dimensions
1656    k = 3 # Number of channels
1657    bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1)) # Bytes per sample
1658    np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps # Number of samples
1659    arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)
1660    
1661    It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by
1662    reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the
1663    patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples.
1664    
1665    The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if
1666    we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in
1667    an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion,
1668    as follows:
1669    
1670    c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1
1671    
1672    In the above example, **-centroid-mark** transforms the lesion segmentation
1673    into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken."""
1674    
1675    def run(
1676        self,
1677        execution: Execution,
1678    ) -> list[str]:
1679        """
1680        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1681        
1682        Args:
1683            self: The sub-command object.
1684            execution: The execution object.
1685        Returns:
1686            
1687        """
1688        cargs = []
1689        cargs.extend(["-export-patches", self.export_patches])
1690        return cargs

-export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions

Syntax: -export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>

See also: -export-patches-aug (-xpa) command, which provides data augmentation for deep learning.

This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example, NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.

c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100

This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.

To read these samples in NumPy use the following code

dims = (9,9,9)                          # Patch dimensions
k = 3                                   # Number of channels
bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1))    # Bytes per sample
np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps      # Number of samples
arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)

It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples.

The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion, as follows:

c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1

In the above example, -centroid-mark transforms the lesion segmentation into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken.

C3dExportPatches(export_patches: str)
export_patches: str

-export-patches, -xp: Fixed size patch sampling from masked regions

Syntax: -export-patches <outfile> <radius_vector> <frequency>

See also: -export-patches-aug (-xpa) command, which provides data augmentation for deep learning.

This command samples patches from a region of a ND image and stores them into a data file that can be read easily in other software, for example, NumPy. This is useful for generating training data for machine learning projects. Multiple "channels" can be sampled.

c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100

This command will sample the three images chan1, chan2, chan3 at foreground voxels in the mask. Voxels in the mask foreground region are sampled randomly, following a uniform distribution. The value of 100 means that every 100-th voxel, on average, is sampled. The radius 4x4x4 means that patches of size 9x9x9 will be generated. For each sampled voxel, the sampled intensity data is represented as a 3x9x9x9 array in this example.

To read these samples in NumPy use the following code

dims = (9,9,9) # Patch dimensions k = 3 # Number of channels bps = (4 * k * reduce(mul, dims, 1)) # Bytes per sample np = os.path.getsize(fname) // bps # Number of samples arr = numpy.memmap(fname,'float32','r',shape=(np,k) + dims)

It is also possible to visualize the extracted samples in ITK-SNAP by reading them as a raw image, with dimensions equal to the dimensions of the patch, and the z-dimension multiplied by the number of samples.

The command can also be used to extract entire structures. For example, if we have a binary segmentation of a lesion of an approximately known size in an MRI scan, we can extract a patch of given size centered on this lesion, as follows:

c3d mri.nii lesion_seg.nii -centroid-mark 1 -xp single_sample.dat 50x50x20 1

In the above example, -centroid-mark transforms the lesion segmentation into a single-voxel mask, from which the sample from the MRI is taken.

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

1676        self,
1677        execution: Execution,
1678    ) -> list[str]:

1683            self: The sub-command object.
1684            execution: The execution object.
1685        Returns:
1686            
1687        """
1688        cargs = []
1689        cargs.extend(["-export-patches", self.export_patches])
1690        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dExportPatchesAug: 
1693@dataclasses.dataclass
1694class C3dExportPatchesAug:
1695    """
1696    -export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning
1697
1698Syntax `-export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>`
1699
1700This command must precede the `-export-patches (-xp)` command and instructs this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also sample **N** randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh standard deviation **sigma_angle**, specified in degrees. This kind of sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms.
1701
1702    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
1703    """
1704    export_patches_aug: str
1705    """-export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning
1706    
1707    Syntax `-export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>`
1708    
1709    This command must precede the `-export-patches (-xp)` command and instructs
1710    this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also
1711    sample **N** randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly
1712    distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh
1713    standard deviation **sigma_angle**, specified in degrees. This kind of
1714    sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms.
1715    
1716    c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4
1717    100"""
1718    
1719    def run(
1720        self,
1721        execution: Execution,
1722    ) -> list[str]:
1723        """
1724        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1725        
1726        Args:
1727            self: The sub-command object.
1728            execution: The execution object.
1729        Returns:
1730            
1731        """
1732        cargs = []
1733        cargs.extend(["-export-patches-aug", self.export_patches_aug])
1734        return cargs

-export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning

Syntax -export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>

This command must precede the -export-patches (-xp) command and instructs this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also sample N randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh standard deviation sigma_angle, specified in degrees. This kind of sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms.

c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100
C3dExportPatchesAug(export_patches_aug: str)
export_patches_aug: str

-export-patches-aug, -xpa: data augmentation for deep learning

Syntax -export-patches-aug <N> <sigma_angle>

This command must precede the -export-patches (-xp) command and instructs this command to not only sample patches along the image axes but to also sample N randomly rotated patches. Rotation is around a uniformly distributed axis with a rotation angle distributed normally with teh standard deviation sigma_angle, specified in degrees. This kind of sampling is useful for data augmentation for machine learning algorithms.

c3d chan1.nii chan2.nii chan3.nii mask.nii -xpa 5 10 -xp samples.dat 4x4x4 100

1796Computes the Fourier transform of a real-valued image at the end of the stack. The image is replaced by the real and imaginary components of the FFT. This command is only available if **convert3d** is compiled with the FFTW library support. 
1797
1798    c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii
1799    """

1807    FFT. This command is only available if **convert3d** is compiled with the
1808    FFTW library support.
1809    
1810    c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii"""

Syntax -fft

Computes the Fourier transform of a real-valued image at the end of the stack. The image is replaced by the real and imaginary components of the FFT. This command is only available if convert3d is compiled with the FFTW library support. 

c3d image.nii -fft -oo real.nii imag.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dFlip: 
1830@dataclasses.dataclass
1831class C3dFlip:
1832    """
1833    -flip: Flip image around an axis    
1834
1835Syntax: `-flip axes`
1836
1837Flips the image around specified axes. The parameter 'axes' may be any combination of characters 'x', 'y', and 'z'; the order does not matter. 
1838
1839    c3d input.img -flip xy -o output.img
1840    """
1841    flip: str
1842    """-flip: Flip image around an axis
1843    
1844    Syntax: `-flip axes`
1845    
1846    Flips the image around specified axes. The parameter 'axes' may be any
1847    combination of characters 'x', 'y', and 'z'; the order does not matter.
1848    
1849    c3d input.img -flip xy -o output.img"""
1850    
1851    def run(
1852        self,
1853        execution: Execution,
1854    ) -> list[str]:
1855        """
1856        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1857        
1858        Args:
1859            self: The sub-command object.
1860            execution: The execution object.
1861        Returns:
1862            
1863        """
1864        cargs = []
1865        cargs.extend(["-flip", self.flip])
1866        return cargs

Syntax: -flip axes

Flips the image around specified axes. The parameter 'axes' may be any combination of characters 'x', 'y', and 'z'; the order does not matter.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dFloor: 
1869@dataclasses.dataclass
1870class C3dFloor:
1871    """
1872    -floor: Round down image intensities
1873
1874Syntax: `-floor `
1875
1876Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or equal to it.
1877
1878    c3d input.img -floor -o output.img
1879
1880To round each intensity to the closest integer, use
1881
1882    c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor
1883    """
1884    floor: str
1885    """-floor: Round down image intensities
1886    
1887    Syntax: `-floor `
1888    
1889    Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or equal to
1890    it.
1891    
1892    c3d input.img -floor -o output.img
1893    
1894    To round each intensity to the closest integer, use
1895    
1896    c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor"""

1899        self,
1900        execution: Execution,
1901    ) -> list[str]:
1902        """
1903        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1904        
1905        Args:
1906            self: The sub-command object.
1907            execution: The execution object.
1908        Returns:
1909            
1910        """
1911        cargs = []
1912        cargs.extend(["-floor", self.floor])
1913        return cargs

Syntax: -floor

Each image intensity is replaced by the largest integer smaller or equal to it.

c3d input.img -floor -o output.img

To round each intensity to the closest integer, use

c3d input.img -shift 0.5 -floor

floor: str

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dForeach: 
1916@dataclasses.dataclass
1917class C3dForeach:
1918    """
1919    -foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1920
1921Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1922
1923This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, 
1924
1925    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii
1926    """
1927    foreach: str
1928    """-foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack
1929    
1930    Syntax: `-foreach commands-list -endfor`
1931    
1932    This command forces the commands between **-foreach** and **-endfor** to be
1933    applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to
1934    automate processing of multiple datasets. For example,
1935    
1936    c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii"""
1937    
1938    def run(
1939        self,
1940        execution: Execution,
1941    ) -> list[str]:
1942        """
1943        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1944        
1945        Args:
1946            self: The sub-command object.
1947            execution: The execution object.
1948        Returns:
1949            
1950        """
1951        cargs = []
1952        cargs.extend(["-foreach", self.foreach])
1953        return cargs

-foreach, -endfor: Loop commands over all images on the stack

Syntax: -foreach commands-list -endfor

This command forces the commands between -foreach and -endfor to be applied to every image on the stack. The main use of this command is to automate processing of multiple datasets. For example, 

c3d epi*.nii -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -oo epism%03d.nii

foreach: str

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dForeachComp: 
1956@dataclasses.dataclass
1957class C3dForeachComp:
1958    """
1959    -foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a multi-component image 
1960
1961Syntax `-foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor`
1962
1963This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack contains images *x1* *y1* *z1* *x2* *y2* *z2*, then the operations will be run on *[x1,x2]*, *[y1,y2]*, *[z1,z2]*. For example, if multi_1.nii to multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image is given by
1964
1965    c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii
1966    """
1967    foreach_comp: str
1968    """-foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a
1969    multi-component image
1970    
1971    Syntax `-foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor`
1972    
1973    This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a
1974    set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to
1975    perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it
1976    can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack
1977    contains images *x1* *y1* *z1* *x2* *y2* *z2*, then the operations will be
1978    run on *[x1,x2]*, *[y1,y2]*, *[z1,z2]*. For example, if multi_1.nii to
1979    multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image
1980    is given by
1981    
1982    c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii"""
1983    
1984    def run(
1985        self,
1986        execution: Execution,
1987    ) -> list[str]:
1988        """
1989        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
1990        
1991        Args:
1992            self: The sub-command object.
1993            execution: The execution object.
1994        Returns:
1995            
1996        """
1997        cargs = []
1998        cargs.extend(["-foreach-comp", self.foreach_comp])
1999        return cargs

-foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a multi-component image

Syntax -foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor

This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack contains images x1 y1 z1 x2 y2 z2, then the operations will be run on [x1,x2], [y1,y2], [z1,z2]. For example, if multi_1.nii to multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image is given by

c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii
C3dForeachComp(foreach_comp: str)
foreach_comp: str

-foreach-comp, -endfor: Loop commands over components of a multi-component image

Syntax -foreach-comp <N> commands-list -endfor

This command runs the list of commands separately for each component of a set of multi-component images loaded with -mcs. This makes it possible to perform component-wise operations on multi-component images. For example, it can be used to average several multi-component images. If the image stack contains images x1 y1 z1 x2 y2 z2, then the operations will be run on [x1,x2], [y1,y2], [z1,z2]. For example, if multi_1.nii to multi_10.nii are three-component images, then the mean three-component image is given by

c2d -mcs multi_*.nii -foreach-comp -mean -endfor -omc multi_mean.nii

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dGlm: 
2002@dataclasses.dataclass
2003class C3dGlm:
2004    """
2005    -glm: General linear model    
2006
2007Syntax: `-glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file`
2008
2009Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely, the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X \beta + \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $\beta$ is a set of $k$ unknown images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute the $\beta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds., *Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition*][6]. The example below computes the regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's age: 
2010
2011      echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt
2012      echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt
2013      echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt
2014      echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt
2015      echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt
2016      c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img
2017    """
2018    glm: str
2019    """-glm: General linear model
2020    
2021    Syntax: `-glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file`
2022    
2023    Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely,
2024    the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X \beta +
2025    \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each
2026    voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design
2027    matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $\beta$ is a set of $k$ unknown
2028    images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute
2029    the $\beta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are
2030    specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector
2031    are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of
2032    numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel
2033    and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds.,
2034    *Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition*][6]. The example below computes the
2035    regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's
2036    age:
2037    
2038    echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt
2039    echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt
2040    echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt
2041    echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt
2042    echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt
2043    c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt
2044    contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img"""
2045    
2046    def run(
2047        self,
2048        execution: Execution,
2049    ) -> list[str]:
2050        """
2051        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2052        
2053        Args:
2054            self: The sub-command object.
2055            execution: The execution object.
2056        Returns:
2057            
2058        """
2059        cargs = []
2060        cargs.extend(["-glm", self.glm])
2061        return cargs

-glm: General linear model

Syntax: -glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file

Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely, the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X eta + \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $eta$ is a set of $k$ unknown images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute the $eta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds., Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition][6]. The example below computes the regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's age: 

  echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt
  echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt
  echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt
  echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt
  echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt
  c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img
C3dGlm(glm: str)
glm: str

-glm: General linear model

Syntax: -glm design_matrix_file contrast_vector_file

Applies voxel-wise general linear model to a set of images. More precisely, the general linear model solves the following system: $Y = X eta + \epsilon$, where Y are the observations (a list of n images, where each voxel is treated as an independent observation); X is the $n x k$ design matrix, where $k$ is the number of factors; $eta$ is a set of $k$ unknown images (factors) and $\epsilon$ is the error term. The command will compute the $eta$ images and return a weighted sum of them, where the weights are specified in the contrast vector. The design matrix and the contrast vector are passed in as files. The file format is just a space-separated list of numbers. For a good explanation of the general linear model, see [S. Kiebel and A. Holmes, General Linear Model, in Ashburner, Friston, Holmes eds., Human Brain Function, 2nd Edition][6]. The example below computes the regression coefficient between a set of longitudinal images and subject's age:

echo "1 67.00" > design_mat.txt echo "1 75.00" >> design_mat.txt echo "1 80.00" >> design_mat.txt echo "1 83.00" >> design_mat.txt echo "0 1" >> contrast_vec.txt c3d time1.img time2.img time3.img time4.img -glm design_mat.txt contrast_vec.txt -o regress.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
2046    def run(
2047        self,
2048        execution: Execution,
2049    ) -> list[str]:
2050        """

2054            self: The sub-command object.
2055            execution: The execution object.
2056        Returns:
2057            
2058        """
2059        cargs = []
2060        cargs.extend(["-glm", self.glm])
2061        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dGradient: 
2064@dataclasses.dataclass
2065class C3dGradient:
2066    """
2067    -grad, -gradient: Image gradient
2068
2069Syntax `-grad`
2070
2071Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to smooth the image first before computing the gradient.
2072
2073    c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii
2074    """
2075    gradient: str
2076    """-grad, -gradient: Image gradient
2077    
2078    Syntax `-grad`
2079    
2080    Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed
2081    on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS
2082    coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other
2083    words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the
2084    isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to
2085    smooth the image first before computing the gradient.
2086    
2087    c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii"""
2088    
2089    def run(
2090        self,
2091        execution: Execution,
2092    ) -> list[str]:
2093        """
2094        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2095        
2096        Args:
2097            self: The sub-command object.
2098            execution: The execution object.
2099        Returns:
2100            
2101        """
2102        cargs = []
2103        cargs.extend(["-grad", self.gradient])
2104        return cargs

-grad, -gradient: Image gradient

Syntax -grad

Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to smooth the image first before computing the gradient.

c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii
C3dGradient(gradient: str)
gradient: str

-grad, -gradient: Image gradient

Syntax -grad

Computes the gradient of the image. Each component of the gradient is placed on the stack in order (x,y,z). The gradient is computed in physical RAS coordinates, taking into account image spacing and orientation. In other words, the gradient is the vector in physical space orthogonal to the isocontours of the image. No smoothing is performed, so it is a good idea to smooth the image first before computing the gradient.

c3d myimage.nii -smooth 1.2vox -grad -oo grad_comp_%02d.nii

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dHelp: 
2107@dataclasses.dataclass
2108class C3dHelp:
2109    """
2110    -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2111
2112Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2113
2114Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.
2115
2116    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
2117    """
2118    v__help: str
2119    """-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2120    
2121    Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2122    
2123    Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues
2124    of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on
2125    the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the
2126    '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing
2127    applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in
2128    physical (mm) units.
2129    
2130    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz"""
2131    
2132    def run(
2133        self,
2134        execution: Execution,
2135    ) -> list[str]:
2136        """
2137        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2138        
2139        Args:
2140            self: The sub-command object.
2141            execution: The execution object.
2142        Returns:
2143            
2144        """
2145        cargs = []
2146        cargs.extend(["-h", self.v__help])
2147        return cargs

-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix

Syntax -hesseig <scale>

Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.

c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
C3dHelp(v__help: str)
v__help: str

-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix

Syntax -hesseig <scale>

Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.

c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
2132    def run(
2133        self,
2134        execution: Execution,
2135    ) -> list[str]:
2136        """
2137        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2138        
2139        Args:
2140            self: The sub-command object.
2141            execution: The execution object.
2142        Returns:
2143            
2144        """
2145        cargs = []
2146        cargs.extend(["-h", self.v__help])
2147        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dHessianEigenvalues: 
2196@dataclasses.dataclass
2197class C3dHessianEigenvalues:
2198    """
2199    -hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2200
2201Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2202
2203Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.
2204
2205    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
2206    """
2207    hessian_eigenvalues: str
2208    """-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix
2209    
2210    Syntax `-hesseig <scale>`
2211    
2212    Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues
2213    of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on
2214    the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the
2215    '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing
2216    applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in
2217    physical (mm) units.
2218    
2219    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz"""
2220    
2221    def run(
2222        self,
2223        execution: Execution,
2224    ) -> list[str]:
2225        """
2226        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2227        
2228        Args:
2229            self: The sub-command object.
2230            execution: The execution object.
2231        Returns:
2232            
2233        """
2234        cargs = []
2235        cargs.extend(["-hesseig", self.hessian_eigenvalues])
2236        return cargs

-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix

Syntax -hesseig <scale>

Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.

c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
C3dHessianEigenvalues(hessian_eigenvalues: str)
hessian_eigenvalues: str

-hesseig, -hessian-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix

Syntax -hesseig <scale>

Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.

c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

2230            execution: The execution object.
2231        Returns:
2232            
2233        """
2234        cargs = []
2235        cargs.extend(["-hesseig", self.hessian_eigenvalues])
2236        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dHessianObjectness: 
2239@dataclasses.dataclass
2240class C3dHessianObjectness:
2241    """
2242    -hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter
2243
2244Syntax: `-hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>`
2245
2246Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF]. 
2247
2248Parameter `dimension` is an integer that determines the kind of features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is used.
2249
2250    # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm
2251    c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5
2252
2253 [HTOMIF] http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html
2254    """
2255    hessian_objectness: str
2256    """-hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter
2257    
2258    Syntax: `-hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>`
2259    
2260    Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to
2261    highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For
2262    details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF].
2263    
2264    Parameter `dimension` is an integer that determines the kind of features
2265    that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The
2266    min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of
2267    the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is
2268    used.
2269    
2270    # Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm
2271    c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5
2272    
2273    [HTOMIF]
2274    http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html"""
2275    
2276    def run(
2277        self,
2278        execution: Execution,
2279    ) -> list[str]:
2280        """
2281        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2282        
2283        Args:
2284            self: The sub-command object.
2285            execution: The execution object.
2286        Returns:
2287            
2288        """
2289        cargs = []
2290        cargs.extend(["-hessobj", self.hessian_objectness])
2291        return cargs

-hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter

Syntax: -hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>

Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF].

Parameter dimension is an integer that determines the kind of features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is used.

# Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm
c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5

[HTOMIF] http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html

C3dHessianObjectness(hessian_objectness: str)
hessian_objectness: str

-hessobj, -hessian-objectness: Hessian objectness filter

Syntax: -hessobj <dimension> <min_scale> <max_scale>

Also known as the Frangi vesselness filter, this filter can be used to highlight tube-like, sheet-like and blob-like objects in the image. For details, see documentation to the [corresponging ITK class][HTOMIF].

Parameter dimension is an integer that determines the kind of features that are highlighed. Use 0 for blobs, 1 for tubes, 2 for pancakes, etc. The min and max scale parameters are floating point values, giving the scale of the features highlighted, in physical units. Typically, just one scale is used.

Detect vessel-like structures at scale 0.5mm

c3d image.nii.gz -hessobj 1 0.5 0.5

[HTOMIF] http://www.itk.org/Doxygen/html/classitk_1_1HessianToObjectnessMeasureImageFilter.html

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

2277        self,
2278        execution: Execution,
2279    ) -> list[str]:

2283        Args:
2284            self: The sub-command object.
2285            execution: The execution object.
2286        Returns:
2287            
2288        """
2289        cargs = []
2290        cargs.extend(["-hessobj", self.hessian_objectness])
2291        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dHolefill: 
2150@dataclasses.dataclass
2151class C3dHolefill:
2152    """
2153    -holefill: Fill holes in binary image
2154
2155Syntax: `-holefill intensity_value [0|1] `
2156
2157Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this algorithm][7]. 
2158
2159    c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz
2160    """
2161    holefill: str
2162    """-holefill: Fill holes in binary image
2163    
2164    Syntax: `-holefill intensity_value [0|1] `
2165    
2166    Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in
2167    the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label
2168    segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value
2169    that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The
2170    second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to
2171    determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face
2172    connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and
2173    vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this
2174    algorithm][7].
2175    
2176    c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz"""
2177    
2178    def run(
2179        self,
2180        execution: Execution,
2181    ) -> list[str]:
2182        """
2183        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2184        
2185        Args:
2186            self: The sub-command object.
2187            execution: The execution object.
2188        Returns:
2189            
2190        """
2191        cargs = []
2192        cargs.extend(["-hf", self.holefill])
2193        return cargs

-holefill: Fill holes in binary image

Syntax: -holefill intensity_value [0|1]

Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this algorithm][7]. 

c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz
C3dHolefill(holefill: str)
holefill: str

-holefill: Fill holes in binary image

Syntax: -holefill intensity_value [0|1]

Apply the binary hole filling algorithm to a particular intensity value in the image. The input image is typically a binary image or a multi-label segmentation image. Holes (voxels not matching the specified intensity value that are completely contained by voxels matching this value) are filled. The second parameter specifies what type of topological connectivity is used to determine holes. The value 0 uses the default algorithm in ITK (face connectivity) and 1 uses the full connectivity variant (face, edge and vertex connectivity). For more details see the [ITK page for this algorithm][7].

c3d segmentation.nii.gz -holefill 5 0 -type uchar -o filledlabel5.nii.gz

2321class C3dInfo:
2322    """
2323    -info: Display brief image information        
2324
2325Syntax: `-info`
2326
2327Prints brief information about the last image on the stack. Does not affect the stack.
2328
2329    c3d image.hdr -info
2330
2331Use with the **-foreach** command to get information on multiple images
2332
2333    c3d images*.nii -foreach -info -endfor
2334    """

2344    
2345    Use with the **-foreach** command to get information on multiple images
2346    
2347    c3d images*.nii -foreach -info -endfor"""

-info: Display brief image information

Syntax: -info

Prints brief information about the last image on the stack. Does not affect the stack.

c3d image.hdr -info

Use with the -foreach command to get information on multiple images

c3d images*.nii -foreach -info -endfor

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dInsert: 
2406@dataclasses.dataclass
2407class C3dInsert:
2408    """
2409    -insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack
2410
2411Syntax: `-insert var pos` 
2412
2413This command is similar to **-push**, but allows you to insert the image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as **-push**). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end position, and so on.
2414    """
2415    insert: str
2416    """-insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack
2417    
2418    Syntax: `-insert var pos`
2419    
2420    This command is similar to **-push**, but allows you to insert the image
2421    associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end.
2422    When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as
2423    **-push**). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end
2424    position, and so on."""
2425    
2426    def run(
2427        self,
2428        execution: Execution,
2429    ) -> list[str]:
2430        """
2431        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2432        
2433        Args:
2434            self: The sub-command object.
2435            execution: The execution object.
2436        Returns:
2437            
2438        """
2439        cargs = []
2440        cargs.extend(["-insert", self.insert])
2441        return cargs

-insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack

Syntax: -insert var pos

This command is similar to -push, but allows you to insert the image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as -push). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end position, and so on.

C3dInsert(insert: str)
insert: str

-insert: Insert image anywhere in the stack

Syntax: -insert var pos

This command is similar to -push, but allows you to insert the image associated with 'var' at any position in the stack, counting from the end. When 'pos' is 0, the image is placed at the end of the stack (same as -push). When pos is one, the image is placed at the next-to-end position, and so on.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dInterpolation: 
2444@dataclasses.dataclass
2445class C3dInterpolation:
2446    """
2447    -interpolation: Set interpolation mode
2448
2449Syntax: `-interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param]`
2450
2451Specifies the interpolation used with **-resample** and other commands. Default is **Linear**. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with small sigmas (a few voxels across). 
2452
2453Shorthand 0 can be used for *NearestNeighbor*, 1 for *Linear* and 3 for *Cubic*. For example:
2454
2455    c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii
2456    """
2457    interpolation: str
2458    """-interpolation: Set interpolation mode
2459    
2460    Syntax: `-interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian>
2461    [param]`
2462    
2463    Specifies the interpolation used with **-resample** and other commands.
2464    Default is **Linear**. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the
2465    standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation
2466    is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter
2467    and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and
2468    has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with
2469    small sigmas (a few voxels across).
2470    
2471    Shorthand 0 can be used for *NearestNeighbor*, 1 for *Linear* and 3 for
2472    *Cubic*. For example:
2473    
2474    c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii"""
2475    
2476    def run(
2477        self,
2478        execution: Execution,
2479    ) -> list[str]:
2480        """
2481        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2482        
2483        Args:
2484            self: The sub-command object.
2485            execution: The execution object.
2486        Returns:
2487            
2488        """
2489        cargs = []
2490        cargs.extend(["-interpolation", self.interpolation])
2491        return cargs

-interpolation: Set interpolation mode

Syntax: -interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param]

Specifies the interpolation used with -resample and other commands. Default is Linear. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with small sigmas (a few voxels across).

Shorthand 0 can be used for NearestNeighbor, 1 for Linear and 3 for Cubic. For example:

c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii
C3dInterpolation(interpolation: str)
interpolation: str

-interpolation: Set interpolation mode

Syntax: -interpolation <NearestNeighbor|Linear|Cubic|Sinc|Gaussian> [param]

Specifies the interpolation used with -resample and other commands. Default is Linear. Gaussian interpolation takes as the parameter the standard deviation of the Gaussian filter (e.g, 1mm). Gaussian interpolation is very similar in result to first smoothing an image with a Gaussian filter and then reslicing it with linear interpolation, but is more accurate and has less aliasing artifacts. It is also slower, and should only be used with small sigmas (a few voxels across).

Shorthand 0 can be used for NearestNeighbor, 1 for Linear and 3 for Cubic. For example:

c3d -int 3 test.nii -resample 200x200x200% -o cubic_supersample.nii

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
2476    def run(

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dLabelStatistics: 
2546@dataclasses.dataclass
2547class C3dLabelStatistics:
2548    """
2549    -lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation volumes and intensity statistics
2550
2551Syntax: `-lstat`
2552
2553Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this command computes the statistics for every label in the latter, including volumes, average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance, if image *mri.nii* is a medical image and *seg.nii* is a multilabel segmentation of the image with labels 0, 1 and 4, the following command can be used to print the statistics of the intensity of *mri.nii* for each of the labels 
2554
2555    c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat
2556
2557The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity and minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from a multi-label image, use **-dup** command as follows:
2558
2559    c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat
2560    """
2561    label_statistics: str
2562    """-lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation volumes and intensity
2563    statistics
2564    
2565    Syntax: `-lstat`
2566    
2567    Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this command
2568    computes the statistics for every label in the latter, including volumes,
2569    average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance, if image *mri.nii* is a
2570    medical image and *seg.nii* is a multilabel segmentation of the image with
2571    labels 0, 1 and 4, the following command can be used to print the statistics
2572    of the intensity of *mri.nii* for each of the labels
2573    
2574    c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat
2575    
2576    The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity and
2577    minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from a
2578    multi-label image, use **-dup** command as follows:
2579    
2580    c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat"""
2581    
2582    def run(
2583        self,
2584        execution: Execution,
2585    ) -> list[str]:
2586        """
2587        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2588        
2589        Args:
2590            self: The sub-command object.
2591            execution: The execution object.
2592        Returns:
2593            
2594        """
2595        cargs = []
2596        cargs.extend(["-label-statistics", self.label_statistics])
2597        return cargs

-lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation volumes and intensity statistics

Syntax: -lstat

Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this command computes the statistics for every label in the latter, including volumes, average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance, if image mri.nii is a medical image and seg.nii is a multilabel segmentation of the image with labels 0, 1 and 4, the following command can be used to print the statistics of the intensity of mri.nii for each of the labels 

c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat

The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity and minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from a multi-label image, use -dup command as follows:

c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat
C3dLabelStatistics(label_statistics: str)
label_statistics: str

-lstat, -label-statistics: Display segmentation volumes and intensity statistics

Syntax: -lstat

Given a grayscale image and a multilabel (or binary) image, this command computes the statistics for every label in the latter, including volumes, average grayscale intensity, etc. For instance, if image mri.nii is a medical image and seg.nii is a multilabel segmentation of the image with labels 0, 1 and 4, the following command can be used to print the statistics of the intensity of mri.nii for each of the labels

c3d mri.nii seg.nii -lstat

The output contains the mean, standard deviation, maximum intensity and minimum intensity for each label. If you just need volumes from a multi-label image, use -dup command as follows:

c3d seg.nii -dup -lstat

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

2593

2595        cargs = []
2596        cargs.extend(["-label-statistics", self.label_statistics])
2597        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dLaplacian: 
2626@dataclasses.dataclass
2627class C3dLaplacian:
2628    """
2629    -laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter
2630
2631Syntax: `-laplacian`
2632
2633Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of intensity. Typically, used with the **-smooth** option to obtain the equivalent of convolving the image with the *Laplacian of the Gaussian (LoG)* kernel: 
2634
2635    c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img
2636    """
2637    laplacian: str
2638    """-laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter
2639    
2640    Syntax: `-laplacian`
2641    
2642    Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of
2643    intensity. Typically, used with the **-smooth** option to obtain the
2644    equivalent of convolving the image with the *Laplacian of the Gaussian
2645    (LoG)* kernel:
2646    
2647    c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img"""
2648    
2649    def run(
2650        self,
2651        execution: Execution,
2652    ) -> list[str]:
2653        """
2654        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2655        
2656        Args:
2657            self: The sub-command object.
2658            execution: The execution object.
2659        Returns:
2660            
2661        """
2662        cargs = []
2663        cargs.extend(["-laplacian", self.laplacian])
2664        return cargs

-laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter

Syntax: -laplacian

Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of intensity. Typically, used with the -smooth option to obtain the equivalent of convolving the image with the Laplacian of the Gaussian (LoG) kernel: 

c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img
C3dLaplacian(laplacian: str)
laplacian: str

-laplacian, -laplace: Laplacian filter

Syntax: -laplacian

Applies the Laplacian filter to the image. Used to detect ridges of intensity. Typically, used with the -smooth option to obtain the equivalent of convolving the image with the Laplacian of the Gaussian (LoG) kernel:

c3d input.img -smooth 1.2vox -laplacian -o output.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dLevelset: 
2667@dataclasses.dataclass
2668class C3dLevelset:
2669    """
2670    -levelset: Level set segmentation
2671
2672Syntax: `-levelset n_iter `
2673
2674Perform level set segmentation for *n\_iter* iterations, like in ITK-SNAP. The last image on the stack is treated as the initialization image and the next-to-last image on the stack is the speed image. Both images should be in the range between -1 and 1. Here is how the signs of the different images are interpreted 
2675
2676|    | Speed Image   | Initialization Image | Output Image |
2677| -- | ------------- | -------------------- | ------------ |
2678| +1 | Foreground    | Outside              | Outside      |
2679| -1 | Background    | Inside               | Inside       | 
2680
2681Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization given: 
2682
2683    c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o seg.img
2684
2685Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image, where the ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The image seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the initialization seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside). 
2686
2687    c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz \
2688        -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500 \
2689        -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz
2690
2691Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for cleaning up manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive inside the binary object, and the initialization is negative inside the object. The command writes out both the level set image (whose 0-level set is the smoothed boundary of the binary object) and the smoothed binary object 
2692
2693    c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1 \
2694        -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img \
2695        -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img
2696    """
2697    levelset: str
2698    """-levelset: Level set segmentation
2699    
2700    Syntax: `-levelset n_iter `
2701    
2702    Perform level set segmentation for *n\_iter* iterations, like in ITK-SNAP.
2703    The last image on the stack is treated as the initialization image and the
2704    next-to-last image on the stack is the speed image. Both images should be in
2705    the range between -1 and 1. Here is how the signs of the different images
2706    are interpreted
2707    
2708    | | Speed Image | Initialization Image | Output Image |
2709    | -- | ------------- | -------------------- | ------------ |
2710    | +1 | Foreground | Outside | Outside |
2711    | -1 | Background | Inside | Inside |
2712    
2713    Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization given:
2714    
2715    c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o seg.img
2716    
2717    Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image, where the
2718    ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The image
2719    seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the initialization
2720    seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside).
2721    
2722    c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz \
2723    -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500 \
2724    -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz
2725    
2726    Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for cleaning up
2727    manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive inside the binary
2728    object, and the initialization is negative inside the object. The command
2729    writes out both the level set image (whose 0-level set is the smoothed
2730    boundary of the binary object) and the smoothed binary object
2731    
2732    c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1 \
2733    -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img \
2734    -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img"""
2735    
2736    def run(
2737        self,
2738        execution: Execution,
2739    ) -> list[str]:
2740        """
2741        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2742        
2743        Args:
2744            self: The sub-command object.
2745            execution: The execution object.
2746        Returns:
2747            
2748        """
2749        cargs = []
2750        cargs.extend(["-levelset", self.levelset])
2751        return cargs

-levelset: Level set segmentation

Syntax: -levelset n_iter

Perform level set segmentation for n_iter iterations, like in ITK-SNAP. The last image on the stack is treated as the initialization image and the next-to-last image on the stack is the speed image. Both images should be in the range between -1 and 1. Here is how the signs of the different images are interpreted

Speed Image Initialization Image Output Image
+1 Foreground Outside Outside
-1 Background Inside Inside

Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization given: 

c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o seg.img

Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image, where the ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The image seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the initialization seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside). 

c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz         -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500         -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz

Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for cleaning up manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive inside the binary object, and the initialization is negative inside the object. The command writes out both the level set image (whose 0-level set is the smoothed boundary of the binary object) and the smoothed binary object 

c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1         -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img         -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img
C3dLevelset(levelset: str)
levelset: str

-levelset: Level set segmentation

Syntax: -levelset n_iter

Perform level set segmentation for n_iter iterations, like in ITK-SNAP. The last image on the stack is treated as the initialization image and the next-to-last image on the stack is the speed image. Both images should be in the range between -1 and 1. Here is how the signs of the different images are interpreted

Speed Image Initialization Image Output Image
+1 Foreground Outside Outside
-1 Background Inside Inside

Here is an example where you have the speed and the initialization given:

c3d speed.img initial.img -levelset-curvature 0.5 -levelset 100 -o seg.img

Here is an example of segmenting the ventricles in an MRI image, where the ventricles and other CSF have intensity below 715. The image seg_bubbles.nii.gz in this example is a binary image of the initialization seeds (1 inside the seeds, 0 outside).

c3d brain.nii.gz -erf 715 100 -scale -1 seg_bubbles.nii.gz -replace 0 1 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 0.2 -levelset 500 -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o segmentation.nii.gz

Another example of smoothing a binary image that is useful for cleaning up manual segmentations. Here the speed image is positive inside the binary object, and the initialization is negative inside the object. The command writes out both the level set image (whose 0-level set is the smoothed boundary of the binary object) and the smoothed binary object

c3d binary.img -threshold 1 inf 1 -1 -binary.img 1 inf 1 -1 -levelset-curvature 1.5 -levelset 100 -o levelset.img -thresh -inf 0 1 0 -o smoothed_binary.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

2745            execution: The execution object.
2746        Returns:
2747            
2748        """
2749        cargs = []
2750        cargs.extend(["-levelset", self.levelset])
2751        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dMatchBoundingBox: 
2900@dataclasses.dataclass
2901class C3dMatchBoundingBox:
2902    """
2903    -mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of one image to another
2904
2905Syntax: `-mbb`
2906
2907Given two images on the stack (reference and target), sets the header of the target image so that the two images occupy the same physical space. The direction cosines of the target image are set to match the reference image.  This command is related to '-copy-transform' but supports images of different size.
2908
2909    c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii
2910    """
2911    match_bounding_box: str
2912    """-mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of one image to another
2913    
2914    Syntax: `-mbb`
2915    
2916    Given two images on the stack (reference and target), sets the header of the
2917    target image so that the two images occupy the same physical space. The
2918    direction cosines of the target image are set to match the reference image.
2919    This command is related to '-copy-transform' but supports images of
2920    different size.
2921    
2922    c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii"""
2923    
2924    def run(
2925        self,
2926        execution: Execution,
2927    ) -> list[str]:
2928        """
2929        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
2930        
2931        Args:
2932            self: The sub-command object.
2933            execution: The execution object.
2934        Returns:
2935            
2936        """
2937        cargs = []
2938        cargs.extend(["-match-bounding-box", self.match_bounding_box])
2939        return cargs

-mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of one image to another

Syntax: -mbb

Given two images on the stack (reference and target), sets the header of the target image so that the two images occupy the same physical space. The direction cosines of the target image are set to match the reference image. This command is related to '-copy-transform' but supports images of different size.

c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii
C3dMatchBoundingBox(match_bounding_box: str)
match_bounding_box: str

-mbb, -match-bounding-box: Match bounding box of one image to another

Syntax: -mbb

The direction cosines of the target image are set to match the reference image. This command is related to '-copy-transform' but supports images of different size.

c3d reference.nii target.nii -mbb -o out.nii

2943class C3dMaximum:
2944    """
2945    -max: Voxel-wise maximum of two images
2946
2947Syntax: `-max`
2948
2949Computes the voxel-wise maximum of two images. Can be used with the **-accum** command to compute maximum of all images. 
2950
2951    c3d i1.nii i2.nii -max -o max12.nii
2952    c3d i1.nii i2.nii i3.nii i4.nii -accum -max -endaccum -o max1234.nii
2953    """
2954    maximum: str

2963    c3d i1.nii i2.nii i3.nii i4.nii -accum -max -endaccum -o max1234.nii"""

class C3dMeanFilter: 
3154@dataclasses.dataclass
3155class C3dMeanFilter:
3156    """
3157    -mf, -mean-filter: Mean filter
3158
3159Syntax: `-mf <radius_vector>`
3160
3161Applies the mean filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the mean of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the mean filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood. 
3162
3163    c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii
3164    """
3165    mean_filter: str
3166    """-mf, -mean-filter: Mean filter
3167    
3168    Syntax: `-mf <radius_vector>`
3169    
3170    Applies the mean filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the mean
3171    of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius
3172    parameter. For example, the following code will apply the mean filter with
3173    the 5x5x5 neighborhood.
3174    
3175    c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii"""
3176    
3177    def run(
3178        self,
3179        execution: Execution,
3180    ) -> list[str]:
3181        """
3182        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3183        
3184        Args:
3185            self: The sub-command object.
3186            execution: The execution object.
3187        Returns:
3188            
3189        """
3190        cargs = []
3191        cargs.extend(["-mf", self.mean_filter])
3192        return cargs

-mf, -mean-filter: Mean filter

Syntax: -mf <radius_vector>

Applies the mean filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the mean of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the mean filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood. 

c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii
C3dMeanFilter(mean_filter: str)
mean_filter: str

c3d in.nii -mf 2x2x2 -o filtered.nii
