@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dMeanSquare: 
3355@dataclasses.dataclass
3356class C3dMeanSquare:
3357    """
3358    -msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric
3359
3360Syntax: `-msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]`
3361
3362Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two images on the stack. If an optional *movtransform.mat* file is provided, the metric is computed by applying the transform to the moving image. If, in addition to *movtransform.mat*, the optional *reftransform.mat* file is also provided -- the moving transform is applied to the moving image, the ref transform is applied to the reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space that is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This may be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms are inverse of each other as both images undergo similar amount of interpolation. The definitions of reference and moving images and the transform file format are similar to the **-reslice-matrix** command. 
3363
3364    # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii
3365    c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq
3366
3367    # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying transform to mov.nii
3368    c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat
3369
3370    # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space after applying transforms to both
3371    c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat
3372    """
3373    mean_square: str
3374    """-msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric
3375    
3376    Syntax: `-msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]`
3377    
3378    Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two images on the
3379    stack. If an optional *movtransform.mat* file is provided, the metric is
3380    computed by applying the transform to the moving image. If, in addition to
3381    *movtransform.mat*, the optional *reftransform.mat* file is also provided --
3382    the moving transform is applied to the moving image, the ref transform is
3383    applied to the reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space
3384    that is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This may
3385    be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms are inverse
3386    of each other as both images undergo similar amount of interpolation. The
3387    definitions of reference and moving images and the transform file format are
3388    similar to the **-reslice-matrix** command.
3389    
3390    # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii
3391    c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq
3392    
3393    # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying transform to
3394    mov.nii
3395    c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat
3396    
3397    # Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space after
3398    applying transforms to both
3399    c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat"""
3400    
3401    def run(
3402        self,
3403        execution: Execution,
3404    ) -> list[str]:
3405        """
3406        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3407        
3408        Args:
3409            self: The sub-command object.
3410            execution: The execution object.
3411        Returns:
3412            
3413        """
3414        cargs = []
3415        cargs.extend(["-msq", self.mean_square])
3416        return cargs

-msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric

Syntax: -msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]

Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two images on the stack. If an optional movtransform.mat file is provided, the metric is computed by applying the transform to the moving image. If, in addition to movtransform.mat, the optional reftransform.mat file is also provided -- the moving transform is applied to the moving image, the ref transform is applied to the reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space that is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This may be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms are inverse of each other as both images undergo similar amount of interpolation. The definitions of reference and moving images and the transform file format are similar to the -reslice-matrix command. 

# Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii
c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq

# Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying transform to mov.nii
c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat

# Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space after applying transforms to both
c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat
C3dMeanSquare(mean_square: str)
mean_square: str

-msq, -mean-square: Compute mean square difference metric

Syntax: -msq [movtransform.mat] [reftransform.mat]

Compute the mean square difference metric between the last two images on the stack. If an optional movtransform.mat file is provided, the metric is computed by applying the transform to the moving image. If, in addition to movtransform.mat, the optional reftransform.mat file is also provided -- the moving transform is applied to the moving image, the ref transform is applied to the reference image, and the metric is computed in an image space that is physically halfway between the reference and moving images. This may be useful for unbiased metric computation if the two transforms are inverse of each other as both images undergo similar amount of interpolation. The definitions of reference and moving images and the transform file format are similar to the -reslice-matrix command.

Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii

c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq

Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii after applying transform to

mov.nii c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat

Compute metric between ref.nii and mov.nii in a neutral space after

applying transforms to both c3d ref.nii mov.nii -msq tmov.mat tref.mat

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
3401    def run(
3402        self,
3403        execution: Execution,
3404    ) -> list[str]:
3405        """
3406        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3407        
3408        Args:
3409            self: The sub-command object.
3410            execution: The execution object.
3411        Returns:
3412            
3413        """
3414        cargs = []
3415        cargs.extend(["-msq", self.mean_square])
3416        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dMedianFilter: 
3077@dataclasses.dataclass
3078class C3dMedianFilter:
3079    """
3080    -median, -median-filter: Median filter
3081
3082Syntax: `-median <radius_vector>`
3083
3084Applies the median filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the median filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood. 
3085
3086    c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii
3087    """
3088    median_filter: str
3089    """-median, -median-filter: Median filter
3090    
3091    Syntax: `-median <radius_vector>`
3092    
3093    Applies the median filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the
3094    median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the
3095    radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the median
3096    filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood.
3097    
3098    c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii"""
3099    
3100    def run(
3101        self,
3102        execution: Execution,
3103    ) -> list[str]:
3104        """
3105        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3106        
3107        Args:
3108            self: The sub-command object.
3109            execution: The execution object.
3110        Returns:
3111            
3112        """
3113        cargs = []
3114        cargs.extend(["-median", self.median_filter])
3115        return cargs

-median, -median-filter: Median filter

Syntax: -median <radius_vector>

Applies the median filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the median filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood. 

c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii
C3dMedianFilter(median_filter: str)
median_filter: str

-median, -median-filter: Median filter

Syntax: -median <radius_vector>

Applies the median filter: the intensity of each voxel is replaced by the median of the intensities in the neighborhood of size specified by the radius parameter. For example, the following code will apply the median filter with the 5x5x5 neighborhood.

c3d in.nii -median 2x2x2 -o median.nii

3109            execution: The execution object.
3110        Returns:
3111            
3112        """

3114        cargs.extend(["-median", self.median_filter])
3115        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

3244

3246    c3d i1.nii i2.nii i3.nii i4.nii -accum -min -endaccum -o min1234.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dMulticomponentSplit: 
2983@dataclasses.dataclass
2984class C3dMulticomponentSplit:
2985    """
2986    -mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of multi-component images on read
2987
2988Syntax: `-mcs`
2989
2990Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a multi-component image is encountered, the components are combined into a single image. Setting the **-mcs** flag changes this behavior, and each of the components is loaded sequentially. See the section below on multi-component image support. 
2991
2992    $ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor
2993    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1
2994    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66
2995    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29
2996
2997    $ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor
2998    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198
2999    """
3000    multicomponent_split: str
3001    """-mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of multi-component images
3002    on read
3003    
3004    Syntax: `-mcs`
3005    
3006    Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a multi-component
3007    image is encountered, the components are combined into a single image.
3008    Setting the **-mcs** flag changes this behavior, and each of the components
3009    is loaded sequentially. See the section below on multi-component image
3010    support.
3011    
3012    $ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor
3013    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1
3014    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66
3015    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29
3016    
3017    $ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor
3018    Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198"""
3019    
3020    def run(
3021        self,
3022        execution: Execution,
3023    ) -> list[str]:
3024        """
3025        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3026        
3027        Args:
3028            self: The sub-command object.
3029            execution: The execution object.
3030        Returns:
3031            
3032        """
3033        cargs = []
3034        cargs.extend(["-mcs", self.multicomponent_split])
3035        return cargs

-mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of multi-component images on read

Syntax: -mcs

Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a multi-component image is encountered, the components are combined into a single image. Setting the -mcs flag changes this behavior, and each of the components is loaded sequentially. See the section below on multi-component image support. 

$ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor
Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1
Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66
Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29

$ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor
Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198
C3dMulticomponentSplit(multicomponent_split: str)
multicomponent_split: str

-mcs, -multicomponent-split: Enable splitting of multi-component images on read

Syntax: -mcs

Enable reading of multi-component images. By default, when a multi-component image is encountered, the components are combined into a single image. Setting the -mcs flag changes this behavior, and each of the components is loaded sequentially. See the section below on multi-component image support.

$ c3d -mcs rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 1 Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 66 Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 29

$ c3d rgb.mha -foreach -probe 110x110x80mm -endfor Interpolated image value at 110 110 80 is 49.5198

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dMultiply: 
3419@dataclasses.dataclass
3420class C3dMultiply:
3421    """
3422    -multiply, -times: Multiply two images
3423
3424Syntax: `-multiply`
3425
3426Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the last two images on the stack. 
3427
3428    # Compute x = a * b
3429    c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img
3430
3431    # Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply
3432    c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img
3433
3434Combine with the **-dup** command to compute voxelwise square of the image
3435
3436    # Compute x = a^2
3437    c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img
3438    """
3439    multiply: str
3440    """-multiply, -times: Multiply two images
3441    
3442    Syntax: `-multiply`
3443    
3444    Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the last two
3445    images on the stack.
3446    
3447    # Compute x = a * b
3448    c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img
3449    
3450    # Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply
3451    c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img
3452    
3453    Combine with the **-dup** command to compute voxelwise square of the image
3454    
3455    # Compute x = a^2
3456    c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img"""
3457    
3458    def run(
3459        self,
3460        execution: Execution,
3461    ) -> list[str]:
3462        """
3463        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3464        
3465        Args:
3466            self: The sub-command object.
3467            execution: The execution object.
3468        Returns:
3469            
3470        """
3471        cargs = []
3472        cargs.extend(["-multiply", self.multiply])
3473        return cargs

-multiply, -times: Multiply two images

Syntax: -multiply

Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the last two images on the stack. 

# Compute x = a * b
c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img

# Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply
c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img

Combine with the -dup command to compute voxelwise square of the image

# Compute x = a^2
c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img
C3dMultiply(multiply: str)
multiply: str

-multiply, -times: Multiply two images

Syntax: -multiply

Multiply two images voxel-by-voxel. The operation is applied to the last two images on the stack.

Compute x = a * b

c3d a.img b.img -multiply -o x.img

Compute x = a * (b + c) using add and -multiply

c3d a.img b.img c.img -multiply -add -o x.img

Combine with the -dup command to compute voxelwise square of the image

Compute x = a^2

c3d a.img -dup -multiply -o x.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
3458    def run(
3459        self,
3460        execution: Execution,
3461    ) -> list[str]:

3467            execution: The execution object.
3468        Returns:
3469            
3470        """
3471        cargs = []
3472        cargs.extend(["-multiply", self.multiply])
3473        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dN4BiasCorrection: 
417@dataclasses.dataclass
418class C3dN4BiasCorrection:
419    """
420    -biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction
421
422Syntax: `-biascorr`
423
424Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This feature uses the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4], based on the N3 algorithm by Sled et al. 
425
426    c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz
427    """
428    n4_bias_correction: str
429    """-biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction
430    
431    Syntax: `-biascorr`
432    
433    Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This feature uses
434    the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4], based on the N3 algorithm
435    by Sled et al.
436    
437    c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz"""
438    
439    def run(
440        self,
441        execution: Execution,
442    ) -> list[str]:
443        """

445        
446        Args:
447            self: The sub-command object.
448            execution: The execution object.
449        Returns:
450            
451        """
452        cargs = []
453        cargs.extend(["-biascorr", self.n4_bias_correction])
454        return cargs

-biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction

Syntax: -biascorr

Performs automatic bias field correction for MRI images. This feature uses the [N3 implementation in ITK by Dr. Tustison][4], based on the N3 algorithm by Sled et al. 

c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz
C3dN4BiasCorrection(n4_bias_correction: str)
n4_bias_correction: str

-biascorr: Automatic MRI bias field correction

c3d mri.nii.gz -biascorr -o mricorr.nii.gz

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dNoCompress: 
896@dataclasses.dataclass
897class C3dNoCompress:
898    """
899    -compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
900
901Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
902
903Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
904
905    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
906    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha
907    """
908    no_compress: str
909    """-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files
910    
911    Syntax: `-compress` or `-no-compress`
912    
913    Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file
914    formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the
915    filename includes the **.gz** extension. For other formats, like MetaImage,
916    you need to specify **-compress** to enable compression. The following two
917    commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:
918    
919    c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
920    c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha"""
921    
922    def run(
923        self,
924        execution: Execution,
925    ) -> list[str]:
926        """
927        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
928        
929        Args:
930            self: The sub-command object.
931            execution: The execution object.
932        Returns:
933            
934        """
935        cargs = []
936        cargs.extend(["-no-compress", self.no_compress])
937        return cargs

-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files

Syntax: -compress or -no-compress

Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the .gz extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify -compress to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:

c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz
c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha
C3dNoCompress(no_compress: str)
no_compress: str

-compress, -no-compress: Enable/disable compression for some image files

Syntax: -compress or -no-compress

Turns on compressing for image file formats that support it. For some file formats, like NIFTI (.nii), compression is enabled automatically when the filename includes the .gz extension. For other formats, like MetaImage, you need to specify -compress to enable compression. The following two commands save the image as compressed NIFTI and MetaImage files:

c3d input.nii -o output.nii.gz c3d input.nii -compress -o output.mha

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
922    def run(
923        self,
924        execution: Execution,
925    ) -> list[str]:
926        """
927        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
928        
929        Args:
930            self: The sub-command object.
931            execution: The execution object.
932        Returns:
933            
934        """
935        cargs = []
936        cargs.extend(["-no-compress", self.no_compress])
937        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dNormalizeLocalWindow: 
3770@dataclasses.dataclass
3771class C3dNormalizeLocalWindow:
3772    """
3773    -nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize image intensity using local neighborhood
3774
3775Syntax: `-nlw <radius>`
3776
3777This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each voxel, the mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the result is divided by the standard deviation of the neighborhood. The mean and standard deviation are computed only over the masked region. You might also want to multiply by the mask.
3778
3779    c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz
3780    """
3781    normalize_local_window: str
3782    """-nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize image intensity using local
3783    neighborhood
3784    
3785    Syntax: `-nlw <radius>`
3786    
3787    This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each voxel, the
3788    mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the result is divided by
3789    the standard deviation of the neighborhood. The mean and standard deviation
3790    are computed only over the masked region. You might also want to multiply by
3791    the mask.
3792    
3793    c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz"""
3794    
3795    def run(
3796        self,
3797        execution: Execution,
3798    ) -> list[str]:
3799        """
3800        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3801        
3802        Args:
3803            self: The sub-command object.
3804            execution: The execution object.
3805        Returns:
3806            
3807        """
3808        cargs = []
3809        cargs.extend(["-nlw", self.normalize_local_window])
3810        return cargs

-nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize image intensity using local neighborhood

Syntax: -nlw <radius>

This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each voxel, the mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the result is divided by the standard deviation of the neighborhood. The mean and standard deviation are computed only over the masked region. You might also want to multiply by the mask.

c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz
C3dNormalizeLocalWindow(normalize_local_window: str)
normalize_local_window: str

-nlw, -normalize-local-window: Standardize image intensity using local neighborhood

Syntax: -nlw <radius>

This command takes as inputs an image and a mask image. At each voxel, the mean of the local neighborhood is subtracted, and the result is divided by the standard deviation of the neighborhood. The mean and standard deviation are computed only over the masked region. You might also want to multiply by the mask.

c3d gray.nii.gz mask.nii.gz -nlw 10x10x10 -o residual.nii.gz

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelation: 
3476@dataclasses.dataclass
3477class C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelation:
3478    """
3479    -ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation: Compute normalized cross-correlation image
3480
3481Syntax: `-ncc <radius_vector>`
3482
3483Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that occupy the same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image is the cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the voxel in the two input images. This is different from **-ncor**, which computes a global cross-correlation metric value.
3484    """
3485    normalized_cross_correlation: str
3486    """-ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation: Compute normalized cross-correlation
3487    image
3488    
3489    Syntax: `-ncc <radius_vector>`
3490    
3491    Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that occupy the
3492    same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image is the
3493    cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the voxel in the
3494    two input images. This is different from **-ncor**, which computes a global
3495    cross-correlation metric value."""
3496    
3497    def run(
3498        self,
3499        execution: Execution,
3500    ) -> list[str]:
3501        """
3502        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3503        
3504        Args:
3505            self: The sub-command object.
3506            execution: The execution object.
3507        Returns:
3508            
3509        """
3510        cargs = []
3511        cargs.extend(["-ncc", self.normalized_cross_correlation])
3512        return cargs

-ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation: Compute normalized cross-correlation image

Syntax: -ncc <radius_vector>

Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that occupy the same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image is the cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the voxel in the two input images. This is different from -ncor, which computes a global cross-correlation metric value.

C3dNormalizedCrossCorrelation(normalized_cross_correlation: str)
normalized_cross_correlation: str

-ncc, -normalized-cross-correlation: Compute normalized cross-correlation image

Syntax: -ncc <radius_vector>

Computes normalized cross-correlation between two images that occupy the same physical space. Each voxel in the resulting image is the cross-correlation of patches of given radius surrounding the voxel in the two input images. This is different from -ncor, which computes a global cross-correlation metric value.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dNoround: 
3839@dataclasses.dataclass
3840class C3dNoround:
3841    """
3842    -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior
3843
3844Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `
3845
3846By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. 
3847
3848    c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img
3849    """
3850    noround: str
3851    """-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior
3852    
3853    Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `
3854    
3855    By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when converting
3856    to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding
3857    should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from
3858    the internal floating point representation.
3859    
3860    c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img"""
3861    
3862    def run(
3863        self,
3864        execution: Execution,
3865    ) -> list[str]:
3866        """
3867        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3868        
3869        Args:
3870            self: The sub-command object.
3871            execution: The execution object.
3872        Returns:
3873            
3874        """
3875        cargs = []
3876        cargs.extend(["-noround", self.noround])
3877        return cargs

-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior

Syntax: -noround or -round

By default, convert3d will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. 

c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img
C3dNoround(noround: str)
noround: str

-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior

Syntax: -noround or -round

By default, convert3d will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation.

c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dNospm: 
3880@dataclasses.dataclass
3881class C3dNospm:
3882    """
3883    -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output
3884
3885Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `
3886
3887These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.
3888
3889    c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz
3890    """
3891    nospm: str
3892    """-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output
3893    
3894    Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `
3895    
3896    These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze
3897    (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM
3898    in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze
3899    files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the
3900    **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and
3901    SPM5 or later.
3902    
3903    c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz"""
3904    
3905    def run(
3906        self,
3907        execution: Execution,
3908    ) -> list[str]:
3909        """
3910        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3911        
3912        Args:
3913            self: The sub-command object.
3914            execution: The execution object.
3915        Returns:
3916            
3917        """
3918        cargs = []
3919        cargs.extend(["-nospm", self.nospm])
3920        return cargs

-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output

Syntax: -spm or -nospm

These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the -nospm option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.

c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz
C3dNospm(nospm: str)
nospm: str

-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output

Syntax: -spm or -nospm

These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the -nospm option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.

c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOrient: 
4084@dataclasses.dataclass
4085class C3dOrient:
4086    """
4087    -orient: Change image orientation
4088
4089Syntax: `-orient CODE`
4090
4091Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior. 
4092
4093The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior. 
4094
4095    c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img
4096    c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img
4097
4098This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.
4099    """
4100    orient: str
4101    """-orient: Change image orientation
4102    
4103    Syntax: `-orient CODE`
4104    
4105    Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The
4106    orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k)
4107    to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i
4108    runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along
4109    slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of
4110    the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y
4111    from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior.
4112    
4113    The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each
4114    letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel
4115    coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to
4116    Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.
4117    
4118    c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img
4119    c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img
4120    
4121    This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in
4122    ITK-SNAP."""
4123    
4124    def run(
4125        self,
4126        execution: Execution,
4127    ) -> list[str]:
4128        """
4129        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4130        
4131        Args:
4132            self: The sub-command object.
4133            execution: The execution object.
4134        Returns:
4135            
4136        """
4137        cargs = []
4138        cargs.extend(["-orient", self.orient])
4139        return cargs

-orient: Change image orientation

Syntax: -orient CODE

Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior.

The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior. 

c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img
c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img

This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.

C3dOrient(orient: str)
orient: str

-orient: Change image orientation

Syntax: -orient CODE

Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior.

The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.

c3d input.img -orient RAI -o output.img c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img

This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

4125        self,
4126        execution: Execution,
4127    ) -> list[str]:

4133            execution: The execution object.
4134        Returns:
4135            
4136        """
4137        cargs = []
4138        cargs.extend(["-orient", self.orient])
4139        return cargs

4210Syntax: `-orient CODE`
4211
4212Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior. 
4213
4214The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior. 
4215

4217    c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img
4218
4219This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.
4220    """

4222    """-orient: Change image orientation
4223    
4224    Syntax: `-orient CODE`
4225    
4226    Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The
4227    orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k)
4228    to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i
4229    runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along
4230    slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of
4231    the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y
4232    from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior.
4233

4235    letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel

-orient: Change image orientation

Syntax: -orient CODE

Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior.

The CODE passed in is a three-letter code consisting of letters RLAPSI. Each letter describes the anatomical direction corresponding to the voxel coordinates (i,j,k). For example, code RAI means that i runs from Right to Left, j from Anterior to Posterior, and k from Inferior to Superior.

c3d input.img -orient SAL -o output.img

This command has the same behavior as the 'Reorient Image' menu option in ITK-SNAP.

Syntax: -orient CODE

Set the orientation of the image using one of 48 canonical orientations. The orientation describes the mapping from the voxel coordinate system (i,j,k) to the physical coordinate system (x,y,z). In the voxel coordinate system, i runs along columns of voxels, j runs along rows of voxels, and k runs along slices of voxels. It is assumed (by the NIFTI convention) that the axes of the physical coordinate system run as follows: x from (L)eft to (R)ight, y from (P)osterior to (A)nterior, z from (I)nferior to (S)uperior.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOrigin: 
4263@dataclasses.dataclass
4264class C3dOrigin:
4265    """
4266    -origin: Set image origin
4267
4268Syntax: `-origin vector `
4269
4270Set the origin of the image. The origin is the world coordinate (in NIfTI coordinate space) of the center of the voxel (0,0,0) in the image. The origin should be specified in millimeters. 
4271
4272    c3d input.img -origin 100x100x100mm -o output.img
4273    """
4274    origin: str
4275    """-origin: Set image origin
4276    
4277    Syntax: `-origin vector `
4278    
4279    Set the origin of the image. The origin is the world coordinate (in NIfTI
4280    coordinate space) of the center of the voxel (0,0,0) in the image. The
4281    origin should be specified in millimeters.
4282    
4283    c3d input.img -origin 100x100x100mm -o output.img"""
4284    
4285    def run(
4286        self,
4287        execution: Execution,
4288    ) -> list[str]:
4289        """
4290        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4291        
4292        Args:
4293            self: The sub-command object.
4294            execution: The execution object.
4295        Returns:
4296            
4297        """
4298        cargs = []
4299        cargs.extend(["-origin", self.origin])
4300        return cargs

-origin: Set image origin

Syntax: -origin vector

Set the origin of the image. The origin is the world coordinate (in NIfTI coordinate space) of the center of the voxel (0,0,0) in the image. The origin should be specified in millimeters. 

c3d input.img -origin 100x100x100mm -o output.img
C3dOrigin(origin: str)
origin: str

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOriginVoxel: 
4303@dataclasses.dataclass
4304class C3dOriginVoxel:
4305    """
4306    -origin-voxel: Assign image origin to a voxel
4307
4308Syntax: `-origin-voxel vector `
4309
4310Set the origin of the image by specifying the voxel coordinates of the center of the patient (RAS) coordinate system. The vector should be specified in voxel units. 
4311
4312    c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img
4313    c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img        # image centered around origin
4314    """
4315    origin_voxel: str
4316    """-origin-voxel: Assign image origin to a voxel
4317    
4318    Syntax: `-origin-voxel vector `
4319    
4320    Set the origin of the image by specifying the voxel coordinates of the
4321    center of the patient (RAS) coordinate system. The vector should be
4322    specified in voxel units.
4323    
4324    c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img
4325    c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img # image centered around
4326    origin"""
4327    
4328    def run(
4329        self,
4330        execution: Execution,
4331    ) -> list[str]:
4332        """
4333        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4334        
4335        Args:
4336            self: The sub-command object.
4337            execution: The execution object.
4338        Returns:
4339            
4340        """
4341        cargs = []
4342        cargs.extend(["-origin-voxel", self.origin_voxel])
4343        return cargs

-origin-voxel: Assign image origin to a voxel

Syntax: -origin-voxel vector

Set the origin of the image by specifying the voxel coordinates of the center of the patient (RAS) coordinate system. The vector should be specified in voxel units. 

c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img
c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img        # image centered around origin
C3dOriginVoxel(origin_voxel: str)
origin_voxel: str

c3d input.img -origin-voxel 60x70x35 -o output.img c3d input.img -origin-voxel 50% -o output.img # image centered around origin

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOriginVoxelCoord: 
4346@dataclasses.dataclass
4347class C3dOriginVoxelCoord:
4348    """
4349    -origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified voxel
4350
4351Syntax: `-origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector>`
4352
4353This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed voxel has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the command to set the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of the center voxel of the image, as follows:
4354
4355    c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii
4356    """
4357    origin_voxel_coord: str
4358    """-origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified voxel
4359    
4360    Syntax: `-origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector>`
4361    
4362    This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed voxel
4363    has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the command to set
4364    the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of the center voxel of the
4365    image, as follows:
4366    
4367    c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii"""
4368    
4369    def run(
4370        self,
4371        execution: Execution,
4372    ) -> list[str]:
4373        """
4374        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4375        
4376        Args:
4377            self: The sub-command object.
4378            execution: The execution object.
4379        Returns:
4380            
4381        """
4382        cargs = []
4383        cargs.extend(["-origin-voxel-coord", self.origin_voxel_coord])
4384        return cargs

-origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified voxel

Syntax: -origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector>

This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed voxel has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the command to set the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of the center voxel of the image, as follows:

c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii
C3dOriginVoxelCoord(origin_voxel_coord: str)
origin_voxel_coord: str

-origin-voxel-coord: Set coordinate of specified voxel

Syntax: -origin-voxel-coord: <index> <vector>

This command updates the origin of the image such that the specifed voxel has the specified coordinate. For example, you can use the command to set the world coordinate (in NIFTI coordinate space) of the center voxel of the image, as follows:

c3d input.nii -origin-voxel-coord: 50% 10x10x5mm -o output.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOutput: 
3923@dataclasses.dataclass
3924class C3dOutput:
3925    """
3926    -o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file    
3927
3928Syntax: `-o filename`
3929
3930Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the **-o** option, **convert3d** will write an image only if it does not exist. The **-o** options protects input images from being accidentally deleted. Here we copy an image, changing format:
3931
3932    c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii
3933
3934The **-o** option can also be used to save an intermediate image in the stack: 
3935
3936    c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o final.img
3937    """
3938    output_: str
3939    """-o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file
3940    
3941    Syntax: `-o filename`
3942    
3943    Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the **-o** option,
3944    **convert3d** will write an image only if it does not exist. The **-o**
3945    options protects input images from being accidentally deleted. Here we copy
3946    an image, changing format:
3947    
3948    c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii
3949    
3950    The **-o** option can also be used to save an intermediate image in the
3951    stack:
3952    
3953    c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o
3954    final.img"""
3955    
3956    def run(
3957        self,
3958        execution: Execution,
3959    ) -> list[str]:
3960        """
3961        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
3962        
3963        Args:
3964            self: The sub-command object.
3965            execution: The execution object.
3966        Returns:
3967            
3968        """
3969        cargs = []
3970        cargs.extend(["-o", self.output_])
3971        return cargs

-o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file

Syntax: -o filename

Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the -o option, convert3d will write an image only if it does not exist. The -o options protects input images from being accidentally deleted. Here we copy an image, changing format:

c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii

The -o option can also be used to save an intermediate image in the stack: 

c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o final.img
C3dOutput(output_: str)
output_: str

-o: Output (write) last image on the stack to image file

Syntax: -o filename

Write image, overriding an existing image. Without the -o option, convert3d will write an image only if it does not exist. The -o options protects input images from being accidentally deleted. Here we copy an image, changing format:

c3d image1.mha -o image2.nii

The -o option can also be used to save an intermediate image in the stack:

c3d image1.img -threshold 1 10 1 0 -o thresh.img -resample 50% -o final.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOutputMulticomponent: 
3974@dataclasses.dataclass
3975class C3dOutputMulticomponent:
3976    """
3977    -omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple images to single file
3978
3979Syntax: `-omc [number] filename`
3980
3981Write multiple images on the **Convert3d** stack as a single multi-component image file. If the optional number *n* is specified, only the last *n* images on the stack will be used. Not all file formats support multi-component output. NIFTI is the safest bet.
3982
3983    c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha
3984
3985For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG files:
3986
3987    c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
3988    """
3989    output_multicomponent: str
3990    """-omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple images to single file
3991    
3992    Syntax: `-omc [number] filename`
3993    
3994    Write multiple images on the **Convert3d** stack as a single multi-component
3995    image file. If the optional number *n* is specified, only the last *n*
3996    images on the stack will be used. Not all file formats support
3997    multi-component output. NIFTI is the safest bet.
3998    
3999    c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha
4000    
4001    For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG files:
4002    
4003    c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png"""
4004    
4005    def run(
4006        self,
4007        execution: Execution,
4008    ) -> list[str]:
4009        """
4010        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4011        
4012        Args:
4013            self: The sub-command object.
4014            execution: The execution object.
4015        Returns:
4016            
4017        """
4018        cargs = []
4019        cargs.extend(["-omc", self.output_multicomponent])
4020        return cargs

-omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple images to single file

Syntax: -omc [number] filename

Write multiple images on the Convert3d stack as a single multi-component image file. If the optional number n is specified, only the last n images on the stack will be used. Not all file formats support multi-component output. NIFTI is the safest bet.

c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha

For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG files:

c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png
C3dOutputMulticomponent(output_multicomponent: str)
output_multicomponent: str

-omc, -output-multicomponent: Output multiple images to single file

Syntax: -omc [number] filename

Write multiple images on the Convert3d stack as a single multi-component image file. If the optional number n is specified, only the last n images on the stack will be used. Not all file formats support multi-component output. NIFTI is the safest bet.

c3d red.nii green.nii blue.nii -omc rgb.mha

For 2D images, this command can be used to generate color PNG files:

c3d image.nii -slice z 50% -colormap jet -type uchar -omc colorslice.png

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOutputMultiple: 
4142@dataclasses.dataclass
4143class C3dOutputMultiple:
4144    """
4145    -oo: Output multiple images to multiple files 
4146
4147Syntax: `-oo image_list` or `-oo image_spec`
4148
4149Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple files. There are two ways to use this command. The first is to supply a list of file names, separated by spaces: 
4150
4151    c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii
4152
4153In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be saved as *labelC.nii*, the image next to the end of the stack will be saved as *labelB.nii* and so on. 
4154
4155The second way to use the **-oo** command is to supply a pattern for the output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack will be written. The format for the pattern is the same as for the [C++ printf command][8]. For example, the following command 
4156
4157    c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii
4158
4159will generate images *label00.nii*, *label01.nii*, *label02.nii* and so on. The image at the end of the stack will have the highest number, and the image at the beginning of the stack will have number 00.
4160    """
4161    output_multiple: str
4162    """-oo: Output multiple images to multiple files
4163    
4164    Syntax: `-oo image_list` or `-oo image_spec`
4165    
4166    Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple files. There are two
4167    ways to use this command. The first is to supply a list of file names,
4168    separated by spaces:
4169    
4170    c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii
4171    
4172    In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be saved as
4173    *labelC.nii*, the image next to the end of the stack will be saved as
4174    *labelB.nii* and so on.
4175    
4176    The second way to use the **-oo** command is to supply a pattern for the
4177    output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack will be written.
4178    The format for the pattern is the same as for the [C++ printf command][8].
4179    For example, the following command
4180    
4181    c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii
4182    
4183    will generate images *label00.nii*, *label01.nii*, *label02.nii* and so on.
4184    The image at the end of the stack will have the highest number, and the
4185    image at the beginning of the stack will have number 00."""
4186    
4187    def run(
4188        self,
4189        execution: Execution,
4190    ) -> list[str]:
4191        """
4192        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4193        
4194        Args:
4195            self: The sub-command object.
4196            execution: The execution object.
4197        Returns:
4198            
4199        """
4200        cargs = []
4201        cargs.extend(["-oo", self.output_multiple])
4202        return cargs

-oo: Output multiple images to multiple files

Syntax: -oo image_list or -oo image_spec

Write all images on the convert3d stack as multiple files. There are two ways to use this command. The first is to supply a list of file names, separated by spaces: 

c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii

In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be saved as labelC.nii, the image next to the end of the stack will be saved as labelB.nii and so on.

The second way to use the -oo command is to supply a pattern for the output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack will be written. The format for the pattern is the same as for the [C++ printf command][8]. For example, the following command 

c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii

will generate images label00.nii, label01.nii, label02.nii and so on. The image at the end of the stack will have the highest number, and the image at the beginning of the stack will have number 00.

C3dOutputMultiple(output_multiple: str)
output_multiple: str

-oo: Output multiple images to multiple files

Syntax: -oo image_list or -oo image_spec

Write all images on the convert3d stack as multiple files. There are two ways to use this command. The first is to supply a list of file names, separated by spaces:

c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo labelA.nii labelB.nii labelC.nii

In the above example, the image at the end of the stack will be saved as labelC.nii, the image next to the end of the stack will be saved as labelB.nii and so on.

The second way to use the -oo command is to supply a pattern for the output filenames. In this case, all the images on the stack will be written. The format for the pattern is the same as for the [C++ printf command][8]. For example, the following command

c3d labelimage.nii -split -oo label%02d.nii

will generate images label00.nii, label01.nii, label02.nii and so on. The image at the end of the stack will have the highest number, and the image at the beginning of the stack will have number 00.

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
4187    def run(
4188        self,
4189        execution: Execution,
4190    ) -> list[str]:
4191        """
4192        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4193        
4194        Args:
4195            self: The sub-command object.
4196            execution: The execution object.
4197        Returns:
4198            
4199        """
4200        cargs = []
4201        cargs.extend(["-oo", self.output_multiple])
4202        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponent: 
4023@dataclasses.dataclass
4024class C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponent:
4025    """
4026    -oomc: Output multiple multi-component images to multiple files
4027
4028Syntax: `-oomc n_comp image_list` or `-oomc n_comp image_spec`
4029
4030Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple multi-component image files. The command is a mixture of the **-omc** and **-oo** commands. There must be a multiple of 'n_comp' images on the stack. Every consecutive 'n_comp' images on the stack will be written to a separate multi-component image.
4031
4032### Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control
4033
4034These commands are used to manipulate the **convert3d** stack. The stack is a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified on the command line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the stack. Most operations take one image from the end of the stack, apply some operation to it, and place the result on the end of the stack. Certain commands like **-levelset** and **-reslice-matrix** take two images from the end of the stack as the input and replace them with a single output. Some other commands, like **-mean** and **-vote** take all images on the stack and replace them with a single output. 
4035
4036Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order of the images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the same command multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow control commands allow you to complete complex tasks without saving intermediate images to the disk.
4037    """
4038    output_multiple_multicomponent: str
4039    """-oomc: Output multiple multi-component images to multiple files
4040    
4041    Syntax: `-oomc n_comp image_list` or `-oomc n_comp image_spec`
4042    
4043    Write all images on the **convert3d** stack as multiple multi-component
4044    image files. The command is a mixture of the **-omc** and **-oo** commands.
4045    There must be a multiple of 'n_comp' images on the stack. Every consecutive
4046    'n_comp' images on the stack will be written to a separate multi-component
4047    image.
4048    
4049    ### Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control
4050    
4051    These commands are used to manipulate the **convert3d** stack. The stack is
4052    a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified on the command
4053    line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the stack. Most operations take
4054    one image from the end of the stack, apply some operation to it, and place
4055    the result on the end of the stack. Certain commands like **-levelset** and
4056    **-reslice-matrix** take two images from the end of the stack as the input
4057    and replace them with a single output. Some other commands, like **-mean**
4058    and **-vote** take all images on the stack and replace them with a single
4059    output.
4060    
4061    Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order of the
4062    images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the same command
4063    multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow control commands allow you
4064    to complete complex tasks without saving intermediate images to the disk."""
4065    
4066    def run(
4067        self,
4068        execution: Execution,
4069    ) -> list[str]:
4070        """
4071        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4072        
4073        Args:
4074            self: The sub-command object.
4075            execution: The execution object.
4076        Returns:
4077            
4078        """
4079        cargs = []
4080        cargs.extend(["-oomc", self.output_multiple_multicomponent])
4081        return cargs

-oomc: Output multiple multi-component images to multiple files

Syntax: -oomc n_comp image_list or -oomc n_comp image_spec

Write all images on the convert3d stack as multiple multi-component image files. The command is a mixture of the -omc and -oo commands. There must be a multiple of 'n_comp' images on the stack. Every consecutive 'n_comp' images on the stack will be written to a separate multi-component image.

Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control

These commands are used to manipulate the convert3d stack. The stack is a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified on the command line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the stack. Most operations take one image from the end of the stack, apply some operation to it, and place the result on the end of the stack. Certain commands like -levelset and -reslice-matrix take two images from the end of the stack as the input and replace them with a single output. Some other commands, like -mean and -vote take all images on the stack and replace them with a single output.

Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order of the images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the same command multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow control commands allow you to complete complex tasks without saving intermediate images to the disk.

C3dOutputMultipleMulticomponent(output_multiple_multicomponent: str)
output_multiple_multicomponent: str

-oomc: Output multiple multi-component images to multiple files

Syntax: -oomc n_comp image_list or -oomc n_comp image_spec

Write all images on the convert3d stack as multiple multi-component image files. The command is a mixture of the -omc and -oo commands. There must be a multiple of 'n_comp' images on the stack. Every consecutive 'n_comp' images on the stack will be written to a separate multi-component image.

Commands: Stack Manipulation and Flow Control

These commands are used to manipulate the convert3d stack. The stack is a linear array of images. Every time an image is specified on the command line, it is loaded and placed at the end of the stack. Most operations take one image from the end of the stack, apply some operation to it, and place the result on the end of the stack. Certain commands like -levelset and -reslice-matrix take two images from the end of the stack as the input and replace them with a single output. Some other commands, like -mean and -vote take all images on the stack and replace them with a single output.

Sometimes, for complex operations, it is useful to change the order of the images on the stack, to duplicate images, or to execute the same command multiple times. The stack manipulation and flow control commands allow you to complete complex tasks without saving intermediate images to the disk.

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
4066    def run(
4067        self,
4068        execution: Execution,
4069    ) -> list[str]:
4070        """
4071        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4072        
4073        Args:
4074            self: The sub-command object.
4075            execution: The execution object.
4076        Returns:
4077            
4078        """
4079        cargs = []
4080        cargs.extend(["-oomc", self.output_multiple_multicomponent])
4081        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

class C3dOutputs(typing.NamedTuple):

7743    """

Output object returned when calling c3d(...).

C3dOutputs(root: pathlib.Path)

Create new instance of C3dOutputs(root,)

root: pathlib.Path

Output root folder. This is the root folder for all outputs.

Inherited Members
builtins.tuple

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOverlap: 
4387@dataclasses.dataclass
4388class C3dOverlap:
4389    """
4390    -overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images    
4391
4392Syntax: `-overlap Z`
4393
4394Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on the stack. Overlap is computed for a given label **Z**, i.e., the number of voxels that are equal to **Z** in both images is computed and divided by either the average number of voxels equal to **Z** in both images (to get Dice coefficient) or by the size of the region where at least one of the images is equal to **Z** (Jaccard coefficient). 
4395
4396The command below computes overlap for label 255.
4397
4398    c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255
4399
4400The output of the command is in the following terse format, with the last two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients, respectively. 
4401
4402    OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459
4403
4404Use the flag **-verbose** to get full information.
4405
4406    Matching voxels in first image:  2383
4407    Matching voxels in second image: 2474
4408    Size of overlap region:          1807
4409    Dice similarity coefficient:     0.744081
4410    Intersection / ratio:            0.592459
4411
4412This command does not alter the stack.
4413    """
4414    overlap: str
4415    """-overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images
4416    
4417    Syntax: `-overlap Z`
4418    
4419    Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on the stack.
4420    Overlap is computed for a given label **Z**, i.e., the number of voxels that
4421    are equal to **Z** in both images is computed and divided by either the
4422    average number of voxels equal to **Z** in both images (to get Dice
4423    coefficient) or by the size of the region where at least one of the images
4424    is equal to **Z** (Jaccard coefficient).
4425    
4426    The command below computes overlap for label 255.
4427    
4428    c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255
4429    
4430    The output of the command is in the following terse format, with the last
4431    two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients, respectively.
4432    
4433    OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459
4434    
4435    Use the flag **-verbose** to get full information.
4436    
4437    Matching voxels in first image: 2383
4438    Matching voxels in second image: 2474
4439    Size of overlap region: 1807
4440    Dice similarity coefficient: 0.744081
4441    Intersection / ratio: 0.592459
4442    
4443    This command does not alter the stack."""
4444    
4445    def run(
4446        self,
4447        execution: Execution,
4448    ) -> list[str]:
4449        """
4450        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4451        
4452        Args:
4453            self: The sub-command object.
4454            execution: The execution object.
4455        Returns:
4456            
4457        """
4458        cargs = []
4459        cargs.extend(["-overlap", self.overlap])
4460        return cargs

-overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images

Syntax: -overlap Z

Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on the stack. Overlap is computed for a given label Z, i.e., the number of voxels that are equal to Z in both images is computed and divided by either the average number of voxels equal to Z in both images (to get Dice coefficient) or by the size of the region where at least one of the images is equal to Z (Jaccard coefficient).

The command below computes overlap for label 255.

c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255

The output of the command is in the following terse format, with the last two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients, respectively. 

OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459

Use the flag -verbose to get full information.

Matching voxels in first image:  2383
Matching voxels in second image: 2474
Size of overlap region:          1807
Dice similarity coefficient:     0.744081
Intersection / ratio:            0.592459

This command does not alter the stack.

C3dOverlap(overlap: str)
overlap: str

-overlap: Compute relative overlap between binary images

Syntax: -overlap Z

Compute relative overlap between labels in the last two images on the stack. Overlap is computed for a given label Z, i.e., the number of voxels that are equal to Z in both images is computed and divided by either the average number of voxels equal to Z in both images (to get Dice coefficient) or by the size of the region where at least one of the images is equal to Z (Jaccard coefficient).

The command below computes overlap for label 255.

c3d -verbose seg1.img seg2.img -overlap 255

The output of the command is in the following terse format, with the last two values giving Dice and Jaccard coefficients, respectively.

OVL: 1, 2383, 2474, 1807, 0.744081, 0.592459

Use the flag -verbose to get full information.

Matching voxels in first image: 2383 Matching voxels in second image: 2474 Size of overlap region: 1807 Dice similarity coefficient: 0.744081 Intersection / ratio: 0.592459

This command does not alter the stack.

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
4445    def run(
4446        self,
4447        execution: Execution,
4448    ) -> list[str]:
4449        """
4450        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4451        
4452        Args:
4453            self: The sub-command object.
4454            execution: The execution object.
4455        Returns:
4456            
4457        """
4458        cargs = []
4459        cargs.extend(["-overlap", self.overlap])
4460        return cargs
