  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dOverlayLabelImage: 
4463@dataclasses.dataclass
4464class C3dOverlayLabelImage:
4465    """
4466    -oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation image on grayscale image
4467
4468Syntax: `-oli lookup_table_file opacity`
4469
4470This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image with a set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue components of a color image. The resulting color image is an overlay of the labels over the grey image. The first parameter (*lookup\_table*) is a text file with entries in the format 
4471
4472    label_value red green blue alpha 
4473
4474Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values should be on the same order as the intensity of the grey image (typically 0-255). The text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and can be generated using the ITK-SNAP `Segmentation->Save Label Descriptions` command. The second parameter (*opacity*) is between 0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the overlay. The output of this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents segmentation data on top of grayscale images. 
4475
4476    c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli labels.txt 0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz
4477
4478Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the lookup table. It should not be used for images with a continuous intensity spectrum. 
4479
4480Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation result. We do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and segmentation images to an ROI around the object of interest; map intensity range of the grayscale image to 0-255; extract slices through the middle of the cropped images; overlay segmentation on the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file. 
4481
4482    c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 \\
4483        -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor \\
4484        -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png
4485    """
4486    overlay_label_image: str
4487    """-oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation image on grayscale image
4488    
4489    Syntax: `-oli lookup_table_file opacity`
4490    
4491    This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image with a
4492    set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue components of a
4493    color image. The resulting color image is an overlay of the labels over the
4494    grey image. The first parameter (*lookup\_table*) is a text file with
4495    entries in the format
4496    
4497    label_value red green blue alpha
4498    
4499    Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values should be
4500    on the same order as the intensity of the grey image (typically 0-255). The
4501    text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and can be generated using the
4502    ITK-SNAP `Segmentation->Save Label Descriptions` command. The second
4503    parameter (*opacity*) is between 0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the
4504    overlay. The output of this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents
4505    segmentation data on top of grayscale images.
4506    
4507    c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli labels.txt
4508    0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz
4509    
4510    Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the lookup table.
4511    It should not be used for images with a continuous intensity spectrum.
4512    
4513    Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation result. We
4514    do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and segmentation images to
4515    an ROI around the object of interest; map intensity range of the grayscale
4516    image to 0-255; extract slices through the middle of the cropped images;
4517    overlay segmentation on the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file.
4518    
4519    c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255
4520    -clip 0 255 \\
4521    -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor \\
4522    -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png"""
4523    
4524    def run(
4525        self,
4526        execution: Execution,
4527    ) -> list[str]:
4528        """
4529        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4530        
4531        Args:
4532            self: The sub-command object.
4533            execution: The execution object.
4534        Returns:
4535            
4536        """
4537        cargs = []
4538        cargs.extend(["-overlay-label-image", self.overlay_label_image])
4539        return cargs

-oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation image on grayscale image

Syntax: -oli lookup_table_file opacity

This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image with a set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue components of a color image. The resulting color image is an overlay of the labels over the grey image. The first parameter (lookup_table) is a text file with entries in the format 

label_value red green blue alpha

Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values should be on the same order as the intensity of the grey image (typically 0-255). The text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and can be generated using the ITK-SNAP Segmentation->Save Label Descriptions command. The second parameter (opacity) is between 0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the overlay. The output of this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents segmentation data on top of grayscale images. 

c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli labels.txt 0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz

Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the lookup table. It should not be used for images with a continuous intensity spectrum.

Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation result. We do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and segmentation images to an ROI around the object of interest; map intensity range of the grayscale image to 0-255; extract slices through the middle of the cropped images; overlay segmentation on the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file. 

c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 \
    -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor \
    -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png
C3dOverlayLabelImage(overlay_label_image: str)
overlay_label_image: str

-oli, -overlay-label-image: Overlay segmentation image on grayscale image

Syntax: -oli lookup_table_file opacity

This command takes a grayscale image and a label image (i.e. image with a set of discrete values) and produces red, green and blue components of a color image. The resulting color image is an overlay of the labels over the grey image. The first parameter (lookup_table) is a text file with entries in the format

label_value red green blue alpha

Alpha values must be between 0 and 1. Red, green and blue values should be on the same order as the intensity of the grey image (typically 0-255). The text file is compatible with ITK-SNAP and can be generated using the ITK-SNAP Segmentation->Save Label Descriptions command. The second parameter (opacity) is between 0 and 1 and sets the overall opacity of the overlay. The output of this command is similar to the way ITK-SNAP presents segmentation data on top of grayscale images.

c3d gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 seg.nii.gz -oli labels.txt 0.5 -omc rgb.nii.gz

Note: this command does not interpolate between entries in the lookup table. It should not be used for images with a continuous intensity spectrum.

Here is a more complex example, used to visualize a segmentation result. We do a few things in this command: trim grayscale and segmentation images to an ROI around the object of interest; map intensity range of the grayscale image to 0-255; extract slices through the middle of the cropped images; overlay segmentation on the grayscale image; and save as a color PNG file.

c3d seg.nii.gz -trim 20x20x0vox -as S gray.nii.gz -stretch 2% 98% 0 255 -clip 0 255 \ -reslice-identity -push S -foreach -slice z 50% -flip xy -endfor \ -oli labels.txt 0.5 -type uchar -omc ovl.png

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

4535

4538        cargs.extend(["-overlay-label-image", self.overlay_label_image])
4539        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dPad: 
4542@dataclasses.dataclass
4543class C3dPad:
4544    """
4545    -pad: Pad image with constant value
4546
4547Syntax: `-pad <padlower> <padupper> <value> `
4548
4549Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The *padlower* dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and the *padupper* dimension pads along the upper faces of the image. For example to add 1 voxel to the left side of an image, do 
4550
4551    c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii
4552
4553while 
4554
4555    c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii
4556
4557adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four slices to the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument changes the location of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the output image will be changed to maintain anatomical alignment between the padded and original images. 
4558
4559Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any constant value, eg : 
4560
4561    c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii
4562
4563Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with the value 1.
4564    """
4565    pad: str
4566    """-pad: Pad image with constant value
4567    
4568    Syntax: `-pad <padlower> <padupper> <value> `
4569    
4570    Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The *padlower*
4571    dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and the *padupper*
4572    dimension pads along the upper faces of the image. For example to add 1
4573    voxel to the left side of an image, do
4574    
4575    c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii
4576    
4577    while
4578    
4579    c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii
4580    
4581    adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four slices to
4582    the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument changes the location
4583    of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the output image will be changed to
4584    maintain anatomical alignment between the padded and original images.
4585    
4586    Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any constant
4587    value, eg :
4588    
4589    c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii
4590    
4591    Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with the value
4592    1."""
4593    
4594    def run(
4595        self,
4596        execution: Execution,
4597    ) -> list[str]:
4598        """
4599        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4600        
4601        Args:
4602            self: The sub-command object.
4603            execution: The execution object.
4604        Returns:
4605            
4606        """
4607        cargs = []
4608        cargs.extend(["-pad", self.pad])
4609        return cargs

-pad: Pad image with constant value

Syntax: -pad <padlower> <padupper> <value>

Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The padlower dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and the padupper dimension pads along the upper faces of the image. For example to add 1 voxel to the left side of an image, do 

c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii

while 

c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii

adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four slices to the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument changes the location of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the output image will be changed to maintain anatomical alignment between the padded and original images.

Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any constant value, eg : 

c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii

Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with the value 1.

C3dPad(pad: str)
pad: str

-pad: Pad image with constant value

Syntax: -pad <padlower> <padupper> <value>

Pads the image by a given percentage or number of voxels. The padlower dimension pads along the zero faces of the image, and the padupper dimension pads along the upper faces of the image. For example to add 1 voxel to the left side of an image, do

c3d img1.nii -pad 1x0x0vox 0x0x0vox 0 -o padded.nii

while

c3d img1.nii -pad 2x2x4vox 0% 0 -o padded.nii

adds two voxels padding to the left and posterior sides, and four slices to the bottom of the image. Note that the first argument changes the location of voxel (0,0,0) and thus the origin of the output image will be changed to maintain anatomical alignment between the padded and original images.

Normally you will want to pad with zeros, but you can pad with any constant value, eg :

c3d img1.nii -pad 10% 10% 1 -o padded.nii

Adds 10% to all sides of the image, and fills the new voxels with the value 1.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dPca: 
4638@dataclasses.dataclass
4639class C3dPca:
4640    """
4641    -pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels
4642
4643Syntax: `-pca`
4644
4645Similar to the *-centroid* command, computes the centroid and prinicipal components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For example if the image is a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will report the center and the principal axes of the ellipsoid, in physical NIFTI coordinates.
4646
4647    c3d binaryimage.img -pca                              // centroid of all non-0 voxels
4648    c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca               // centroid of all voxels with label 5
4649    c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor       // centroids of all labels (including 0)
4650    """
4651    pca: str
4652    """-pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels
4653    
4654    Syntax: `-pca`
4655    
4656    Similar to the *-centroid* command, computes the centroid and prinicipal
4657    components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For example if the image is
4658    a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will report the center and the
4659    principal axes of the ellipsoid, in physical NIFTI coordinates.
4660    
4661    c3d binaryimage.img -pca // centroid of all non-0 voxels
4662    c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca // centroid of all voxels with label
4663    5
4664    c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor // centroids of all labels
4665    (including 0)"""
4666    
4667    def run(
4668        self,
4669        execution: Execution,
4670    ) -> list[str]:
4671        """
4672        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4673        
4674        Args:
4675            self: The sub-command object.
4676            execution: The execution object.
4677        Returns:
4678            
4679        """
4680        cargs = []
4681        cargs.extend(["-pca", self.pca])
4682        return cargs

-pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels

Syntax: -pca

Similar to the -centroid command, computes the centroid and prinicipal components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For example if the image is a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will report the center and the principal axes of the ellipsoid, in physical NIFTI coordinates.

c3d binaryimage.img -pca                              // centroid of all non-0 voxels
c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca               // centroid of all voxels with label 5
c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor       // centroids of all labels (including 0)
C3dPca(pca: str)
pca: str

-pca: Principal components analysis of foreground voxels

Syntax: -pca

Similar to the -centroid command, computes the centroid and prinicipal components of the foregrond voxels in the image. For example if the image is a binary image of an ellipsoid, this will report the center and the principal axes of the ellipsoid, in physical NIFTI coordinates.

c3d binaryimage.img -pca // centroid of all non-0 voxels c3d labelimage.img -thresh 5 5 1 0 -pca // centroid of all voxels with label 5 c3d labelimage.img -split -foreach -pca -endfor // centroids of all labels (including 0)

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dPercentIntensityMode: 
4685@dataclasses.dataclass
4686class C3dPercentIntensityMode:
4687    """
4688    -pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of % specifier
4689
4690Syntax: `-pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r`
4691
4692This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when specifying intensity values. **Quantile (q)** means that `10%` describes the 10th percentile of all intensity values in the image (i.e., 10% of the voxels have lower intensity). **ForegroundQuantile (fq)** is similar, but voxels with background intensity (see **-background** option) are excluded from the percentile computation. **Range (r)** changes the meaning of percent sign from percentile to the range between the minimum and maximum of the image, and `0.1%` becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX - MIN). The default is **Quantile**. 
4693
4694    $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 
4695    Quantile 0.75 maps to 18
4696
4697    $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 
4698    Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58
4699
4700    $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 
4701    Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25
4702    """
4703    percent_intensity_mode: str
4704    """-pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of % specifier
4705    
4706    Syntax: `-pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r`
4707    
4708    This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when specifying
4709    intensity values. **Quantile (q)** means that `10%` describes the 10th
4710    percentile of all intensity values in the image (i.e., 10% of the voxels
4711    have lower intensity). **ForegroundQuantile (fq)** is similar, but voxels
4712    with background intensity (see **-background** option) are excluded from the
4713    percentile computation. **Range (r)** changes the meaning of percent sign
4714    from percentile to the range between the minimum and maximum of the image,
4715    and `0.1%` becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX - MIN). The default is
4716    **Quantile**.
4717    
4718    $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0
4719    Quantile 0.75 maps to 18
4720    
4721    $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose -threshold 75%
4722    inf 1 0
4723    Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58
4724    
4725    $ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0
4726    Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25"""
4727    
4728    def run(
4729        self,
4730        execution: Execution,
4731    ) -> list[str]:
4732        """
4733        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4734        
4735        Args:
4736            self: The sub-command object.
4737            execution: The execution object.
4738        Returns:
4739            
4740        """
4741        cargs = []
4742        cargs.extend(["-percent-intensity-mode", self.percent_intensity_mode])
4743        return cargs

-pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of % specifier

Syntax: -pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r

This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when specifying intensity values. Quantile (q) means that 10% describes the 10th percentile of all intensity values in the image (i.e., 10% of the voxels have lower intensity). ForegroundQuantile (fq) is similar, but voxels with background intensity (see -background option) are excluded from the percentile computation. Range (r) changes the meaning of percent sign from percentile to the range between the minimum and maximum of the image, and 0.1% becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX - MIN). The default is Quantile. 

$ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 
Quantile 0.75 maps to 18

$ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 
Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58

$ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 
Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25
C3dPercentIntensityMode(percent_intensity_mode: str)
percent_intensity_mode: str

-pim, -percent-intensity-mode: Set behavior of % specifier

Syntax: -pim Quantile | q | ForegroundQuantile | fq | Range | r

This options changes how the percent sign (%) is interpreted when specifying intensity values. Quantile (q) means that 10% describes the 10th percentile of all intensity values in the image (i.e., 10% of the voxels have lower intensity). ForegroundQuantile (fq) is similar, but voxels with background intensity (see -background option) are excluded from the percentile computation. Range (r) changes the meaning of percent sign from percentile to the range between the minimum and maximum of the image, and 0.1% becomes equal to MIN + 0.1 (MAX - MIN). The default is Quantile.

$ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Quantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 Quantile 0.75 maps to 18

$ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim ForegroundQuantile -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 Foreground quantile 0.75 (over 37467 voxels) maps to 58

$ c3d comp01.png -verbose -pim Range -verbose -threshold 75% inf 1 0 Intensity range spec 0.75 maps to 191.25

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
4728    def run(
4729        self,
4730        execution: Execution,
4731    ) -> list[str]:
4732        """
4733        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4734        
4735        Args:
4736            self: The sub-command object.
4737            execution: The execution object.
4738        Returns:
4739            
4740        """
4741        cargs = []
4742        cargs.extend(["-percent-intensity-mode", self.percent_intensity_mode])
4743        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

4851

4853    c3d img1.img -interpolation NearestNeighbor -probe 60x60x60mm
4854    c3d img1.img -probe 50%

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dPush: 
4886@dataclasses.dataclass
4887class C3dPush:
4888    """
4889    -push: Place variable at the end of the stack
4890
4891Syntax: `-push var`
4892
4893Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the image stack. Variable names are assigned using the **-as** command. The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: 
4894
4895    c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img
4896    """
4897    push: str
4898    """-push: Place variable at the end of the stack
4899    
4900    Syntax: `-push var`
4901    
4902    Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the image
4903    stack. Variable names are assigned using the **-as** command. The **-as**
4904    and **-push** commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more
4905    than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute
4906    the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values
4907    outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following
4908    command:
4909    
4910    c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img"""
4911    
4912    def run(
4913        self,
4914        execution: Execution,
4915    ) -> list[str]:
4916        """
4917        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4918        
4919        Args:
4920            self: The sub-command object.
4921            execution: The execution object.
4922        Returns:
4923            
4924        """
4925        cargs = []
4926        cargs.extend(["-push", self.push])
4927        return cargs

-push: Place variable at the end of the stack

Syntax: -push var

Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the image stack. Variable names are assigned using the -as command. The -as and -push commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: 

c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img
C3dPush(push: str)
push: str

-push: Place variable at the end of the stack

Syntax: -push var

Places the image associated with variable name 'var' on end of the image stack. Variable names are assigned using the -as command. The -as and -push commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command:

c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dRank: 
4930@dataclasses.dataclass
4931class C3dRank:
4932    """
4933    -rank: Voxelwise ranking of intensity values
4934
4935Syntax: `-rank `
4936
4937This command takes N images as the input (all the images on the stack are used). It also generates N images as the output. For voxel k in image j, it assigns it a label based on its rank among the values of voxel k in all N images. If the voxel has highest intensity in image j, then the j'th output will have value 1. 
4938
4939    c3d img1.img img2.img ... imgN.img -rank -oo rank%d.img
4940    """
4941    rank: str
4942    """-rank: Voxelwise ranking of intensity values
4943    
4944    Syntax: `-rank `
4945    
4946    This command takes N images as the input (all the images on the stack are
4947    used). It also generates N images as the output. For voxel k in image j, it
4948    assigns it a label based on its rank among the values of voxel k in all N
4949    images. If the voxel has highest intensity in image j, then the j'th output
4950    will have value 1.
4951    
4952    c3d img1.img img2.img ... imgN.img -rank -oo rank%d.img"""
4953    
4954    def run(
4955        self,
4956        execution: Execution,
4957    ) -> list[str]:
4958        """
4959        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
4960        
4961        Args:
4962            self: The sub-command object.
4963            execution: The execution object.
4964        Returns:
4965            
4966        """
4967        cargs = []
4968        cargs.extend(["-rank", self.rank])
4969        return cargs

-rank: Voxelwise ranking of intensity values

Syntax: -rank

This command takes N images as the input (all the images on the stack are used). It also generates N images as the output. For voxel k in image j, it assigns it a label based on its rank among the values of voxel k in all N images. If the voxel has highest intensity in image j, then the j'th output will have value 1. 

c3d img1.img img2.img ... imgN.img -rank -oo rank%d.img

rank: str

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dReorder: 
5053@dataclasses.dataclass
5054class C3dReorder:
5055    """
5056    -reorder: Rearrange images on the stack
5057
5058Syntax: `-reorder k` or `-reorder fraction`
5059
5060Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k positions apart become next to each other on the stack. In other words, if the original order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new order of the images becomes 1, 1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ..., k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be divisible by k. As an alternative to specifying k, you can specify a floating point number (i.e., **-reorder** 0.5), in which case k is obtained by multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the nearest integer. 
5061
5062The following three commands are equivalent:
5063
5064    c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 4 ...
5065    c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 0.5 ...
5066    c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ...
5067
5068The **-reorder** command us useful when you specify two sets of images using wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations on the images. For example 
5069
5070    c3d weight*.nii gray*.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii
5071
5072is equivalent to the command
5073
5074    c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ... -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii
5075    """
5076    reorder: str
5077    """-reorder: Rearrange images on the stack
5078    
5079    Syntax: `-reorder k` or `-reorder fraction`
5080    
5081    Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k positions apart
5082    become next to each other on the stack. In other words, if the original
5083    order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new order of the images becomes 1,
5084    1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ..., k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be
5085    divisible by k. As an alternative to specifying k, you can specify a
5086    floating point number (i.e., **-reorder** 0.5), in which case k is obtained
5087    by multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the nearest
5088    integer.
5089    
5090    The following three commands are equivalent:
5091    
5092    c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 4 ...
5093    c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 0.5 ...
5094    c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ...
5095    
5096    The **-reorder** command us useful when you specify two sets of images using
5097    wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations on the images. For
5098    example
5099    
5100    c3d weight*.nii gray*.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii
5101    
5102    is equivalent to the command
5103    
5104    c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ... -weighted-sum-voxelwise
5105    -o wsum.nii"""
5106    
5107    def run(
5108        self,
5109        execution: Execution,
5110    ) -> list[str]:
5111        """
5112        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5113        
5114        Args:
5115            self: The sub-command object.
5116            execution: The execution object.
5117        Returns:
5118            
5119        """
5120        cargs = []
5121        cargs.extend(["-reorder", self.reorder])
5122        return cargs

-reorder: Rearrange images on the stack

Syntax: -reorder k or -reorder fraction

Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k positions apart become next to each other on the stack. In other words, if the original order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new order of the images becomes 1, 1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ..., k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be divisible by k. As an alternative to specifying k, you can specify a floating point number (i.e., -reorder 0.5), in which case k is obtained by multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the nearest integer.

The following three commands are equivalent:

c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 4 ... c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 0.5 ... c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ...

The -reorder command us useful when you specify two sets of images using wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations on the images. For example 

c3d weight*.nii gray*.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii

is equivalent to the command

c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ... -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii
C3dReorder(reorder: str)
reorder: str

-reorder: Rearrange images on the stack

Syntax: -reorder k or -reorder fraction

Rearranges images in the stack, such that images that are k positions apart become next to each other on the stack. In other words, if the original order of the images is 1, 2, ..., n, the new order of the images becomes 1, 1+k, 1+2k, ..., 2, 2+k, 2+2k, ..., k, 2k, ... n. Of course, n must be divisible by k. As an alternative to specifying k, you can specify a floating point number (i.e., -reorder 0.5), in which case k is obtained by multiplying n by the floating point number and rounding to the nearest integer.

The following three commands are equivalent:

c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 4 ... c3d a1.nii a2.nii a3.nii a4.nii b1.nii b2.nii b3.nii b4.nii -reorder 0.5 ... c3d a1.nii b1.nii a2.nii b2.nii a3.nii b3.nii a4.nii b4.nii ...

The -reorder command us useful when you specify two sets of images using wildcards and then want to perform pairwise operations on the images. For example

c3d weight.nii gray.nii -reorder 0.5 -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii

is equivalent to the command

c3d weight1.nii gray1.nii weight2.nii gray2.nii ... -weighted-sum-voxelwise -o wsum.nii

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

5110    ) -> list[str]:

5117        Returns:
5118            
5119        """
5120        cargs = []
5121        cargs.extend(["-reorder", self.reorder])
5122        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dResample: 
5549@dataclasses.dataclass
5550class C3dResample:
5551    """
5552    -resample: Resample image to new dimensions
5553
5554Syntax: `-resample <dimensions> `
5555
5556Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but changing the number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be specified as a percentage, for example to double the number of voxels in each direction. The **-interpolation** flag affects how sampling is performed. 
5557
5558    c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img 
5559    c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img 
5560    c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img 
5561    c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img
5562    """
5563    resample: str
5564    """-resample: Resample image to new dimensions
5565    
5566    Syntax: `-resample <dimensions> `
5567    
5568    Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but changing the
5569    number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be specified as a
5570    percentage, for example to double the number of voxels in each direction.
5571    The **-interpolation** flag affects how sampling is performed.
5572    
5573    c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img
5574    c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img
5575    c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img
5576    c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o
5577    img2.img"""
5578    
5579    def run(
5580        self,
5581        execution: Execution,
5582    ) -> list[str]:
5583        """
5584        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5585        
5586        Args:
5587            self: The sub-command object.
5588            execution: The execution object.
5589        Returns:
5590            
5591        """
5592        cargs = []
5593        cargs.extend(["-resample", self.resample])
5594        return cargs

-resample: Resample image to new dimensions

Syntax: -resample <dimensions>

Resamples the image, keeping the bounding box the same, but changing the number of voxels in the image. The dimensions can be specified as a percentage, for example to double the number of voxels in each direction. The -interpolation flag affects how sampling is performed. 

c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img 
c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img 
c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img 
c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img
C3dResample(resample: str)
resample: str

-resample: Resample image to new dimensions

c3d img1.img -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img c3d img1.img -resample 200% -o img2.img c3d img1.img -resample 100x100x200% -o img2.img c3d img1.img -background 4.0 -interpolation Cubic -resample 123x142x200 -o img2.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dResampleIso: 
5597@dataclasses.dataclass
5598class C3dResampleIso:
5599    """
5600    -resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution
5601
5602Syntax: `-resample-iso <min|max>`
5603
5604Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls **-resample** with appropriately calculated new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic. 
5605
5606    c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img
5607    """
5608    resample_iso: str
5609    """-resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution
5610    
5611    Syntax: `-resample-iso <min|max>`
5612    
5613    Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based
5614    on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension
5615    ('max' mode). This command calls **-resample** with appropriately calculated
5616    new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is
5617    preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual
5618    voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic.
5619    
5620    c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img"""
5621    
5622    def run(
5623        self,
5624        execution: Execution,
5625    ) -> list[str]:
5626        """
5627        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5628        
5629        Args:
5630            self: The sub-command object.
5631            execution: The execution object.
5632        Returns:
5633            
5634        """
5635        cargs = []
5636        cargs.extend(["-resample-iso", self.resample_iso])
5637        return cargs

-resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution

Syntax: -resample-iso <min|max>

Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls -resample with appropriately calculated new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic. 

c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img
C3dResampleIso(resample_iso: str)
resample_iso: str

-resample-iso: Resample image to (approximately) isotropic resolution

Syntax: -resample-iso <min|max>

Resamples the image to have approximately isotropic resolution, either based on the smallest voxel dimension ('min' mode) or largest voxel dimension ('max' mode). This command calls -resample with appropriately calculated new image dimensions. The bounding box of the image in physical space is preserved. Therefore, since the image dimensions must be integer, the actual voxel dimensions after resampling may not be precisely isotropic.

c3d img1.img -resample-iso min -o img2.img

5641class C3dResampleMm:
5642    """
5643    -resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution
5644
5645Syntax: `-resample-mm <voxel_size> `
5646
5647Resamples the image as in **-resample**, but the user specifies the new voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so the bounding box of the image may change. A warning will be generated in that case. 
5648
5649    c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img
5650    """
5651    resample_mm: str
5652    """-resample-mm: Resample image to new resolution

5657    voxel size rather than dimensions. This may not be precise, so the bounding
5658    box of the image may change. A warning will be generated in that case.
5659    
5660    c3d img1.img -resample-mm 1.0x1.5x1.5mm -o img2.img"""
5661

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dResliceIdentity: 
5741@dataclasses.dataclass
5742class C3dResliceIdentity:
5743    """
5744    -reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform 
5745
5746Syntax: `-reslice-identity `
5747
5748Applies the **-reslice-matrix** command with the identity transform. This is useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1 
5749
5750    c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii
5751    """
5752    reslice_identity: str
5753    """-reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform
5754    
5755    Syntax: `-reslice-identity `
5756    
5757    Applies the **-reslice-matrix** command with the identity transform. This is
5758    useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate
5759    transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the
5760    space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in
5761    different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space
5762    of the T1
5763    
5764    c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii"""
5765    
5766    def run(
5767        self,
5768        execution: Execution,
5769    ) -> list[str]:

5775            execution: The execution object.
5776        Returns:
5777            
5778        """
5779        cargs = []
5780        cargs.extend(["-reslice-identity", self.reslice_identity])
5781        return cargs

-reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform

Syntax: -reslice-identity

Applies the -reslice-matrix command with the identity transform. This is useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1 

c3d t1.nii t2.nii -reslice-identity -o t2_in_t1_space.nii
C3dResliceIdentity(reslice_identity: str)

-reslice-identity: Resample image using identity transform

This is useful when you have two scans of the same subject with different coordinate transformations to patient space and you want to resample one scan in the space of another scan. For example, if you have T1 and T2 images in different coordinate frames, and want to reslice the T2 image into the space of the T1

5735        """
5736        cargs = []
5737        cargs.extend(["-reslice-matrix", self.reslice_matrix])
5738        return cargs

No description found.

5166class C3dRfApply:
5167    """
5168    -rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier 
5169
5170Syntax: `-rf-apply <classifier_file>`
5171
5172This command applies a classifier trained previously by **-rf-train**. The stack must contain the same number of feature images as when training. The images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See examples under **-rf-train** for usage.
5173    """
5174    rf_apply: str
5175    """-rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier
5176    
5177    Syntax: `-rf-apply <classifier_file>`
5178    
5179    This command applies a classifier trained previously by **-rf-train**. The
5180    stack must contain the same number of feature images as when training. The
5181    images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K
5182    probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See
5183    examples under **-rf-train** for usage."""
5184

5186        self,
5187        execution: Execution,
5188    ) -> list[str]:
5189        """

5192        Args:
5193            self: The sub-command object.
5194            execution: The execution object.
5195        Returns:
5196            
5197        """
5198        cargs = []
5199        cargs.extend(["-rf-apply", self.rf_apply])
5200        return cargs

-rf-apply: Apply Random Forest classifier

Syntax: -rf-apply <classifier_file>

This command applies a classifier trained previously by -rf-train. The stack must contain the same number of feature images as when training. The images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See examples under -rf-train for usage.

rf_apply: str

Syntax: -rf-apply <classifier_file>

The images will be removed from the stack and replaced with a set of K probability images, where K is the number of classes during training. See examples under -rf-train for usage.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dRfParamPatch: 
5298@dataclasses.dataclass
5299class C3dRfParamPatch:
5300    """
5301    -rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size
5302
5303Syntax: `-rf-param-patch <size_spec>`
5304
5305Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See **-rf-train** command for details.
5306
5307    # Set patch size to 5x5x5 
5308    c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf
5309    """
5310    rf_param_patch: str
5311    """-rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size
5312    
5313    Syntax: `-rf-param-patch <size_spec>`
5314    
5315    Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier.
5316    By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel
5317    is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in
5318    neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve
5319    classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each
5320    dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See **-rf-train** command for details.
5321    
5322    # Set patch size to 5x5x5
5323    c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf"""
5324    
5325    def run(
5326        self,
5327        execution: Execution,
5328    ) -> list[str]:
5329        """
5330        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5331        
5332        Args:
5333            self: The sub-command object.
5334            execution: The execution object.
5335        Returns:
5336            
5337        """
5338        cargs = []
5339        cargs.extend(["-rf-param-patch", self.rf_param_patch])
5340        return cargs

-rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size

Syntax: -rf-param-patch <size_spec>

Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See -rf-train command for details.

# Set patch size to 5x5x5 
c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf
C3dRfParamPatch(rf_param_patch: str)
rf_param_patch: str

-rf-param-patch: Random Forest training patch size

Syntax: -rf-param-patch <size_spec>

Set the radius of the patch used to generate features for the RF classifier. By default this is zero, which means that just the intensity of each voxel is used as a feature. Setting this to non-zero values will result in neighboring intensities also being used as features, and can improve classification in presence of complex image texture. The patch size in each dimension is (2 * radius + 1). See -rf-train command for details.

Set patch size to 5x5x5

c3d ... -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 ... -rf-train myforest.rf

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
5325    def run(
5326        self,
5327        execution: Execution,
5328    ) -> list[str]:

5332        Args:
5333            self: The sub-command object.
5334            execution: The execution object.
5335        Returns:
5336            
5337        """
5338        cargs = []
5339        cargs.extend(["-rf-param-patch", self.rf_param_patch])
5340        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dRfTrain: 
5203@dataclasses.dataclass
5204class C3dRfTrain:
5205    """
5206    -rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier
5207
5208Syntax: `-rf-train <classifier_file>`
5209
5210This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with label *L* are treated as the examples of class *L*. The classifier is output to a binary file that can later be used by the **-rf-apply** command. Multiple parameters can be specified with the **-rf-param-xxx** options before calling **-rf-train**. The stack is not modified by this command.
5211
5212    # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters
5213    c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf
5214
5215    # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)
5216    c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf
5217
5218    # Applying the classifier
5219    c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz
5220
5221The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:
5222
5223    # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects
5224    c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \
5225        seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \
5226        -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \
5227        -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf
5228
5229    # Apply using single MRI
5230    c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii
5231
5232 [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32.
5233 [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media
5234    """
5235    rf_train: str
5236    """-rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier
5237    
5238    Syntax: `-rf-train <classifier_file>`
5239    
5240    This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et
5241    al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by
5242    [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images
5243    of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The
5244    latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different
5245    classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels
5246    with label *L* are treated as the examples of class *L*. The classifier is
5247    output to a binary file that can later be used by the **-rf-apply** command.
5248    Multiple parameters can be specified with the **-rf-param-xxx** options
5249    before calling **-rf-train**. The stack is not modified by this command.
5250    
5251    # Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters
5252    c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf
5253    
5254    # Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)
5255    c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf
5256    
5257    # Applying the classifier
5258    c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz
5259    
5260    The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation
5261    mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire
5262    image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers
5263    jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as
5264    long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space
5265    and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:
5266    
5267    # Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects
5268    c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI \
5269    seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG \
5270    -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 \
5271    -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf
5272    
5273    # Apply using single MRI
5274    c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii
5275    
5276    [Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32.
5277    [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer
5278    vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media"""
5279    
5280    def run(
5281        self,
5282        execution: Execution,
5283    ) -> list[str]:
5284        """
5285        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5286        
5287        Args:
5288            self: The sub-command object.
5289            execution: The execution object.
5290        Returns:
5291            
5292        """
5293        cargs = []
5294        cargs.extend(["-rf-train", self.rf_train])
5295        return cargs

-rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier

Syntax: -rf-train <classifier_file>

This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with label L are treated as the examples of class L. The classifier is output to a binary file that can later be used by the -rf-apply command. Multiple parameters can be specified with the -rf-param-xxx options before calling -rf-train. The stack is not modified by this command.

# Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters
c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf

# Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)
c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf

# Applying the classifier
c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz

The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:

# Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects
c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI         seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG         -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0         -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf

# Apply using single MRI
c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii

[Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32. [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media

C3dRfTrain(rf_train: str)
rf_train: str

-rf-train: Train Random Forest classifier

Syntax: -rf-train <classifier_file>

This command trains a classifier using an implementation of the [Breyman et al. Random Forest Algorithm][Br2001], with modifications proposed by [Criminisi and Shotton][Cr2004]. The stack must contain one or more images of features (e.g., grayscale images), followed by a multi-label image. The latter must have at least two non-zero labels corresponding to different classes. The classifier is trained on a voxel by voxel basis. All voxels with label L are treated as the examples of class L. The classifier is output to a binary file that can later be used by the -rf-apply command. Multiple parameters can be specified with the -rf-param-xxx options before calling -rf-train. The stack is not modified by this command.

Training with two MRI modalities as features and default parameters

c3d t1_mri.nii t2_mri.nii segmentation.nii -rf-train myforest1.rf

Training with patches as features (see docs for -rf-param-patch)

c3d ultrasound.nii seg.nii -rf-param-patch 2x2x2 -rf-train myforest2.rf

Applying the classifier

c3d ultrasound.nii -rf-apply myforest2.rf -omc class_prob.nii.gz

The commands are meant to replicate the "classification" pre-segmentation mode in ITK-SNAP, i.e., extending a rough example segmentation to the entire image domain. It is possible to also use the commands to train classifiers jointly on data from multiple subjects, each with its own segmentation, as long as the images from the different subjects occupy the same image space and can be stacked into a 4-dimensional image. For example:

Train using MRI and segmentations from N subjects

c4d mri_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLMRI seg_subj*.nii -tile w -popas ALLSEG -rf-param-patch 2x2x2x0 -push ALLMRI -push ALLSEG -rf-train myforest.rf

Apply using single MRI

c4d mri_new.nii -rf-apply myforest.rf -omc classprob.nii

[Br2001] Breiman, L. (2001). Random forests. Machine learning, 45(1), 5-32. [Cr2004] Criminisi, A., & Shotton, J. (2013). Decision forests for computer vision and medical image analysis. Springer Science & Business Media

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
5280    def run(
5281        self,
5282        execution: Execution,
5283    ) -> list[str]:
5284        """
5285        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5286        
5287        Args:
5288            self: The sub-command object.
5289            execution: The execution object.
5290        Returns:
5291            
5292        """
5293        cargs = []
5294        cargs.extend(["-rf-train", self.rf_train])
5295        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

5792
5793    c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png
5794    """

c3d -mcs color.png -rgb2hsv -omc hsv.png

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dRms: 
5824@dataclasses.dataclass
5825class C3dRms:
5826    """
5827    -rms: Voxelwise vector norm
5828
5829Syntax: `-rms`
5830
5831Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same size. 
5832
5833    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img
5834
5835The equivalent of this command is
5836
5837    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor \
5838        -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img
5839    """
5840    rms: str
5841    """-rms: Voxelwise vector norm
5842    
5843    Syntax: `-rms`
5844    
5845    Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command
5846    takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and
5847    takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical
5848    operations. Images must have the same size.
5849    
5850    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img
5851    
5852    The equivalent of this command is
5853    
5854    c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor \
5855    -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img"""
5856    
5857    def run(
5858        self,
5859        execution: Execution,
5860    ) -> list[str]:
5861        """
5862        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5863        
5864        Args:
5865            self: The sub-command object.
5866            execution: The execution object.
5867        Returns:
5868            
5869        """
5870        cargs = []
5871        cargs.extend(["-rms", self.rms])
5872        return cargs

-rms: Voxelwise vector norm

Syntax: -rms

Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same size. 

c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img

The equivalent of this command is

c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor         -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img
C3dRms(rms: str)
rms: str

-rms: Voxelwise vector norm

Syntax: -rms

Computes RMS (root mean square) of all images on the stack. The command takes the square of each image on the stack, adds all the squared images and takes the square root of the result. This is very useful for statistical operations. Images must have the same size.

c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -rms -o rms.img

The equivalent of this command is

c3d img1.img img2.img img3.img img4.img -foreach -dup -times -endfor -accum -add -endaccum -sqrt -o rms.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dRound: 
5875@dataclasses.dataclass
5876class C3dRound:
5877    """
5878    -noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior
5879
5880Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `
5881
5882By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. 
5883
5884    c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img
5885    """
5886    round_: str
5887    """-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior
5888    
5889    Syntax: `-noround` or `-round `
5890    
5891    By default, **convert3d** will round floating point values when converting
5892    to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding
5893    should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from
5894    the internal floating point representation.
5895    
5896    c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img"""
5897    
5898    def run(
5899        self,
5900        execution: Execution,
5901    ) -> list[str]:
5902        """
5903        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
5904        
5905        Args:
5906            self: The sub-command object.
5907            execution: The execution object.
5908        Returns:
5909            
5910        """
5911        cargs = []
5912        cargs.extend(["-round", self.round_])
5913        return cargs

-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior

Syntax: -noround or -round

By default, convert3d will round floating point values when converting to an integer, short or byte image. This command specifies that rounding should not be used. Rounding is used to avoid numerical errors stemming from the internal floating point representation. 

c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img

round_: str

-noround, -round: Floating point rounding behavior

c3d image1.img -type short -noround image2.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSet: 
272@dataclasses.dataclass
273class C3dSet:
274    """
275    -as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable
276
277Syntax: `-as var`
278
279Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name 'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using the **-push** command. The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: 
280
281    c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img
282    """
283    set_: str
284    """-as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable
285    
286    Syntax: `-as var`
287    
288    Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name
289    'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using
290    the **-push** command. The **-as** and **-push** commands are useful when
291    you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation.
292    For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image
293    and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value
294    0, you would use the following command:
295    
296    c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img"""
297    
298    def run(
299        self,
300        execution: Execution,
301    ) -> list[str]:
302        """
303        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
304        
305        Args:
306            self: The sub-command object.
307            execution: The execution object.
308        Returns:
309            
310        """
311        cargs = []
312        cargs.extend(["-as", self.set_])
313        return cargs

-as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable

Syntax: -as var

Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name 'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using the -push command. The -as and -push commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command: 

c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img
C3dSet(set_: str)
set_: str

-as: Assign image at the end of the stack to a variable

Syntax: -as var

Associates the image currently at the end of the stack with variable name 'var'. This allows you to retrieve the image later on the command line using the -push command. The -as and -push commands are useful when you need to use a certain image more than once during a convert3d operation. For example, if you want to compute the distance transform of a binary image and mask it so that the values outside of the binary image region have value 0, you would use the following command:

c3d binary.img -as A -sdt -push A -times -o masked_distance.img

6138    """

6145    edges in the image.
6146

6164        return cargs

-sharpen: Sharpen edges in the image

Syntax: -sharpen

Applies the Laplacian sharpening filter from ITK, which accentuates the edges in the image.

c3d input.nii.gz -sharpen -o output.nii.gz
C3dSharpen(sharpen: str)
sharpen: str

-sharpen: Sharpen edges in the image

Syntax: -sharpen

Applies the Laplacian sharpening filter from ITK, which accentuates the edges in the image.

c3d input.nii.gz -sharpen -o output.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

6159        Returns:
6160

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSignedDistanceTransform: 
6205@dataclasses.dataclass
6206class C3dSignedDistanceTransform:
6207    """
6208    -sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary image
6209
6210Syntax: `-sdt`
6211
6212Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary image. 
6213
6214    c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img
6215    """
6216    signed_distance_transform: str
6217    """-sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary
6218    image
6219    
6220    Syntax: `-sdt`
6221    
6222    Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the
6223    binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the
6224    binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value
6225    will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object
6226    represented by the binary image.
6227    
6228    c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img"""
6229    
6230    def run(
6231        self,
6232        execution: Execution,
6233    ) -> list[str]:
6234        """
6235        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6236        
6237        Args:
6238            self: The sub-command object.
6239            execution: The execution object.
6240        Returns:
6241            
6242        """
6243        cargs = []
6244        cargs.extend(["-signed-distance-transform", self.signed_distance_transform])
6245        return cargs

-sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary image

Syntax: -sdt

Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary image. 

c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img
C3dSignedDistanceTransform(signed_distance_transform: str)
signed_distance_transform: str

-sdt, -signed-distance-transform: Signed distance transform of a binary image

Syntax: -sdt

Computes the signed distance transform of a binary image. Voxels where the binary image is non-zero will have negative values and voxels where the binary image is zero will have negative values. The magnitude of the value will be the approximate Euclidean distance to the boundary of the object represented by the binary image.

c3d binary.img -sdt -o dist.img
