@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSlice: 
6025@dataclasses.dataclass
6026class C3dSlice:
6027    """
6028    -slice: Extract slices from an image
6029
6030Syntax: `-slice axis position_spec`
6031
6032Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier **position_spec** can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image. 
6033
6034    c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz
6035    c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz
6036    c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png
6037    c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz 
6038    c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz 
6039
6040With the new command **c4d**, the **-slice** command can be used to extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command 
6041
6042    c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz
6043    """
6044    slice_: str
6045    """-slice: Extract slices from an image
6046    
6047    Syntax: `-slice axis position_spec`
6048    
6049    Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier
6050    **position_spec** can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single
6051    slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is
6052    zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N
6053    is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last.
6054    The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last
6055    dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image.
6056    
6057    c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz
6058    c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz
6059    c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png
6060    c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz
6061    c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz
6062    
6063    With the new command **c4d**, the **-slice** command can be used to extract
6064    volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as
6065    a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command
6066    
6067    c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz"""
6068    
6069    def run(
6070        self,
6071        execution: Execution,
6072    ) -> list[str]:
6073        """
6074        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6075        
6076        Args:
6077            self: The sub-command object.
6078            execution: The execution object.
6079        Returns:
6080            
6081        """
6082        cargs = []
6083        cargs.extend(["-slice", self.slice_])
6084        return cargs

-slice: Extract slices from an image

Syntax: -slice axis position_spec

Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier position_spec can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image. 

c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz
c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz
c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png
c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz 
c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz

With the new command c4d, the -slice command can be used to extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command 

c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz
C3dSlice(slice_: str)
slice_: str

-slice: Extract slices from an image

Syntax: -slice axis position_spec

Extracts a slice along the specified axis (x,y or z). The position specifier position_spec can be a single slice or a range of slices. For a single slice, it can be specified as a number or a percentage. Numbering is zero-based, i.e, the first slice is slice 0, the last slice is N-1, where N is the number of slices. For a range, use MATLAB notation first:step:last. The slice is placed on the stack as an image with size 1 in the last dimension. You can save the slice as a 2D PNG image.

c3d input.img -slice x 128 -o myslice.nii.gz c3d input.img -slice y 50% myslice.nii.gz c3d input.img -slice z 25% -type uchar -stretch 0 2000 0 255 -o myslice.png c3d input.img -slice z 0:-1 -oo slice%0d.nii.gz c3d input.img -slice z 20%:10%:80% -oo slice%0d.nii.gz

With the new command c4d, the -slice command can be used to extract volumes from a 4D image. This can be useful to reformat a 4D NIFTI image as a 3D multi-component NIFTI image, using the command

c4d input4d.nii.gz -slice w 0:-1 -omc output3d_multicomp.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
6069    def run(
6070        self,
6071        execution: Execution,
6072    ) -> list[str]:
6073        """
6074        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6075        
6076        Args:
6077            self: The sub-command object.
6078            execution: The execution object.
6079        Returns:
6080            
6081        """
6082        cargs = []
6083        cargs.extend(["-slice", self.slice_])
6084        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSliceAll: 
6087@dataclasses.dataclass
6088class C3dSliceAll:
6089    """
6090    -slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack
6091
6092Syntax `-slice-all axis position_spec`
6093
6094This command behaves identical to the **-slice** command, but all images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows:
6095
6096    c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz
6097    """
6098    slice_all: str
6099    """-slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack
6100    
6101    Syntax `-slice-all axis position_spec`
6102    
6103    This command behaves identical to the **-slice** command, but all images on
6104    the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for
6105    slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component
6106    image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows:
6107    
6108    c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz"""
6109    
6110    def run(
6111        self,
6112        execution: Execution,
6113    ) -> list[str]:
6114        """
6115        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6116        
6117        Args:
6118            self: The sub-command object.
6119            execution: The execution object.
6120        Returns:
6121            
6122        """
6123        cargs = []
6124        cargs.extend(["-slice-all", self.slice_all])
6125        return cargs

-slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack

Syntax -slice-all axis position_spec

This command behaves identical to the -slice command, but all images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows:

c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz
C3dSliceAll(slice_all: str)
slice_all: str

-slice-all: Extract slices from all images on the stack

Syntax -slice-all axis position_spec

This command behaves identical to the -slice command, but all images on the stack are sliced, and the slices are interleaved. This is useful for slicing multi-component images. For example, if you read a four-component image 'test4.nii.gz', you can extract and save the slices as follows:

c3d test4.nii.gz -slice-all 20%:10%:80% -oomc 4 slice4_%03d.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
6110    def run(
6111        self,
6112        execution: Execution,
6113    ) -> list[str]:
6114        """

6123        cargs = []
6124        cargs.extend(["-slice-all", self.slice_all])

6298    """

6306    deviation of the Gaussian kernel. Also see [Vector Format Specification][10]
6307    below.
6308    
6309    c3d img1.img -smooth-fast 20x10x10vox -o out.img"""

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSpacing: 
6329@dataclasses.dataclass
6330class C3dSpacing:
6331    """
6332    -spacing: Set voxel spacing
6333
6334Syntax: `-spacing <vector> `
6335
6336Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector with positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the image to 1mm isotropic, use the command below. This command only changes the header of the image, not its contents. 
6337
6338    c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img
6339    """
6340    spacing: str
6341    """-spacing: Set voxel spacing
6342    
6343    Syntax: `-spacing <vector> `
6344    
6345    Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector with
6346    positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the image to 1mm
6347    isotropic, use the command below. This command only changes the header of
6348    the image, not its contents.
6349    
6350    c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img"""
6351    
6352    def run(
6353        self,
6354        execution: Execution,
6355    ) -> list[str]:
6356        """
6357        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6358        
6359        Args:
6360            self: The sub-command object.
6361            execution: The execution object.
6362        Returns:
6363            
6364        """
6365        cargs = []
6366        cargs.extend(["-spacing", self.spacing])
6367        return cargs

-spacing: Set voxel spacing

Syntax: -spacing <vector>

Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector with positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the image to 1mm isotropic, use the command below. This command only changes the header of the image, not its contents. 

c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img
C3dSpacing(spacing: str)
spacing: str

-spacing: Set voxel spacing

Syntax: -spacing <vector>

Sets the voxel spacing of the image. This should always be a vector with positive components. For example, to set the spacing of the image to 1mm isotropic, use the command below. This command only changes the header of the image, not its contents.

c3d img.nii -spacing 1x1x1mm -o out.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
6352    def run(
6353        self,
6354        execution: Execution,
6355    ) -> list[str]:
6356        """
6357        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6358        
6359        Args:
6360            self: The sub-command object.
6361            execution: The execution object.
6362        Returns:
6363            
6364        """
6365        cargs = []
6366        cargs.extend(["-spacing", self.spacing])
6367        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSplit: 
6370@dataclasses.dataclass
6371class C3dSplit:
6372    """
6373    -split: Split multi-label image into binary images
6374
6375Syntax: `-split`
6376
6377This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the **-merge** command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by **convert3d** so that when **-merge** is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The **-merge** command treats each input as a probability image, and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using **-merge** 
6378
6379    c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o ml_smooth.nii
6380
6381Also of note is that the **-split** command will disregard infinite intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with *inf*, for example, using the **-thresh** command.
6382    """
6383    split: str
6384    """-split: Split multi-label image into binary images
6385    
6386    Syntax: `-split`
6387    
6388    This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete
6389    intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each
6390    of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the **-merge**
6391    command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by
6392    **convert3d** so that when **-merge** is called, the labels are faithfully
6393    reassigned. The **-merge** command treats each input as a probability image,
6394    and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The
6395    example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using
6396    **-merge**
6397    
6398    c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o
6399    ml_smooth.nii
6400    
6401    Also of note is that the **-split** command will disregard infinite
6402    intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels,
6403    you can replace labels you do not care about with *inf*, for example, using
6404    the **-thresh** command."""
6405    
6406    def run(
6407        self,
6408        execution: Execution,
6409    ) -> list[str]:
6410        """
6411        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6412        
6413        Args:
6414            self: The sub-command object.
6415            execution: The execution object.
6416        Returns:
6417            
6418        """
6419        cargs = []
6420        cargs.extend(["-split", self.split])
6421        return cargs

-split: Split multi-label image into binary images

Syntax: -split

This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the -merge command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by convert3d so that when -merge is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The -merge command treats each input as a probability image, and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using -merge 

c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o ml_smooth.nii

Also of note is that the -split command will disregard infinite intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with inf, for example, using the -thresh command.

C3dSplit(split: str)
split: str

-split: Split multi-label image into binary images

Syntax: -split

This command takes a multilabel image (one with a small number of discrete intensity levels), and replaces it with a set of binary images, one for each of the levels. The images can later be recombined using the -merge command. The labels corresponding to each binary image are remembered by convert3d so that when -merge is called, the labels are faithfully reassigned. The -merge command treats each input as a probability image, and selects at each voxel the label that has highest probability. The example below smooths each label independently, then recombines using -merge

c3d multilabel.nii -split -foreach -smooth 3mm -endfor -merge -o ml_smooth.nii

Also of note is that the -split command will disregard infinite intensity values. So if you want to apply voting to a subset of the labels, you can replace labels you do not care about with inf, for example, using the -thresh command.

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

6415            execution: The execution object.
6416        Returns:
6417            
6418        """
6419        cargs = []
6420        cargs.extend(["-split", self.split])
6421        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSpm: 
6559@dataclasses.dataclass
6560class C3dSpm:
6561    """
6562    -spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output
6563
6564Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `
6565
6566These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.
6567
6568    c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz
6569    """
6570    spm: str
6571    """-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output
6572    
6573    Syntax: `-spm` or `-nospm `
6574    
6575    These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze
6576    (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM
6577    in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze
6578    files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the
6579    **-nospm** option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and
6580    SPM5 or later.
6581    
6582    c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz"""
6583    
6584    def run(
6585        self,
6586        execution: Execution,
6587    ) -> list[str]:
6588        """
6589        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6590        
6591        Args:
6592            self: The sub-command object.
6593            execution: The execution object.
6594        Returns:
6595            
6596        """
6597        cargs = []
6598        cargs.extend(["-spm", self.spm])
6599        return cargs

-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output

Syntax: -spm or -nospm

These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the -nospm option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.

c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz
C3dSpm(spm: str)
spm: str

-spm, -nospm: SPM compatibility in Analyze output

Syntax: -spm or -nospm

These options specify whether use the SPM extension to the Analyze (.hdr,.img) format. When this option is on, the origin field stored by SPM in the Analyze header will be correctly interpreted. When saving analyze files, the origin will be set correctly. The default is equivalent to the -nospm option. Best to avoid this issue altogether by using NIFTI and SPM5 or later.

c3d -spm in.hdr out.img.gz

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dStaple: 
6462@dataclasses.dataclass
6463class C3dStaple:
6464    """
6465    -staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations
6466
6467Syntax: `-staple <intensity_value> `
6468
6469Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a different rater. The parameter *intensity_value* specifies the label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the *intensity_value*). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the **-verbose** command is used before the **-staple** command. 
6470
6471    c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img
6472    c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img
6473    """
6474    staple: str
6475    """-staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations
6476    
6477    Syntax: `-staple <intensity_value> `
6478    
6479    Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]).
6480    STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given
6481    a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images
6482    on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a
6483    different rater. The parameter *intensity_value* specifies the label in the
6484    segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the
6485    segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2
6486    corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in
6487    2 as the *intensity_value*). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image
6488    with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel
6489    being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a
6490    binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the
6491    sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the
6492    **-verbose** command is used before the **-staple** command.
6493    
6494    c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img
6495    c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img"""
6496    
6497    def run(
6498        self,
6499        execution: Execution,
6500    ) -> list[str]:
6501        """
6502        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6503        
6504        Args:
6505            self: The sub-command object.
6506            execution: The execution object.
6507        Returns:
6508            
6509        """
6510        cargs = []
6511        cargs.extend(["-staple", self.staple])
6512        return cargs

-staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations

Syntax: -staple <intensity_value>

Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a different rater. The parameter intensity_value specifies the label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the intensity_value). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the -verbose command is used before the -staple command. 

c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img
c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img
C3dStaple(staple: str)
staple: str

-staple: STAPLE algorithm to combine segmentations

Syntax: -staple <intensity_value>

Runs the ITK implementation of the STAPLE algorithm ([See Paper][11]). STAPLE generates an estimate of the 'true' segmentation of a structure given a set of segmentations by different raters. This command treats all images on the stack as inputs. Each image is considered to be a segmentation by a different rater. The parameter intensity_value specifies the label in the segmentation images corresponding to the structure of interest (e.g., the segmentation image may have value 1 corresponding to the caudate and value 2 corresponding to the hippocampus. To run STAPLE on the hippocampus, pass in 2 as the intensity_value). The output of STAPLE is a real-valued image with voxels between 0 and 1, representing the probability of each voxel being in the 'true' segmentation. This image can be thresholded to get a binary consensus segmentation. Additional outputs (estimates of the sensitivity and specificity of each rater) are printed out if the -verbose command is used before the -staple command.

c3d -verbose rater1.img rater2.img rater3.img -staple 1 -o probmap.img c3d -verbose rater*.img -staple 1 -threshold 0.5 inf 1 0 -o bin_segm.img

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dStretch: 
6654@dataclasses.dataclass
6655class C3dStretch:
6656    """
6657    -stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly
6658
6659Syntax: `-stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> `
6660
6661Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use 
6662
6663    c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img
6664    """
6665    stretch: str
6666    """-stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly
6667    
6668    Syntax: `-stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2> `
6669    
6670    Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and
6671    u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in
6672    the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating
6673    point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an
6674    unsigned short image, use
6675    
6676    c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img"""
6677    
6678    def run(
6679        self,
6680        execution: Execution,
6681    ) -> list[str]:
6682        """
6683        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6684        
6685        Args:
6686            self: The sub-command object.
6687            execution: The execution object.
6688        Returns:
6689            
6690        """
6691        cargs = []
6692        cargs.extend(["-stretch", self.stretch])
6693        return cargs

-stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly

Syntax: -stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2>

Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use 

c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img
C3dStretch(stretch: str)
stretch: str

-stretch: Stretch image intensities linearly

Syntax: -stretch <u1 u2 v1 v2>

Stretches the intensities in the image linearly, such that u1 maps to v1 and u2 maps to v2. The linear transformation is applied to all intensities in the image, whether inside the range or not. For example, to map a floating point image with intensities in interval (0,1) to the full range of an unsigned short image, use

c3d input.img -stretch 0.0 1.0 0 65535 -type ushort -o output.img

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dStructureTensorEigenvalues: 
6515@dataclasses.dataclass
6516class C3dStructureTensorEigenvalues:
6517    """
6518    -steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor
6519
6520Syntax `-steig <scale> <radius>`
6521
6522Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.
6523
6524    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
6525    """
6526    structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str
6527    """-steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the
6528    structure tensor
6529    
6530    Syntax `-steig <scale> <radius>`
6531    
6532    Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues
6533    of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on
6534    the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the
6535    '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing
6536    applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in
6537    physical (mm) units.
6538    
6539    c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz"""
6540    
6541    def run(
6542        self,
6543        execution: Execution,
6544    ) -> list[str]:
6545        """
6546        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6547        
6548        Args:
6549            self: The sub-command object.
6550            execution: The execution object.
6551        Returns:
6552            
6553        """
6554        cargs = []
6555        cargs.extend(["-steig", self.structure_tensor_eigenvalues])
6556        return cargs

-steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor

Syntax -steig <scale> <radius>

Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.

c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz
C3dStructureTensorEigenvalues(structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str)
structure_tensor_eigenvalues: str

-steig, -structure-tensor-eigenvalues: Compute eigenvalues of the structure tensor

Syntax -steig <scale> <radius>

Computes the Hessian matrix at every pixel of an image and the eigenvalues of the Hessian. Images of the eigenvalues (sorted by value) are placed on the stack. These images are useful as texture features. See also the '''-steig''' command. The scale determines the amount of Gaussian smoothing applied for computing the partial derivatives in the Hessian, and is in physical (mm) units.

c3d myimage.nii -hesseig 2.0 -oo eig%02d.nii.gz

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
6541    def run(
6542        self,
6543        execution: Execution,
6544    ) -> list[str]:
6545        """

6548        Args:
6549            self: The sub-command object.
6550            execution: The execution object.
6551        Returns:
6552            
6553        """
6554        cargs = []
6555        cargs.extend(["-steig", self.structure_tensor_eigenvalues])
6556        return cargs

  • self: The sub-command object.

@dataclasses.dataclass

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dSwapdim: 
6696@dataclasses.dataclass
6697class C3dSwapdim:
6698    """
6699    -swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image
6700
6701Syntax `-swapdim <code>`
6702
6703This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command.
6704
6705    c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii
6706
6707
6708### Commands: Image Processing
6709
6710The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options, which are listed separately.
6711    """
6712    swapdim: str
6713    """-swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image
6714    
6715    Syntax `-swapdim <code>`
6716    
6717    This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a
6718    desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image
6719    remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels
6720    in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The
6721    transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the
6722    '''-orient''' command.
6723    
6724    c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii
6725    
6726    
6727    ### Commands: Image Processing
6728    
6729    The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary
6730    commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands
6731    apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options,
6732    which are listed separately."""
6733    
6734    def run(
6735        self,
6736        execution: Execution,
6737    ) -> list[str]:
6738        """
6739        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6740        
6741        Args:
6742            self: The sub-command object.
6743            execution: The execution object.
6744        Returns:
6745            
6746        """
6747        cargs = []
6748        cargs.extend(["-swapdim", self.swapdim])
6749        return cargs

-swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image

Syntax -swapdim <code>

This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command.

c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii

Commands: Image Processing

The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options, which are listed separately.

C3dSwapdim(swapdim: str)
swapdim: str

-swapdim: Reorder the coordinate axes of an image

Syntax -swapdim <code>

This command reorders the image axes (columns, rows, slices) to achieve a desired transformation between voxel space and physical space. The image remains exactly the same in physical space, but the encoding of the voxels in memory and on disk is changed to obtain the desired transformation. The transformation is specified as a three-letter 'RAI' code, as in the '''-orient''' command.

c3d img.nii -swapdim ASL -info -o out.nii

Commands: Image Processing

The following commands invoke an action that is applied to images. Unary commands apply the action to the last image on the stack, binary commands apply to the last two images and so on. Commands are affected by options, which are listed separately.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dTestImage: 
6752@dataclasses.dataclass
6753class C3dTestImage:
6754    """
6755    -test-image, -test-probe: Test condition
6756
6757Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value> [tolerance]`
6758
6759These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell). The commands check a certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the test failed. 
6760
6761**-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8. 
6762
6763    c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image
6764
6765**-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by **vector** is equal to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the default is 1e-8. 
6766
6767    c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6
6768    """
6769    test_image: str
6770    """-test-image, -test-probe: Test condition
6771    
6772    Syntax: `-test-image [tolerance]` and `-test-probe <vector> <value>
6773    [tolerance]`
6774    
6775    These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily
6776    meant to allow testing of **c3d**. However, they can also be used for flow
6777    control in shell scripts (e.g., **bash** shell). The commands check a
6778    certain aspect of the **c3d** state and cause the program to exit with
6779    either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the
6780    test failed.
6781    
6782    **-test-image** tests if the last two images on the stack are identical
6783    (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical.
6784    The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8.
6785    
6786    c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image
6787    
6788    **-test-probe** is similar to the **-probe** command. It tests if the value
6789    of the last image on the stack at the position given by **vector** is equal
6790    to the **test_value**. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the
6791    default is 1e-8.
6792    
6793    c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6"""
6794    
6795    def run(
6796        self,
6797        execution: Execution,
6798    ) -> list[str]:
6799        """
6800        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6801        
6802        Args:
6803            self: The sub-command object.
6804            execution: The execution object.
6805        Returns:
6806            
6807        """
6808        cargs = []
6809        cargs.extend(["-test-image", self.test_image])
6810        return cargs

-test-image, -test-probe: Test condition

Syntax: -test-image [tolerance] and -test-probe <vector> <value> [tolerance]

These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily meant to allow testing of c3d. However, they can also be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., bash shell). The commands check a certain aspect of the c3d state and cause the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the test failed.

-test-image tests if the last two images on the stack are identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8. 

c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image

-test-probe is similar to the -probe command. It tests if the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by vector is equal to the test_value. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the default is 1e-8. 

c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6
C3dTestImage(test_image: str)
test_image: str

These advanced commands (with more to come in the future) are primarily meant to allow testing of c3d. However, they can also be used for flow control in shell scripts (e.g., bash shell). The commands check a certain aspect of the c3d state and cause the program to exit with either return code 0 if the test succeeded or a non-zero return code if the test failed.

-test-image tests if the last two images on the stack are identical (both in terms of data and header). Returns 0 if the images are identical. The optional tolerance parameter has default value 1e-8.

c3d input1.img input2.img -test-image

-test-probe is similar to the -probe command. It tests if the value of the last image on the stack at the position given by vector is equal to the test_value. An optional tolerance value may be specified, the default is 1e-8.

c3d input1.img -test-probe 40x40x20vox 1.0 1e-6

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dThreshold: 
6874@dataclasses.dataclass
6875class C3dThreshold:
6876    """
6877    -thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding
6878
6879Syntax: `-thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> `
6880
6881Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values *u1* and *u2* are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values **inf** and **-inf** for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also specify *u1* and *u2* as percentiles. 
6882    c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img
6883    c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img
6884    c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img
6885    """
6886    threshold: str
6887    """-thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding
6888    
6889    Syntax: `-thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut> `
6890    
6891    Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2]
6892    to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values *u1* and *u2* are intensity
6893    specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values **inf**
6894    and **-inf** for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also
6895    specify *u1* and *u2* as percentiles.
6896    c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img
6897    c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img
6898    c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img"""
6899    
6900    def run(
6901        self,
6902        execution: Execution,
6903    ) -> list[str]:
6904        """
6905        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6906        
6907        Args:
6908            self: The sub-command object.
6909            execution: The execution object.
6910        Returns:
6911            
6912        """
6913        cargs = []
6914        cargs.extend(["-threshold", self.threshold])
6915        return cargs

-thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding

Syntax: -thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut>

Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values u1 and u2 are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values inf and -inf for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also specify u1 and u2 as percentiles. c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img

C3dThreshold(threshold: str)
threshold: str

-thresh, -threshold: Binary thresholding

Syntax: -thresh <u1 u2 vIn vOut>

Thresholds the image, setting voxels whose intensity is in the range [u1,u2] to vIn and all other voxels to vOut. Values u1 and u2 are intensity specifications (see below). This means that you can supply values inf and -inf for u1 and u2 to construct a one-sided threshold. You can also specify u1 and u2 as percentiles. c3d in.img -threshold -inf 128 1 0 -o out.img c3d in.img -threshold 64 128 1 0 -o out.img c3d in.img -threshold 20% 40% 1 0 -o out.img

6909            execution: The execution object.
6910        Returns:
6911            
6912        """
6913        cargs = []
6914        cargs.extend(["-threshold", self.threshold])
6915        return cargs

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dTile: 
6918@dataclasses.dataclass
6919class C3dTile:
6920    """
6921    -tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one
6922
6923Syntax: `-tile <tile_spec>`
6924
6925Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single tiled image. The **tile_spec** parameter can either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g., **4x4**) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of slices, we use 
6926
6927    c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz
6928
6929And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we would use the **c2d** command as follows: 
6930
6931    c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png
6932    """
6933    tile: str
6934    """-tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one
6935    
6936    Syntax: `-tile <tile_spec>`
6937    
6938    Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into
6939    a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single
6940    tiled image. The **tile_spec** parameter can either specify a coordinate
6941    axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g.,
6942    **4x4**) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the
6943    last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of
6944    images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of
6945    slices, we use
6946    
6947    c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz
6948    
6949    And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we
6950    would use the **c2d** command as follows:
6951    
6952    c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png"""
6953    
6954    def run(
6955        self,
6956        execution: Execution,
6957    ) -> list[str]:
6958        """
6959        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6960        
6961        Args:
6962            self: The sub-command object.
6963            execution: The execution object.
6964        Returns:
6965            
6966        """
6967        cargs = []
6968        cargs.extend(["-tile", self.tile])
6969        return cargs

-tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one

Syntax: -tile <tile_spec>

Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single tiled image. The tile_spec parameter can either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g., 4x4) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of slices, we use 

c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz

And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we would use the c2d command as follows: 

c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png
C3dTile(tile: str)
tile: str

-tile: Tile and stack multiple images into one

Syntax: -tile <tile_spec>

Tiles multiple images into a single image -- including stacking slices into a 3D volume. The command takes all images on the stack and produces a single tiled image. The tile_spec parameter can either specify a coordinate axis (x, y, or z) along which to tile the images, or a layout vector (e.g., 4x4) which specifies the tiling along each coordinate. Passing 0 for the last value in the layout vector determines the value based on the number of images currently loaded. For example, to create a 3D volume from a set of slices, we use

c3d slices*.png -tile z -o volume.nii.gz

And to arrange the same 2D slices into a 2D montage of 4 images per row, we would use the c2d command as follows:

c2d slices*.png -tile 4x0 -type uchar -o montage.png

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]: 
6954    def run(
6955        self,
6956        execution: Execution,
6957    ) -> list[str]:
6958        """
6959        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
6960        
6961        Args:
6962            self: The sub-command object.
6963            execution: The execution object.
6964        Returns:
6965            
6966        """
6967        cargs = []
6968        cargs.extend(["-tile", self.tile])
6969        return cargs

Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.

Arguments:
  • self: The sub-command object.
  • execution: The execution object.

Returns:

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dTrim: 
6972@dataclasses.dataclass
6973class C3dTrim:
6974    """
6975    -trim: Trim background region of image
6976
6977Syntax: `-trim <margin_vector>`
6978
6979Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides
6980
6981    c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img
6982    """
6983    trim: str
6984    """-trim: Trim background region of image
6985    
6986    Syntax: `-trim <margin_vector>`
6987    
6988    Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is
6989    filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region
6990    that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then
6991    expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the
6992    resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an
6993    image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides
6994    
6995    c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img"""
6996    
6997    def run(
6998        self,
6999        execution: Execution,
7000    ) -> list[str]:
7001        """
7002        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7003        
7004        Args:
7005            self: The sub-command object.
7006            execution: The execution object.
7007        Returns:
7008            
7009        """
7010        cargs = []
7011        cargs.extend(["-trim", self.trim])
7012        return cargs

-trim: Trim background region of image

Syntax: -trim <margin_vector>

Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides

c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img
C3dTrim(trim: str)
trim: str

Syntax: -trim <margin_vector>

Use this command to trim background in an image. When most of the image is filled by background, this command will find the smallest rectangular region that contains all of the non-background voxels in the image. I will then expand this region by the margin of the size specified, and return the resulting region as the new image. For example, this command will trim an image, leaving a 5-voxel margin of background values on all sides

c3d in.img -trim 5vox -o out.img

7015@dataclasses.dataclass
7016class C3dTrimToSize:
7017    """
7018    -trim-to-size: Trim image to given size
7019
7020Syntax: `-trim-to-size <size_vector>`
7021
7022Like **-trim**, this command trims the background in an image. However, instead of **-trim**, you specify the target size of the output region. The actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call 
7023
7024    c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img
7025    """
7026    trim_to_size: str
7027    """-trim-to-size: Trim image to given size
7028    
7029    Syntax: `-trim-to-size <size_vector>`

7032    instead of **-trim**, you specify the target size of the output region. The
7033    actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the
7034    boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image
7035    containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call
7036

-trim-to-size: Trim image to given size

Syntax: -trim-to-size <size_vector>

Like -trim, this command trims the background in an image. However, instead of -trim, you specify the target size of the output region. The actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call 

c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img
C3dTrimToSize(trim_to_size: str)

-trim-to-size: Trim image to given size

The actual region may be smaller if the specified region falls outside the boundaries of the input image. For example, if you want a 64x64x128 image containing all the foreground pixels in your image, call

c3d in.img -trim-to-size 64x64x128vox -o out.img

7057@dataclasses.dataclass
7058class C3dType:
7059    """
7060    -type: Specify pixel type for image output
7061
7062Syntax: `-type < char | uchar | short | ushort | int | uint | float | double > `
7063
7064Specifies the pixel type for the output image. By default, images are written in floating point (**float**) format. The type does not affect how images are processed, only how they are saved. 
7065
7066    c3d image1.img -type short image2.img
7067
7068Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG images, uchar or ushort type must be specified.
7069    """
7070    type_: str

c3d image1.img -type short image2.img

Some images require data in certain types. For example, to save PNG images, uchar or ushort type must be specified.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dVote: 
7194@dataclasses.dataclass
7195class C3dVote:
7196    """
7197    -vote: Vote among images on the stack
7198
7199Syntax: `-vote `
7200
7201This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel *(i,j,k)* returns the index of the image for which the image value at *(i,j,k)* is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the **-vote** command will return the most probable label at each voxel. 
7202
7203    c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img
7204
7205The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands **-split** and **-merge**.
7206    """
7207    vote: str
7208    """-vote: Vote among images on the stack
7209    
7210    Syntax: `-vote `
7211    
7212    This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel
7213    *(i,j,k)* returns the index of the image for which the image value at
7214    *(i,j,k)* is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability
7215    maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give
7216    the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the **-vote**
7217    command will return the most probable label at each voxel.
7218    
7219    c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img
7220    
7221    The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of
7222    the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the
7223    output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for
7224    prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands **-split** and
7225    **-merge**."""
7226    
7227    def run(
7228        self,
7229        execution: Execution,
7230    ) -> list[str]:
7231        """
7232        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7233        
7234        Args:
7235            self: The sub-command object.
7236            execution: The execution object.
7237        Returns:
7238            
7239        """
7240        cargs = []
7241        cargs.extend(["-vote", self.vote])
7242        return cargs

-vote: Vote among images on the stack

Syntax: -vote

This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel (i,j,k) returns the index of the image for which the image value at (i,j,k) is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the -vote command will return the most probable label at each voxel. 

c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img

The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands -split and -merge.

C3dVote(vote: str)
vote: str

-vote: Vote among images on the stack

Syntax: -vote

This command takes all images on the stack as arguments and at each voxel (i,j,k) returns the index of the image for which the image value at (i,j,k) is the greatest. This is most useful when combining probability maps into a single label image. If images prob1.img, prob2.img, etc. give the probability of label 1, 2, etc. over the image domain, the -vote command will return the most probable label at each voxel.

c3d prob1.img prob2.img prob3.img -vote -type uchar -o label.img

The value assigned to each image is based on its position from the bottom of the stack, with zero indicating bottom-most image. In the example above, the output image has values 0 for voxels where prob1.img is highest, 1 for prob2.img and 2 for prob3.img. Also see the related commands -split and -merge.

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dVoteMrf: 
7245@dataclasses.dataclass
7246class C3dVoteMrf:
7247    """
7248    -vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization
7249
7250Syntax: `-vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>`
7251
7252This command is similar to **-vote** but it performs regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more contiguous segments. 
7253
7254The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel **x** in image **k** holds the probability that voxel **x** has label **k**. Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label 0 in the output.
7255
7256The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel **x** the label **k**. The parameter **mode** describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost. 
7257
7258* `VOTES_AGAINST` or `VA`. This mode is useful when the command is being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that assign label *k* to voxel *x*. The data term equals to the error associated to assining the voxel *k* label *x*. This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all labels at *x* minus the likelihood for *k* at *x*. Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted as missing data for some voxels. 
7259
7260* `LOG_LIKELIHOOD` or `LL`. The cost for label *k* at voxel *x* is the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at *x*. This will assign infinite cost when the likelihood is zero. 
7261
7262The regularlization term is encoded as **lambda** times the total number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that have different labels. 
7263
7264The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers. 
7265
72661. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, *Efficient Approximate Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001. 
7267
72682. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, *What Energy Functions can be Minimized via Graph Cuts?*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004.
7269
72703. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, *An Experimental Comparison of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004. 
7271
7272As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication.  If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, *System and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts*, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.
7273
7274The example below illustrates applying **-vote-mrf** with a user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label.
7275
7276    c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \
7277        -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \
7278        -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii
7279    """
7280    vote_mrf: str
7281    """-vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization
7282    
7283    Syntax: `-vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>`
7284    
7285    This command is similar to **-vote** but it performs regularlization using
7286    the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the
7287    total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more
7288    contiguous segments.
7289    
7290    The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are
7291    likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel
7292    **x** in image **k** holds the probability that voxel **x** has label **k**.
7293    Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range
7294    are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels
7295    will be assigned label 0 in the output.
7296    
7297    The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a
7298    data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost
7299    (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel **x** the label **k**. The
7300    parameter **mode** describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost.
7301    
7302    * `VOTES_AGAINST` or `VA`. This mode is useful when the command is being
7303    used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each
7304    likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that
7305    assign label *k* to voxel *x*. The data term equals to the error associated
7306    to assining the voxel *k* label *x*. This error is calculated as the sum of
7307    the likelihoods for all labels at *x* minus the likelihood for *k* at *x*.
7308    Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be
7309    interpreted as missing data for some voxels.
7310    
7311    * `LOG_LIKELIHOOD` or `LL`. The cost for label *k* at voxel *x* is the
7312    logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at *x*. This will assign infinite
7313    cost when the likelihood is zero.
7314    
7315    The regularlization term is encoded as **lambda** times the total number of
7316    neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that
7317    have different labels.
7318    
7319    The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut
7320    algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers.
7321    
7322    1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, *Efficient Approximate Energy
7323    Minimization via Graph Cuts*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p.
7324    1222-1239, 2001.
7325    
7326    2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, *What Energy Functions can be
7327    Minimized via Graph Cuts?*, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p.
7328    147-159, 2004.
7329    
7330    3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, *An Experimental Comparison of
7331    Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision*, IEEE
7332    transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004.
7333    
7334    As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms
7335    distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used
7336    only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any
7337    resulting publication. If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms
7338    described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should
7339    be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, *System
7340    and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts*, United
7341    Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.
7342    
7343    The example below illustrates applying **-vote-mrf** with a user-specified
7344    mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number)
7345    and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label.
7346    
7347    c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M \
7348    -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor \
7349    -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii"""
7350    
7351    def run(
7352        self,
7353        execution: Execution,
7354    ) -> list[str]:
7355        """
7356        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7357        
7358        Args:
7359            self: The sub-command object.
7360            execution: The execution object.
7361        Returns:
7362            
7363        """
7364        cargs = []
7365        cargs.extend(["-vote-mrf", self.vote_mrf])
7366        return cargs

-vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization

Syntax: -vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>

This command is similar to -vote but it performs regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more contiguous segments.

The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel x in image k holds the probability that voxel x has label k. Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label 0 in the output.

The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel x the label k. The parameter mode describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost.

  • VOTES_AGAINST or VA. This mode is useful when the command is being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that assign label k to voxel x. The data term equals to the error associated to assining the voxel k label x. This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all labels at x minus the likelihood for k at x. Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted as missing data for some voxels.

  • LOG_LIKELIHOOD or LL. The cost for label k at voxel x is the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at x. This will assign infinite cost when the likelihood is zero.

The regularlization term is encoded as lambda times the total number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that have different labels.

The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers.

  1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, Efficient Approximate Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001.

  2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, What Energy Functions can be Minimized via Graph Cuts?, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004.

  3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, An Experimental Comparison of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004.

As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication. If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, System and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.

The example below illustrates applying -vote-mrf with a user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label.

c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M         -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor         -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii
C3dVoteMrf(vote_mrf: str)
vote_mrf: str

-vote-mrf: Vote with Markov Random Field regularlization

Syntax: -vote-mrf <mode> <lambda>

This command is similar to -vote but it performs regularlization using the Markov Random Field (MRF). This form of regularization penalizes the total surface area of the segments in the output. It results in more contiguous segments.

The command takes all the images on the stack and assumes that they are likelihood images corresponding to labels 1, 2, ... N. This means that voxel x in image k holds the probability that voxel x has label k. Likelihood images must be between 0 and 1. Any values outside of the range are interpreted as the voxel being excluded from the voting. These voxels will be assigned label 0 in the output.

The problem is encoded in the form of energy minimization, consisting of a data term and a regularization term. The data term encodes the cost (penalty) associated with assigning the voxel x the label k. The parameter mode describes how likelihood images are mapped to the cost.

  • VOTES_AGAINST or VA. This mode is useful when the command is being used to combine several multi-label segmentations into a single one. Each likelihood image is assumed to be the proportion of segmentations that assign label k to voxel x. The data term equals to the error associated to assining the voxel k label x. This error is calculated as the sum of the likelihoods for all labels at x minus the likelihood for k at x. Note that the likelihoods do not have to add up to one, which may be interpreted as missing data for some voxels.

  • LOG_LIKELIHOOD or LL. The cost for label k at voxel x is the logarithm of the k-th likelihood image at x. This will assign infinite cost when the likelihood is zero.

The regularlization term is encoded as lambda times the total number of neighboring voxels inside the mask (non-excluded region of the image) that have different labels.

The optmization problem is solved using the Alpha-Expansion graph cut algorithm. Users of this functionality should cite the following papers.

  1. Yuri Boykov, Olga Veksler, Ramin Zabih, Efficient Approximate Energy Minimization via Graph Cuts, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 20, no. 12, p. 1222-1239, 2001.

  2. Vladimir Kolmogorov and Ramin Zabih, What Energy Functions can be Minimized via Graph Cuts?, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 2, p. 147-159, 2004.

  3. Yuri Boykov and Vladimir Kolmogorov, An Experimental Comparison of Min-Cut/Max-Flow Algorithms for Energy Minimization in Vision, IEEE transactions on PAMI, vol. 26, no. 9, p. 1124-1137, 2004.

As noted in the open source implementation of the graph cuts algorithms distributed under the General Public License, "This software can be used only for research purposes, you should cite the aforementioned paper in any resulting publication. If you wish to use this software (or the algorithms described in the aforementioned paper) for commercial purposes, you should be aware that there is a US patent: R. Zabih, Y. Boykov, O. Veksler, System and method for fast approximate energy minimization via graph cuts, United Stated Patent 6,744,923, June 1, 2004.

The example below illustrates applying -vote-mrf with a user-specified mask. Voxels outside of the mask are first remapped to NaN (not a number) and thus excluded from the MRF optimization and given 0 label.

c3d lhood01.nii lhood02.nii lhood03.nii mask.nii -popas M -foreach -push M -replace 0 NaN -times -endfor -vote-mrf VA 0.2 -o result.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dVoxelwiseRegression: 
7477@dataclasses.dataclass
7478class C3dVoxelwiseRegression:
7479    """
7480    -voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images
7481
7482Syntax: `-voxreg regression_order `
7483
7484Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b\_0, b\_1, ..., b\_k, such that Y is best approximated by b\_0 + b\_1 * X + b\_2 * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression. 
7485
7486    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2 
7487    REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935
7488    REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024
7489
7490    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2
7491    REGCOEFF[0] = 0
7492    REGCOEFF[1] = 1
7493    """
7494    voxelwise_regression: str
7495    """-voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images
7496    
7497    Syntax: `-voxreg regression_order `
7498    
7499    Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command
7500    takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b\_0,
7501    b\_1, ..., b\_k, such that Y is best approximated by b\_0 + b\_1 * X + b\_2
7502    * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression.
7503    
7504    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2
7505    REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935
7506    REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024
7507    
7508    $ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2
7509    REGCOEFF[0] = 0
7510    REGCOEFF[1] = 1"""
7511    
7512    def run(
7513        self,
7514        execution: Execution,
7515    ) -> list[str]:
7516        """
7517        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7518        
7519        Args:
7520            self: The sub-command object.
7521            execution: The execution object.
7522        Returns:
7523            
7524        """
7525        cargs = []
7526        cargs.extend(["-voxelwise-regression", self.voxelwise_regression])
7527        return cargs

-voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images

Syntax: -voxreg regression_order

Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b_0, b_1, ..., b_k, such that Y is best approximated by b_0 + b_1 * X + b_2 * X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression. 

$ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2 
REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935
REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024

$ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2
REGCOEFF[0] = 0
REGCOEFF[1] = 1
C3dVoxelwiseRegression(voxelwise_regression: str)
voxelwise_regression: str

-voxreg, -voxelwise-regression: Regression between two images

Syntax: -voxreg regression_order

Perform regression between corresponding voxels in two images. This command takes two images as input, X and Y. This command finds parameters b_0, b_1, ..., b_k, such that Y is best approximated by b_0 + b_1 * X + b_2

  • X^2 + ... + b_k * X^k. Here is an example of linear regression.

$ c3d Y.nii X.nii -voxreg 2 REGCOEFF[0] = 5.56935 REGCOEFF[1] = 0.844024

$ c3d Y.nii X.nii -scale 0.844024 -shift 5.56935 -voxreg 2 REGCOEFF[0] = 0 REGCOEFF[1] = 1

def run(self, execution: styxdefs.types.Execution) -> list[str]:

7525        cargs = []
7526        cargs.extend(["-voxelwise-regression", self.voxelwise_regression])
