@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dWeightedSum: 
7639@dataclasses.dataclass
7640class C3dWeightedSum:
7641    """
7642    -wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights
7643
7644Syntax: `-wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN `
7645
7646Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack. 
7647
7648    c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii
7649
7650This command is particularly useful for combining components in a multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows: 
7651
7652    c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii
7653    """
7654    weighted_sum: str
7655    """-wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights
7656    
7657    Syntax: `-wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN `
7658    
7659    Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack.
7660    
7661    c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii
7662    
7663    This command is particularly useful for combining components in a
7664    multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to
7665    grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows:
7666    
7667    c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii"""
7668    
7669    def run(
7670        self,
7671        execution: Execution,
7672    ) -> list[str]:
7673        """
7674        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7675        
7676        Args:
7677            self: The sub-command object.
7678            execution: The execution object.
7679        Returns:
7680            
7681        """
7682        cargs = []
7683        cargs.extend(["-weighted-sum", self.weighted_sum])
7684        return cargs

-wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights

Syntax: -wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN

Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack. 

c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii

This command is particularly useful for combining components in a multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows: 

c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii
C3dWeightedSum(weighted_sum: str)
weighted_sum: str

-wsum, -weighted-sum: Weighed sum of images with constant weights

Syntax: -wsum weight1 weight2 ... weightN

Computes weighted sum of the last N images on the stack.

c3d image1.nii image2.nii image3.nii -wsum 0.2 0.7 0.1 -o wsum.nii

This command is particularly useful for combining components in a multicomponent image. For example, for an RGB image, we can convert it to grayscale (using [ImageMagick][13] formula) as follows:

c3d -mcs rgb.nii -wsum 0.29900 0.58700 0.11400 -o gray.nii

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dWeightedSumVoxelwise: 
7687@dataclasses.dataclass
7688class C3dWeightedSumVoxelwise:
7689    """
7690    -wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially varying weights
7691
7692Syntax: `-wsv `
7693
7694Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used.
7695
7696    c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7697
7698The **-reorder** command can simplify loading the images:
7699
7700    c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7701
7702### Commands: Image Header Manipulation
7703    """
7704    weighted_sum_voxelwise: str
7705    """-wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially
7706    varying weights
7707    
7708    Syntax: `-wsv `
7709    
7710    Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images
7711    must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used.
7712    
7713    c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii
7714    -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7715    
7716    The **-reorder** command can simplify loading the images:
7717    
7718    c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz
7719    
7720    ### Commands: Image Header Manipulation"""
7721    
7722    def run(
7723        self,
7724        execution: Execution,
7725    ) -> list[str]:
7726        """
7727        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7728        
7729        Args:
7730            self: The sub-command object.
7731            execution: The execution object.
7732        Returns:
7733            
7734        """
7735        cargs = []
7736        cargs.extend(["-weighted-sum-voxelwise", self.weighted_sum_voxelwise])
7737        return cargs

-wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially varying weights

Syntax: -wsv

Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used.

c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz

The -reorder command can simplify loading the images:

c3d weight*.nii image*.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz

Commands: Image Header Manipulation

C3dWeightedSumVoxelwise(weighted_sum_voxelwise: str)
weighted_sum_voxelwise: str

-wsv, -weighed-sum-voxelwise: Weighed sum of images with spatially varying weights

Syntax: -wsv

Computes weighted sum of N weight images and N scalar images. The images must be interleaved on the stack. All images on the stack are used.

c3d weight1.nii image1.nii weight2.nii image2.nii weight3.nii image3.nii -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz

The -reorder command can simplify loading the images:

c3d weight.nii image.nii -reorder 0.5 -wsv -o mysum.nii.gz

Commands: Image Header Manipulation

@dataclasses.dataclass
class C3dWrap: 
7582@dataclasses.dataclass
7583class C3dWrap:
7584    """
7585    -wrap: Wrap (rotate) image 
7586
7587Syntax: `-wrap <vector> `
7588
7589Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer components, possibly negative. For example, 
7590
7591    c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz
7592
7593will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20). 
7594
7595
7596### Commands: Options and Parameters
7597
7598Options change the behavior of commands that *appear later on the command line*. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will have no effect.
7599    """
7600    wrap: str
7601    """-wrap: Wrap (rotate) image
7602    
7603    Syntax: `-wrap <vector> `
7604    
7605    Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used
7606    to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer
7607    components, possibly negative. For example,
7608    
7609    c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz
7610    
7611    will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel
7612    at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20).
7613    
7614    
7615    ### Commands: Options and Parameters
7616    
7617    Options change the behavior of commands that *appear later on the command
7618    line*. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will
7619    have no effect."""
7620    
7621    def run(
7622        self,
7623        execution: Execution,
7624    ) -> list[str]:
7625        """
7626        Build command line arguments. This method is called by the main command.
7627        
7628        Args:
7629            self: The sub-command object.
7630            execution: The execution object.
7631        Returns:
7632            
7633        """
7634        cargs = []
7635        cargs.extend(["-wrap", self.wrap])
7636        return cargs

-wrap: Wrap (rotate) image

Syntax: -wrap <vector>

Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer components, possibly negative. For example, 

c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz

will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20).

Commands: Options and Parameters

Options change the behavior of commands that appear later on the command line. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will have no effect.

C3dWrap(wrap: str)
wrap: str

-wrap: Wrap (rotate) image

Syntax: -wrap <vector>

Wrap image around one or more voxel dimensions. Wrapping is typically used to correct for MRI wrap-around artifacts. The vector must have integer components, possibly negative. For example,

c3d badmri.nii.gz -wrap 0x20x0 -o fixedmri.nii.gz

will wrap the image in the second voxel dimension by 20 voxels (i.e., voxel at 10x40x20 will me moved to the position 10x20x20).

Commands: Options and Parameters

Options change the behavior of commands that appear later on the command line. This is very important. Specifying options after the command will have no effect.

C3dVersion, C3dVote, C3dVoteMrf, C3dVoteLabel, C3dVoxelSum, C3dVoxelIntegral, C3dVoxelwiseRegression, C3dWarp, C3dWarpLabel, C3dWrap, C3dWeightedSum, C3dWeightedSumVoxelwise],
7752    runner: Runner | None = None,
7753) -> C3dOutputs:
7754    """
7755    c3d.
7756    
7757    C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.
7758    
7759    Args:
7760        input_: The input image to process.
7761        output: The output image.
7762        operations: The operations to perform.
7763        runner: Command runner.
7764    Returns:
7765        NamedTuple of outputs (described in `C3dOutputs`).
7766    """
7767    runner = runner or get_global_runner()
7768    execution = runner.start_execution(C3D_METADATA)
7769    cargs = []
7770    cargs.append("c3d")
7771    cargs.extend(["-i", execution.input_file(input_)])
7772    cargs.extend(operations.run(execution))
7773    cargs.extend(["-o", execution.input_file(output)])
7774    ret = C3dOutputs(
7775        root=execution.output_file("."),
7776    )
7777    execution.run(cargs)
7778    return ret

c3d.

C3D is a command-line tool for medical image processing.

Arguments:
  • input_: The input image to process.
  • output: The output image.
  • operations: The operations to perform.
  • runner: Command runner.
Returns:

NamedTuple of outputs (described in C3dOutputs).
